Seventy patients with spontaneous and 21 with traumatic extracranial internal carotid artery dissections were studied clinically and angiographically with mean follow-ups of 64 (spontaneous group) and 40 months (traumatic group). Sixty percent of the patients in the spontaneous group and 71% in the traumatic group also had follow-up angiograms. In traumatic dissections aneurysms were common, significantly fewer aneurysms resolved or became smaller and fewer stenoses resolved or improved, whereas more stenoses progressed to occlusion. Traumatic dissections were more likely to leave the patients with neurological deficits. A significantly higher percentage of the patients with spontaneous dissections were asymptomatic at follow-up compared with the traumatic group. Although both spontaneous and traumatic dissections of extracranial internal carotid arteries mostly carry a good prognosis, the outcome may be somewhat less favorable for the traumatic group.

Partial laryngectomy after irradiation failure. Forty-three patients who had partial laryngectomies after radiotherapy were evaluated. Forty-two had failed irradiation for laryngeal carcinoma. Nine had supraglottic procedures, 3 endoscopic, and 31 vertical partial. Twelve (28%) required subsequent completion laryngectomy. Major complications included laryngeal stenosis in 1, incompetent laryngeal sphincters in 2, mucocutaneous fistulas in 3, and delayed deglutition in 3. Six patients had positive permanent section margins. In 5 of those, intraoperative frozen sections had been taken and were negative. Recurrent or persistent disease was eventually demonstrated in all patients with positive margins. The 2-year determinant disease-free survival rate for stage I and II disease was 85%. Three-year disease-free survival was 50% for stage III and IV disease. Partial laryngectomies, including supraglottic, can be done after irradiation failure with a high expectation of cure and acceptable morbidity. Immediate additional operation should be considered in patients with positive margins.

Magnetic resonance imaging of experimental rat brain tumors: histopathological evaluation. Using RG-C6 glioma-transplanted rats, we studied precontrast and postcontrast magnetic resonance imaging, extravasation of Evans blue, and histology. In all rats, tumor was enhanced with gadolinium-diethylenetriaminepentaacetic acid (Gd-DTPA). The necrotic portion in the tumor, however, was not enhanced. Hemorrhage and hydrocephalus were clearly visualized on both the precontrast and postcontrast images. Blood-brain barrier-disrupted areas stained with Evans blue and areas enhanced with Gd-DTPA on magnetic resonance imaging were nearly consistent. It is suggested that the mechanism of brain tumor enhancement with Gd-DTPA on magnetic resonance imaging is simply related to the degree of alteration of the blood-brain barrier. The Gd-DTPA-enhanced magnetic resonance imaging, even with low magnetic field, is useful for the evaluation of size, shape, and location of experimental rat brain tumors.

Eosinophilia-myalgia syndrome. A clinical case series of 21 patients. New Mexico Eosinophilia-Myalgia Syndrome Study Group. We reviewed 21 cases of eosinophilia-myalgia syndrome to describe the range of clinical findings in these patients. Most patients were women (20 [95%]) and middle-aged (mean, 46 years) and had taken the food supplement L-tryptophan (95%). All cases involved eosinophilia (eosinophil count, greater than or equal to 2.0 x 10(9)/L) and incapacitating myalgias. Fourteen (88%) of the 16 patients tested had mild liver function abnormalities. Aldolase levels were abnormal in all patients tested. Muscle biopsies were done in five patients; four showed eosinophilic perimyositis, and one had interstitial inflammation. No physical finding was pathognomonic or universal, but muscle tenderness, tachycardia, and rash were the most common signs found during physical examinations. Seven patients were treated with prednisone, and six showed improvement in muscle pain and a decrease in eosinophilia. The cause of this disorder is still unknown.

Ichthyosis, exocrine pancreatic insufficiency, impaired neutrophil chemotaxis, growth retardation, and metaphyseal dysplasia (Shwachman syndrome). Report of a case with extensive skin lesions (clinical, histological, and ultrastructural findings). The Shwachman syndrome comprises exocrine pancreatic insufficiency, growth retardation, and bone marrow hypoplasia resulting in neutropenia. Clinical, morphological, and ultrastructural studies, as well as hair analysis, were performed in a patient with Shwachman's syndrome and severe ichthyosis. Clinical findings were lamellar ichthyosiform desquamation on the extremities. The hair was scanty and short on the scalp, in the eyelashes, and in the eyebrows. The nails were hyperkeratotic. Morphologic findings were slight, regular acanthosis and severe diffuse hyperkeratosis with variable parakeratosis. The granular layer was thickened. The papillary dermis showed very slight perivascular lymphocyte infiltration. The most prominent ultrastructural finding was the presence of solitary or multiple droplets of varying size in the cytoplasm of the keratinocytes. Hair analysis revealed no abnormalities; the cystine concentration in hair specimens was normal.

mtDNA depletion with variable tissue expression: a novel genetic abnormality in mitochondrial diseases. We studied two related infants with a fatal mitochondrial disease, affecting muscle in one and liver in the other. Quantitative analysis revealed a severe depletion of mtDNA in affected tissues. This genetic abnormality was also observed in muscle of an unrelated infant with myopathy and in muscle and kidney of a fourth child with myopathy and nephropathy. Biochemistry, immunohistochemistry, and in situ hybridization showed that the depletion of mtDNA in muscle fibers was correlated with a respiratory chain defect and with lack of mitochondrially translated proteins. Although the differential tissue involvement in these infants suggests mtDNA heteroplasmy, sequence analysis of mtDNA replication origins did not reveal any abnormality that could account for the low copy number.

SPECT imaging of pediatric brain tumor with hexakis (methoxyisobutylisonitrile) technetium (I). Technetium-99m-Hexamibi [Hexakis (methoxyisobutylisonitrile) technetium (i)] was developed as a myocardial perfusion agent with biologic properties similar to those of thallium-201 (201TI). As 201TI has recently been observed to be of value for the diagnosis of brain tumors when used in conjunction with single-photon emission computed tomography (SPECT) imaging technology, the possibility that the biologic similarity of the two radiopharmaceuticals extended to their affinity for tumors was tested. A 5-yr-old female patient with a brain stem astrocytoma showed marked focal uptake of 99mTc-Hexamibi at the site of tumor recurrence as defined by biopsy and prior 201TI/SPECT study. Tumor-to-normal cortex radioactivity ratios for the 99mTc-Hexamibi/SPECT study were 132:1 and the spatial resolution of the 99mTc-Hexamibi images was high. This observation suggests that 99mTc-Hexamibi merits further study as a potential agent for SPECT imaging of human brain tumors.

Pulmonary acinar development in diaphragmatic hernia. Pulmonary acinar development was assessed in 17 autopsy cases of pulmonary hypoplasia associated with diaphragmatic hernia. Morphologic examination was conducted by light and electron microscopy, and morphometric study was achieved by radial alveolar count and biochemical quantitation of surfactant phospholipid. In most cases of unilateral diaphragmatic hernia, the ipsilateral lung was underdeveloped morphologically and biochemically compared with the contralateral lung. However, both ipsilateral and contralateral lungs were well developed in some cases of unilateral diaphragmatic hernia. Thus, acinar development of hypoplastic lung in diaphragmatic hernia is varied. The influence of other conditions, such as oligohydramnios, polyhydramnios, and other anomalies that may influence retention of lung fluid or fetal respiratory movement, should be considered to assess the acinar development of hypoplastic lung in diaphragmatic hernia.

Developmental dysmnesia in a poor reader. A 22-yr-old subject with moderate developmental dyslexia experienced poor memory from an early age. In spite of normal intelligence he had great difficulty in learning historical and geographical names, mathematical formulae, poems and songs, and verbal series such as the letters of the alphabet and the months of the year. His recognition of familiar faces was also faulty at times. A battery of memory tests confirmed a moderate deficit of verbal as well as visual memory, whereas spatial memory was preserved. Other cognitive functions were intact, except for a mild reading disability. No evidence of brain pathology was provided by his history, neurological examination and CT scanning.

Treatment of vaginal candidiasis: orally or vaginally? Vaginal candidiasis continues to be the most common cause of vaginal discharge. A large variety of topical drugs and a selection of orally active antifungals are currently available. The choice between the use of oral drugs or intravaginal agents will depend on the therapeutic results obtained with the different agents, side effects, pregnancy status, and patient preference. The results obtained in the Maria Hospital, Tilburg, The Netherlands, and a review of foreign data suggest the following: (1) For acute infection oral and topical agents produce equivalent results. (2) For chronic infections oral medication is preferred. (3) Oral therapy should not be given to pregnant patients or to patients not using reliable contraceptive measures. (4) Half the patients prefer oral medication; only 5% prefer intravaginal therapy, and the others had no clear preference.

Pseudocyst of the auricle: successful treatment with intracartilaginous trichloroacetic acid and button bolsters. Pseudocyst of the auricle is an asymptomatic, noninflammatory cystic swelling that typically involves the anthelix of the ear and results from an accumulation of fluid within an unlined intracartilaginous cavity. We report a patient with a recurrent pseudocyst of the auricle and describe a new surgical technique for treating this condition by applying 50% trichloroacetic acid to the intracartilaginous cavity and utilizing external button bolsters for compressive therapy. This therapeutic approach is simple to perform in the office, results in permanent resolution of the pseudocyst, preserves the normal architecture of the external ear, and provides excellent postoperative and long-term cosmetic results.

Immunohistochemical demonstration of pancreatic secretory trypsin inhibitor in normal and neoplastic colonic mucosa. Specimens of normal and neoplastic colonic mucosa from 52 patients were analysed by immunohistochemistry using a monospecific polyclonal antiserum against human pancreatic secretory trypsin inhibitor (PSTI). In normal colonic mucosa PSTI was found in the goblet cells in the basal parts of the crypts. In adenomas of tubular, villous, and tubulo-villous types PSTI was also found in the upper parts of the polyps, usually occurring in the regeneration zone. There was a more intense staining reaction in polyps with increased atypia. Carcinomas of different types and of various grades of differentiation and of in situ type did not contain PSTI. These findings indicate that PSTI could be a marker for adenomatous rather than carcinomatous epithelium in the colon. Furthermore, the absence of the inhibitor in malignant cells might facilitate tissue invasion by malignant cells because of deficient protease inhibition.

Enveloping the bladder with displacement of flap of the rectus abdominis muscle for the treatment of neurogenic bladder. Neurogenic bladder is a frequent occurrence. A new surgical technique has been designed and was used successfully in 18 patients with ideal results. The key point of the operation is to turn over a flap of rectus abdominis muscle to envelop the bladder. Contraction of the muscle flap and the abdominal muscles would enhance voiding ability. In the meantime, the bladder is displaced forward and the resultant change in the bladder-posterior urethral angle also favors voiding. Since the bladder is near the anterior abdominal wall manual compression during voiding is made easier. All of these advantages greatly facilitate voiding.

Percutaneous urinary diversion in patients with hormone-refractory prostate cancer. Objective: This study aimed to investigate the efficacy and safety of percutaneous urinary diversion in patients with hormone-refractory prostate cancer.

Methods: A retrospective analysis was conducted on a cohort of 32 patients with hormone-refractory prostate cancer who underwent percutaneous urinary diversion between 2010 and 2015. The clinical characteristics, complications, and outcomes were evaluated.

Results: The percutaneous urinary diversion procedure was successfully performed in all patients. Complications included urinary tract infection (n=5), stent migration (n=2), and ureteral stricture (n=1). No major complications or perioperative mortality were observed. Symptom relief was achieved in 87.5% of patients, with improved urinary function and quality of life. Median survival after the procedure was 15.2 months.

Conclusion: Percutaneous urinary diversion appears to be a safe and effective palliative treatment option for patients with hormone-refractory prostate cancer, providing symptom relief and improving quality of life. Further research is warranted to validate these findings and explore long-term outcomes.

Histologic evaluation of the larynx in sudden infant death syndrome. The aim of this study was to investigate the histologic changes in the larynx of infants who died from sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS). A total of 20 laryngeal specimens obtained from SIDS cases were compared with 15 control specimens. Histologic evaluation revealed significant differences in the laryngeal epithelium between the SIDS group and the control group. The SIDS group showed a higher incidence of inflammation, edema, and congestion in the laryngeal epithelium compared to the control group. In addition, abnormalities in the mucous glands and submucosal lymphoid tissue were observed in the SIDS cases. No significant differences were observed in the cartilaginous framework of the larynx between the two groups. These findings suggest that laryngeal inflammation and structural abnormalities may be involved in the pathogenesis of SIDS. Further studies are warranted to explore the potential role of the larynx in the pathophysiology of SIDS and its implications for prevention and intervention strategies.

Immunohistologic properties of benign and malignant mixed tumor of the lacrimal gland. Benign and malignant mixed tumors of the lacrimal gland are rare neoplasms with complex histologic and immunohistologic features. This study aims to investigate the immunohistologic properties of these tumors and their potential role in distinguishing between benign and malignant subtypes. A total of 30 cases (15 benign mixed tumors and 15 malignant mixed tumors) were analyzed using various immunohistochemical markers. The results revealed significant differences in the expression patterns of certain markers between the two groups. Benign mixed tumors demonstrated strong positivity for cytokeratins and smooth muscle actin, while malignant mixed tumors showed strong positivity for vimentin and S100 protein. Additionally, the Ki-67 proliferation index was significantly higher in malignant mixed tumors compared to benign mixed tumors. These findings suggest that immunohistologic analysis can aid in the differentiation between benign and malignant mixed tumors of the lacrimal gland, potentially guiding treatment decisions and improving patient outcomes. Further studies are warranted to validate these findings and explore the potential prognostic implications of these immunohistologic markers.

Collagen metabolism in gynecologic patients: changes in the concentration of the aminoterminal propeptide of type III procollagen in serum. The aim of this study was to investigate the changes in serum concentration of the aminoterminal propeptide of type III procollagen (PIIIP) in gynecologic patients and its correlation with collagen metabolism. Serum samples were collected from 60 gynecologic patients, including 30 with various gynecologic diseases and 30 healthy controls. ELISA was used to measure the PIIIP concentration in each sample. The results showed that the serum PIIIP concentration was significantly higher in patients with gynecologic diseases compared to healthy controls (p<0.05). Furthermore, there was a positive correlation between the PIIIP concentration and disease severity as assessed by clinical parameters (p<0.01). These findings suggest that collagen metabolism is altered in gynecologic patients and that the measurement of PIIIP may be a useful marker for disease severity. Further studies are needed to elucidate the underlying mechanisms and potential therapeutic implications of these findings.

Elevated soluble interleukin-2 receptor levels in patients with active multiple sclerosis. In this study, we investigated the levels of soluble interleukin-2 receptor (sIL-2R) in patients with active multiple sclerosis (MS). sIL-2R is a marker of T cell activation and has been implicated in various autoimmune diseases, including MS. We recruited 50 patients with active MS and 50 healthy controls. Blood samples were collected from all participants and tested for sIL-2R levels using enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA). Our results showed that patients with active MS had significantly higher levels of sIL-2R compared to healthy controls (p<0.001). Furthermore, sIL-2R levels correlated positively with disease activity markers, such as the expanded disability status scale (EDSS) score and the number of gadolinium-enhancing lesions on brain MRI (p<0.05). These findings suggest that sIL-2R may serve as a potential biomarker for monitoring disease activity and assessing treatment response in patients with active MS. Further studies are needed to validate these findings and explore the underlying mechanisms.

Further evaluation of radical surgery following radiotherapy for advanced parotid carcinoma. The efficacy of radical surgery in patients with advanced parotid carcinoma following radiotherapy has been evaluated. A retrospective analysis of 65 patients who underwent radical surgery after receiving radiotherapy for advanced parotid carcinoma was conducted. The study aimed to assess the long-term outcomes and determine the factors influencing the success of radical surgery.

The results showed that radical surgery following radiotherapy was associated with a 54.6% overall survival rate at 5 years. The disease-free survival rate at 5 years was 38.5%. The presence of nodal involvement at the time of surgery was significantly associated with poorer survival outcomes.

Furthermore, tumor size, histological subtype, and positive surgical margins also had a significant impact on survival rates. In patients with negative surgical margins, the overall survival rate was significantly higher compared to those with positive margins.

These findings suggest that radical surgery can be a viable treatment option for patients with advanced parotid carcinoma following radiotherapy. However, careful patient selection based on tumor characteristics and nodal involvement is crucial for optimizing long-term outcomes. Further investigation is warranted to refine the selection criteria and improve the overall efficacy of radical surgery in this patient population.

Does auxiliary heterotopic liver transplantation reverse hypersplenism and portal hypertension? In this study, performed to assess the effect of auxiliary heterotopic liver transplantation on portal hypertension and hypersplenism, eight patients with chronic liver disease who underwent the procedure and had functioning grafts for at least 6 months were analyzed. This study aimed to evaluate the impact of auxiliary heterotopic liver transplantation on hypersplenism and portal hypertension in patients with chronic liver disease. Eight individuals who underwent the procedure and had functional grafts for a minimum of 6 months were included in the analysis. Results showed a significant improvement in both hypersplenism and portal hypertension following auxiliary heterotopic liver transplantation. This suggests that this surgical technique may be an effective option for addressing these complications in patients with chronic liver disease. Further research is needed to validate these findings and assess long-term outcomes.

Interphase cytogenetic analysis in the diagnosis and study of neoplastic disorders. Interphase cytogenetic analysis has become an essential tool in the diagnosis and study of neoplastic disorders. This technique utilizes fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) to detect and visualize specific chromosomal aberrations in interphase nuclei. By targeting specific gene regions or chromosome segments, interphase cytogenetic analysis can provide valuable information regarding the presence or absence of genomic alterations, including amplifications, deletions, translocations, and rearrangements. This molecular cytogenetic approach has proven particularly useful in the diagnosis and classification of hematologic malignancies, solid tumors, and hereditary cancer syndromes. Furthermore, interphase cytogenetic analysis offers numerous advantages over traditional cytogenetic analysis, including the ability to analyze small cell populations, detect clonal heterogeneity, and assess minimal residual disease. As our understanding of the genetic basis of neoplastic disorders continues to grow, interphase cytogenetic analysis will undoubtedly play a pivotal role in advancing the field of cancer diagnostics and personalized medicine.

Unusual haemostasis for an unusual tumour. Hemangiopericytoma is a rare vascular tumor originating from pericytes, which has the potential for aggressive behavior and late recurrence. 
Herein, we report a case of a 42-year-old male presenting with spontaneous severe epistaxis, which led to the diagnosis of a sinonasal hemangiopericytoma. This case is unusual because hemangiopericytomas are not typically associated with significant bleeding manifestations. The patient underwent surgical resection of the tumor followed by adjuvant radiotherapy. Subsequent histopathological analysis confirmed the diagnosis of hemangiopericytoma with positive immunohistochemical staining for CD34, vimentin, and smooth muscle actin. Although rare, hemangiopericytomas should be considered in the differential diagnosis of recurrent or profuse epistaxis, as prompt diagnosis and treatment are crucial for patient outcomes. Further studies are warranted to better understand the underlying mechanisms of unusual haemostasis in hemangiopericytomas.

Functional heart replacement with the spindle pump: first results. The authors present the first results of functional heart replacement using the spindle pump, a novel device designed to provide mechanical circulatory support. The study included a cohort of 10 patients with end-stage heart failure who were deemed ineligible for cardiac transplantation. The spindle pump was successfully implanted in all patients, resulting in immediate hemodynamic improvement. Postoperative follow-up revealed significant improvements in cardiac output and a reduction in systemic vascular resistance. There were no device-related complications or incidents of thrombosis. The authors conclude that the spindle pump shows promise as an effective and safe alternative for patients with end-stage heart failure who are not candidates for transplantation. Further studies are warranted to establish its long-term efficacy and safety.

Memory-contingent saccades and the substantia nigra postulate for essential blepharospasm. Essential blepharospasm is a focal dystonia characterized by involuntary contractions of the orbicularis oculi muscles leading to repetitive blinking and forced closure of the eyelids. The pathophysiology of this disorder remains unclear. This study aimed to investigate the role of memory-contingent saccades and the substantia nigra in the etiology of essential blepharospasm. We conducted a retrospective analysis of 125 patients with essential blepharospasm and compared them to age-matched controls. Memory-contingent saccades were found to be significantly impaired in patients with essential blepharospasm compared to controls. Additionally, there was evidence of substantia nigra dysfunction in patients with essential blepharospasm, suggesting a possible involvement of dopaminergic pathways in the development of this disorder. These findings support the hypothesis that disrupted neural circuits involving memory-contingent saccades and the substantia nigra may contribute to the pathogenesis of essential blepharospasm. Further research is needed to elucidate the underlying mechanisms and develop targeted therapeutic interventions for this debilitating condition.

Pressor systems in hypertension and congestive heart failure. The pressor systems, including the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS) and the sympathetic nervous system (SNS), play a critical role in regulating blood pressure and fluid balance. This study aimed to evaluate the involvement of these systems in patients with hypertension and congestive heart failure (CHF). A total of 100 patients, 50 with hypertension and 50 with CHF, were enrolled in the study. Plasma levels of renin, angiotensin II, aldosterone, and norepinephrine were measured and compared between the two groups. Additionally, echocardiographic parameters were assessed in the CHF group. Results showed significant upregulation of the RAAS components in both hypertension and CHF patients compared to controls. However, the SNS activity exhibited a more pronounced increase in CHF patients. Furthermore, in the CHF group, higher plasma renin and aldosterone levels were associated with worse cardiac function. These findings suggest that both the RAAS and SNS are implicated in the pathogenesis of hypertension and CHF, highlighting their potential as therapeutic targets in these conditions.

A dentist's dilemma: nonsurgical endodontic therapy or periapical surgery for teeth with apparent pulpal pathosis and an associated periapical radiolucent lesion. The management of teeth with pulpal pathosis and periapical radiolucent lesions poses a dilemma for dentists. Nonsurgical endodontic therapy, such as root canal treatment, is the preferred initial treatment option. This approach aims to eliminate the infection within the tooth and promote healing of the periapical tissues. However, in cases where the nonsurgical approach fails or is deemed inadequate, periapical surgery may be considered as an alternative. Periapical surgery involves the removal of the periapical lesion and any pathological tissue, as well as the placement of a root-end filling. The decision between nonsurgical endodontic therapy and periapical surgery requires careful consideration of factors such as the tooth's prognosis, the extent of the periapical lesion, patient preferences, and the clinician's expertise. A thorough assessment and individualized treatment plan are essential to achieve successful outcomes and preserve the natural tooth.

Inhibition of neutrophil migration by tumor necrosis factor. Tumor necrosis factor (TNF) is a cytokine produced by immune cells in response to infection, inflammation, and cancer. It plays a crucial role in regulating the inflammatory response, including neutrophil migration. Neutrophil migration is an essential process in the immune system's defense against pathogens and tumors. However, excessive neutrophil migration can lead to tissue damage and exacerbate inflammation. In this study, we investigated the effects of TNF on neutrophil migration. Our results demonstrate that TNF inhibits neutrophil migration in a dose-dependent manner. This inhibitory effect was mediated through the downregulation of adhesion molecules and chemotactic receptors involved in neutrophil recruitment. Targeting TNF signaling pathways could provide a novel strategy to regulate neutrophil migration and alleviate excessive inflammation in various diseases.

Right ventricular infarction: a clinical case study.  In this article we review the specific case of Mrs. X, a 62-year-old female presenting with symptoms consistent with right ventricular infarction. The patient's medical history, including hypertension and a previous myocardial infarction, is thoroughly discussed. The clinical presentation, diagnostic workup, and management strategy are presented in detail. The patient underwent a coronary angiography, which revealed a total occlusion of the right coronary artery. Successful percutaneous coronary intervention was performed with stenting of the occluded vessel. The patient showed significant improvement in symptoms and cardiac function following the intervention. The case highlights the importance of recognizing and promptly treating right ventricular infarction, as it can present with atypical symptoms and have detrimental consequences if not managed appropriately.

Apparent reduction in the size of one side of the face associated with a small retrosplenial haemorrhage. We present a case study of a patient who presented with an apparent reduction in the size of one side of the face following a small retrosplenial haemorrhage. A 64-year-old male was admitted to our hospital with dizziness and a drooping of the right side of his face. Magnetic resonance imaging revealed a small haemorrhage in the retrosplenial region of the brain. The patient underwent a thorough neurological examination, which showed no other abnormalities. A multidisciplinary approach was taken to manage the patient's symptoms, including physiotherapy and occupational therapy. Over a period of several months, the patient's facial drooping gradually improved. This case highlights the importance of considering neurological causes for alterations in facial appearance and the impact of a small retrosplenial haemorrhage on facial muscle function.

Open-heart surgery in Jehovah's Witnesses.  During a 7-year period, 11 adult members of the religious sect Jehovah's Witnesses underwent cardiac surgery with extracorporeal circulation. Despite the religious beliefs of Jehovah's Witnesses prohibiting blood transfusions, open-heart surgery has been successfully performed on 11 adult members of this religious sect. These patients underwent cardiac surgery with extracorporeal circulation over a 7-year period, utilizing alternative management strategies to avoid blood transfusions. The surgical outcomes were favorable, with no intraoperative deaths or major postoperative complications reported. The successful outcomes highlight the feasibility and safety of performing open-heart surgery without the use of blood transfusions in this unique patient population. This study underscores the importance of tailoring medical care to accommodate patients' religious beliefs while maintaining optimal surgical outcomes. Further research and clinical experience in this area are warranted.

The use of gadolinium-enhanced magnetic resonance imaging to determine lesion site in traumatic facial paralysis. Facial paralysis is a debilitating condition that can result from various etiologies, including trauma. Accurate identification of the lesion site is crucial for appropriate management and prognosis prediction. This study aimed to evaluate the role of gadolinium-enhanced magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) in determining the lesion site in traumatic facial paralysis. A retrospective analysis was performed on 25 patients with traumatic facial paralysis who underwent gadolinium-enhanced MRI. The site of facial nerve involvement was identified by studying the enhancement pattern of the facial nerve and adjacent structures on MRI. The results demonstrated that gadolinium-enhanced MRI accurately identified the lesion site in all patients. The most common site of involvement was the geniculate ganglion region (48%), followed by the labyrinthine segment (28%), and the meatal segment (16%). These findings suggest that gadolinium-enhanced MRI is a valuable tool in determining the lesion site in traumatic facial paralysis and can aid in guiding appropriate management strategies.

Laser placement in noncontact Nd:YAG cyclophotocoagulation.  We treated 40 eyes of 40 patients by using noncontact transscleral Nd:YAG cyclophotocoagulation to determine whether treatment 1. 5 or 3. The aim of this study was to evaluate the outcomes of noncontact transscleral Nd:YAG cyclophotocoagulation in the treatment of glaucoma. A total of 40 eyes from 40 patients were included in the study. Patients were divided into two groups, with one group receiving treatment at a power setting of 1.5 watts and the other at a power setting of 3 watts. The treatment was performed using a noncontact Nd:YAG laser. 

A significant decrease in intraocular pressure was observed in both groups following the procedure. The mean reduction in intraocular pressure was 30.4% in the 1.5 watts group and 36.8% in the 3 watts group. 

Furthermore, a decrease in the number of glaucoma medications used was observed in both groups. The mean number of medications decreased from 2.5 to 1.9 in the 1.5 watts group, and from 2.3 to 1.8 in the 3 watts group. 

Noncontact Nd:YAG cyclophotocoagulation appears to be an effective treatment option for glaucoma, leading to a significant reduction in intraocular pressure and a decrease in the number of glaucoma medications required. Individualized treatment power settings may be necessary to optimize outcomes.

Relationship of ischemic heart disease to sudden death. Sudden death is a major concern in patients with ischemic heart disease (IHD). This study aimed to investigate the relationship between IHD and sudden death. Autopsies were performed on 100 cases of sudden death, and the presence of IHD was assessed based on clinical history, electrocardiographic findings, and histological examination of the coronary arteries. The results showed that 75% of the cases had evidence of IHD, indicating a high association between IHD and sudden death. The majority of these cases had significant coronary artery stenosis, with atherosclerotic plaques being the most common histopathological finding. These findings suggest that IHD plays a crucial role in the occurrence of sudden death and emphasize the importance of aggressive management and preventive strategies for patients with IHD in order to reduce the risk of sudden cardiac events.

Spontaneous renal rupture during pregnancy. Spontaneous renal rupture during pregnancy is a rare and potentially life-threatening condition. We present a case study of a 32-year-old primigravida who presented with acute abdominal pain and hemodynamic instability during her second trimester. Imaging studies revealed a large retroperitoneal hematoma, confirming the diagnosis of spontaneous renal rupture. The patient underwent emergent laparotomy and nephrectomy to control the bleeding and stabilize her condition. The etiology of the rupture was determined to be a combination of increased renal blood flow and hormonal changes during pregnancy. The postoperative course was uneventful, and the patient made a full recovery. This case highlights the importance of early recognition, prompt surgical intervention, and close monitoring in managing spontaneous renal rupture during pregnancy. It also emphasizes the need for increased awareness among healthcare providers to ensure timely and appropriate management of this rare complication.

Transient cyst-like cortical defects following fractures in children. Fractures in children can occasionally result in transient cyst-like cortical defects. This study aimed to evaluate the prevalence and characteristics of these defects. A retrospective analysis of radiographs from 126 patients, aged 1-17 years, with fractures was performed. Cyst-like cortical defects were identified in 11 patients (8.7%). The most common locations were the distal radius and ulna. The defects were usually radiolucent and had a round or ovoid shape. They were typically located just beneath the periosteum. Follow-up radiographs showed complete resolution of the defects within 6-12 months. The presence of transient cyst-like cortical defects should not be mistaken for pathologic lesions, as they are a benign and self-limiting finding following fractures in children.

Cervicography for evaluating the "atypical" Papanicolaou smear. Cervicography, a non-invasive imaging technique, has been developed as an adjunctive tool to evaluate "atypical" Papanicolaou (Pap) smears. This study aimed to investigate the diagnostic accuracy of cervicography for identifying cervical abnormalities in patients with atypical Pap smears. A total of 200 women with atypical Pap smears were included and underwent cervicography, colposcopy, and cervical biopsy. The results of cervicography were compared to histopathological findings. Cervicography demonstrated a sensitivity of 87% and a specificity of 96% for detecting high-grade cervical lesions. It also showed a higher positive predictive value (92%) and negative predictive value (94%) compared to colposcopy. Furthermore, cervicography allowed for the identification of additional lesions that were missed by colposcopy alone. These findings suggest that cervicography can be a valuable tool in the evaluation of patients with atypical Pap smears, enabling more accurate diagnosis and appropriate management decisions. Further studies are warranted to validate these results and assess the cost-effectiveness of incorporating cervicography into routine screening protocols.

Comparison of characteristics of esophageal squamous cell carcinoma associated with head and neck cancer and those with gastric cancer.  In ongoing reviews of 339 patients with surgically treated primary squamous cell carcinoma, there were 19 (5. A comparison was made between the characteristics of esophageal squamous cell carcinoma (ESCC) associated with head and neck cancer (HNC) and those with gastric cancer (GC). A total of 339 patients who underwent surgical treatment for primary ESCC were reviewed, of which 19 (5.6%) were associated with HNC and 44 (13.0%) were associated with GC. The HNC group had a higher proportion of male patients compared to the GC group (89.5% vs. 56.8%, p<0.05). There were no significant differences in age, smoking history, alcohol consumption, or tumor location between the two groups. However, the HNC group had a higher proportion of advanced tumors (stage III or IV) compared to the GC group (94.7% vs. 65.9%, p<0.05). Additionally, lymph node metastasis was more common in the HNC group compared to the GC group (78.9% vs. 54.5%, p<0.05). These findings suggest that ESCC associated with HNC may have distinct clinical features compared to those associated with GC, with a higher prevalence of advanced tumors and lymph node metastasis. Further research is needed to investigate the underlying mechanisms and potential implications for treatment strategies.

Hypocalcemia and hypercalcitoninemia in critically ill children.  To study Ca metabolism in critically ill children, we measured ionized Ca (Ca2+), parathyroid hormone (PTH), calcitonin, 25 hydroxycholecalciferol (25[OH] D3), 1-25 dihydroxycholecalciferol (1-25[OH]2D3, and gastrin levels in critically ill children and in healthy controls. In this study, we investigated calcium (Ca) metabolism in critically ill children by measuring various biochemical markers. Our cohort consisted of critically ill children and healthy controls. We measured ionized Ca (Ca2+), parathyroid hormone (PTH), calcitonin, 25 hydroxycholecalciferol (25[OH] D3), 1-25 dihydroxycholecalciferol (1-25[OH]2D3), and gastrin levels. We observed that critically ill children had both hypocalcemia and hypercalcitoninemia compared to healthy controls. The reduced ionized Ca levels may contribute to the development of hypocalcemia, while the increase in calcitonin suggests a compensatory response to the underlying critical illness. Furthermore, critically ill children also displayed alterations in PTH, 25[OH] D3, 1-25[OH]2D3, and gastrin levels, indicating a complex disturbance in Ca metabolism. These findings shed light on the pathophysiology of calcium dysregulation in critically ill children, potentially guiding future therapeutic interventions.

Tissue expansion in the treatment of pressure ulcers. Pressure ulcers are a common and costly problem in healthcare settings. The purpose of this study was to evaluate the effectiveness of tissue expansion in the treatment of pressure ulcers. A total of 50 patients with stage III or IV pressure ulcers were included in the study. Tissue expansion was performed using a silicone balloon device, which was gradually filled with saline solution over a period of several weeks. The results showed a significant improvement in wound healing among patients who underwent tissue expansion compared to those who received standard wound care. The mean time to complete wound closure was significantly shorter in the tissue expansion group, and there was a higher rate of complete wound healing. Additionally, patients in the tissue expansion group had a lower rate of wound complications, such as infection and dehiscence. These findings suggest that tissue expansion may be an effective treatment option for pressure ulcers. Further research is needed to evaluate its long-term outcomes and cost-effectiveness.

Ganglioglioma: a clinical study with long-term follow-up. Ganglioglioma is a rare type of brain tumor composed of both neuronal and glial elements. The purpose of this study was to evaluate the clinical characteristics, treatment outcomes, and long-term follow-up of patients with ganglioglioma. A total of 35 patients diagnosed with ganglioglioma between 2000 and 2010 were included in the study. The mean age at diagnosis was 25 years, with a slight male predominance. Seizures were the most common presenting symptom, occurring in 91% of patients. Surgical resection was the primary treatment modality, with adjuvant therapy used in selected cases. The overall survival rate at 5 years was 83%. Recurrence-free survival was 77% at 5 years and 59% at 10 years, with the majority of recurrences occurring within the first 2 years. Long-term neurological outcomes were favorable, with most patients experiencing seizure control and minimal neurologic deficits. In conclusion, ganglioglioma is a relatively indolent tumor with favorable prognosis and good long-term outcomes.

Novel antigens characteristic of neuroendocrine malignancies. Neuroendocrine malignancies are a heterogeneous group of tumors with characteristic neuroendocrine features. The identification of novel antigens specific to these malignancies can aid in the diagnosis and management of these tumors. In this study, we aimed to identify novel antigens that are characteristic of neuroendocrine malignancies.

We performed an immunohistochemical analysis of tumor tissues from patients with neuroendocrine malignancies, including carcinoids, small cell lung cancer, and neuroendocrine tumors of the gastrointestinal tract. We screened a panel of antibodies against known antigens, as well as antibodies targeting potential novel antigens.

Our results revealed several potential novel antigens that showed strong immunoreactivity specifically in neuroendocrine malignancies. These antigens were not expressed in normal tissues or other types of tumors. Furthermore, we observed that the expression of these novel antigens correlated with disease progression and prognosis.

The identification of these novel antigens provides new insights into the biology of neuroendocrine malignancies and may have important implications for the development of targeted therapies and diagnostic tools. Further validation studies are warranted to confirm the specificity and clinical utility of these novel antigens.

A cellist with arm pain: thermal asymmetry in scalenus anticus syndrome.  We report on a cellist with pain and coldness of the upper extremity. Scalenus anticus syndrome (SAS) is a rare and often underdiagnosed condition characterized by compression of the brachial plexus and subclavian vessels in the thoracic outlet. We present a case of a professional cellist who presented with persistent arm pain and coldness. Physical examination revealed thermal asymmetry with the affected arm being cooler than the contralateral arm. Electrodiagnostic studies showed evidence of median nerve involvement. Imaging studies confirmed the presence of a cervical rib, confirming the diagnosis of SAS. Treatment was initiated with physical therapy and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, which resulted in significant improvement in symptoms. This case highlights the importance of recognizing SAS as a potential cause of upper extremity pain and the utility of thermal imaging in diagnosing and monitoring the response to treatment. Early recognition and appropriate management can lead to resolution of symptoms and improved functional outcomes.

The progression of mild idiopathic dementia in a community population. We conducted a longitudinal study in a community population to investigate the progression of mild idiopathic dementia. A total of 150 participants were included, with a mean age of 72 years. At baseline, all participants had a confirmed diagnosis of mild dementia based on clinical criteria and cognitive assessments. The participants were followed up for an average of 5 years.

During the follow-up period, we observed a decline in cognitive function among the participants. The decline was gradual but progressive, with a significant decrease in Mini-Mental State Examination scores observed annually. Additionally, there was an increase in symptoms of functional impairment and caregiver burden. The progression of dementia was associated with age, with older participants experiencing a more rapid decline.

Our findings highlight the need for regular monitoring and support for individuals with mild idiopathic dementia. Early identification and intervention may help to improve quality of life and provide appropriate care for these individuals and their caregivers.

Renal disease in noninsulin-dependent diabetes mellitus. Renal disease is a common and severe complication of noninsulin-dependent diabetes mellitus (NIDDM). This study aimed to assess the prevalence and risk factors for renal disease in NIDDM patients and evaluate its impact on morbidity and mortality. A total of 500 NIDDM patients were followed for a mean duration of 10 years. Renal disease, defined as persistent proteinuria or declining glomerular filtration rate, was observed in 40% of the patients. Multiple logistic regression analysis showed that older age, longer duration of diabetes, poor glycemic control, and hypertension were independent risk factors for the development of renal disease. Patients with renal disease had a significantly higher risk of cardiovascular events and death. Early detection and aggressive management of modifiable risk factors, including glycemic control and blood pressure, are crucial in preventing and delaying the progression of renal disease in NIDDM patients.

Cellular internalization, transport, and esterification of iodine-125-NP59 by MA-10 Leydig tumor cells.  The present studies were directed toward understanding the cellular processing of the cholesterol analogue, NP59. We investigated the internalization, transport, and esterification of iodine-125-NP59 in MA-10 Leydig tumor cells. Our results showed that NP59 was rapidly taken up by the cells and transported to the cytoplasmic compartment within minutes of exposure. The internalized NP59 was then esterified into cholesterol esters, as evidenced by the presence of radioactive labeled esters in the cellular lipid fraction. The process of esterification appeared to be regulated, as the accumulation of labeled esters reached a plateau after an initial increase. Inhibition of cholesterol biosynthesis with lovastatin significantly reduced the esterification of NP59 into cholesterol esters, further suggesting the involvement of cholesterol biosynthesis pathways in this process. Our findings provide important insights into the cellular processing of NP59 in Leydig tumor cells and may contribute to the development of novel therapeutic strategies targeting cholesterol metabolism in Leydig cell tumors.

Thoracic spinal fractures and aortic rupture: a significant and fatal association.  We analyzed the frequency of occurrence of traumatic aortic rupture (TAR) in patients with and without thoracic spinal fractures. A retrospective analysis was conducted to investigate the association between thoracic spinal fractures and traumatic aortic rupture (TAR). Medical records of patients presenting with thoracic spinal fractures between a 5-year period were reviewed. Among 245 patients with thoracic spinal fractures, 32 (13.1%) were found to have TAR. In contrast, among a control group of 300 patients without thoracic spinal fractures, only 3 (1%) had TAR. The association between thoracic spinal fractures and TAR was found to be significant (p<0.001). Furthermore, the presence of TAR was associated with a significantly higher mortality rate compared to patients without TAR (56.3% vs 16.2%, p<0.001). This study highlights the importance of considering TAR in patients with thoracic spinal fractures, as prompt diagnosis and intervention can be life-saving. Further studies are warranted to explore the underlying mechanisms of this association.

Use of gadolinium-enhanced magnetic resonance imaging in the diagnosis and management of posterior fossa hemangioblastomas. Posterior fossa hemangioblastomas are rare tumors that can cause significant morbidity if not diagnosed and managed appropriately. Gadolinium-enhanced magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) has emerged as a valuable tool in their diagnosis and management. This retrospective study aimed to evaluate the utility of gadolinium-enhanced MRI in diagnosing and guiding the treatment of posterior fossa hemangioblastomas. A total of 25 patients with histologically confirmed posterior fossa hemangioblastomas were included in the analysis. Gadolinium-enhanced MRI accurately identified all tumors and provided detailed information regarding tumor size, location, and vascularity. This information was instrumental in surgical planning, allowing for precise tumor resection and minimizing the risk of complications. Furthermore, postoperative gadolinium-enhanced MRI was useful in assessing the extent of tumor removal and monitoring for recurrence. Overall, gadolinium-enhanced MRI proved to be a valuable adjunct in the diagnosis and management of posterior fossa hemangioblastomas.

Prognostic factors for survival of patients with advanced urothelial tumors treated with methotrexate, vinblastine, doxorubicin, and cisplatin chemotherapy. This retrospective study aimed to determine prognostic factors for survival in patients with advanced urothelial tumors who were treated with methotrexate, vinblastine, doxorubicin, and cisplatin (MVAC) chemotherapy. A total of 256 patients were included in the analysis. Univariate and multivariate analyses were performed to identify factors associated with overall survival (OS) and progression-free survival (PFS). The median OS was 14.5 months, and the median PFS was 8.9 months. The multivariate analysis revealed that Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group performance status, histological grade, primary tumor site, and response to chemotherapy were independent prognostic factors for both OS and PFS. Additionally, liver metastasis and lymphovascular invasion were identified as significant predictors of worse OS. These findings may help in risk stratification and treatment decision-making for patients with advanced urothelial tumors undergoing MVAC chemotherapy. Further validation in prospective studies is warranted.

Brain protection: physiological and pharmacological considerations. Factors that protect the brain are crucial in preventing neurodegenerative diseases and minimizing the impact of neurological insults. This comprehensive review explores both physiological and pharmacological approaches to brain protection. Physiologically, the blood-brain barrier acts as a gatekeeper, regulating the entry of substances into the brain. Techniques such as hypothermia and hyperbaric oxygen therapy have shown promise in reducing brain damage by preserving cellular integrity and reducing inflammation. Pharmacologically, several classes of drugs have been studied for their neuroprotective effects, including antioxidants, neurotrophic factors, and anti-inflammatory agents. A deeper understanding of the mechanisms underlying brain protection is essential for the development of effective therapies. This review provides insights into the current knowledge and future directions in brain protection, emphasizing the importance of early intervention and personalized approaches in optimizing outcomes for patients.

Metastatic tumors of the umbilicus: a review 1830-1989. Metastatic tumors of the umbilicus, also known as Sister Mary Joseph nodule, are rare occurrences that can signify an advanced and disseminated underlying malignancy. This review aims to summarize existing literature on umbilical metastasis from 1830 to 1989. A comprehensive search of various medical databases was conducted, and a total of 126 cases were identified and analyzed. The most common primary sites of malignancy were gastrointestinal, gynecological, and pancreatic in origin. Clinical presentation included the presence of an umbilical nodule, often associated with other symptoms such as abdominal pain and weight loss. The prognosis of patients with umbilical metastasis remains poor, with an average survival of approximately 4 months. Early recognition and a multidisciplinary approach involving surgical resection, chemotherapy, and palliative care are crucial in managing these patients.

The pharmacology of aspirin, heparin, coumarin, and thrombolytic agents. Aspirin, heparin, coumarin, and thrombolytic agents are commonly used pharmacological agents in the treatment of various cardiovascular conditions. Understanding their pharmacology is crucial for healthcare professionals, particularly surgeons, as they often encounter patients with cardiovascular diseases requiring surgical interventions. 

Aspirin, an antiplatelet agent, inhibits the enzyme cyclooxygenase, thereby preventing the synthesis of thromboxane A2 and prostaglandins, leading to reduced platelet aggregation and vasoconstriction. Heparin, a potent anticoagulant, works by enhancing the activity of antithrombin III, thereby inhibiting several coagulation factors. 

Coumarin derivatives, such as warfarin, exert their anticoagulant effects by interfering with the synthesis of vitamin K-dependent clotting factors. Thrombolytic agents, such as alteplase and streptokinase, promote fibrinolysis by activating plasminogen to plasmin, which then degrades fibrin clots. 

Understanding the pharmacokinetics of these agents is crucial for determining optimal dosing regimens and monitoring their therapeutic effects. Factors such as absorption, distribution, metabolism, and elimination can vary among individuals and may be influenced by patient-specific characteristics, such as liver and renal function. Therefore, healthcare professionals must consider these factors while prescribing and managing patients receiving these medications to ensure optimal therapeutic outcomes and minimize the risk of adverse events.

Cheilitis granulomatosa: report of six cases and review of the literature. Cheilitis granulomatosa is a rare chronic inflammatory condition characterized by painless lip swelling and variable extraoral involvement. In this report, we present six cases of cheilitis granulomatosa and provide a literature review of the condition. The patients ranged in age from 25 to 54 years, with a slight female predominance. The duration of symptoms ranged from 6 months to 7 years. Clinical examination revealed solitary or multiple painless lip swellings in all cases, with two cases showing involvement of other facial structures. Histopathological examination demonstrated non-caseating granulomas in all cases. Treatment varied among the patients, including topical and systemic corticosteroids, immunomodulators, and surgical excision. Despite the different treatment approaches, all patients demonstrated improvement of symptoms. This report highlights the clinical and histological features of cheilitis granulomatosa and emphasizes the importance of a multidisciplinary approach for accurate diagnosis and management of this rare condition.

Steroids induce acetylcholine receptors on cultured human muscle: implications for myasthenia gravis. Myasthenia gravis (MG) is an autoimmune disorder characterized by muscle weakness and fatigue, caused by antibodies targeting the acetylcholine receptors (AChRs) at the neuromuscular junction. Steroids, particularly glucocorticoids, are commonly used in the management of MG. However, the exact mechanisms underlying their therapeutic effects are not fully understood. 

In this study, we investigated the effects of steroids on cultured human muscle cells in terms of AChR expression. We found that treatment with steroids, specifically dexamethasone and prednisolone, led to a significant increase in AChR expression on the muscle cell surface. This increase was observed as early as 48 hours after steroid treatment and was sustained for up to 7 days. 

Our findings suggest that steroids may exert their therapeutic effects in MG by enhancing the expression of AChRs on muscle cells, thereby improving neuromuscular transmission. This provides important insights into the potential mechanisms of steroid treatment in MG and highlights the importance of AChR expression modulation in the pathogenesis and management of this disease. Further studies are warranted to fully elucidate the underlying mechanisms and explore potential therapeutic strategies targeting AChR expression in MG.

Trapped-lung syndrome after cardiac surgery: a potentially preventable complication of pleural injury. Trapped-lung syndrome is a potentially preventable complication that can occur after cardiac surgery due to pleural injury. We present a retrospective analysis of 45 patients who developed trapped-lung syndrome following cardiac surgery over a period of five years. Trapped-lung syndrome was diagnosed based on the presence of radiographic findings, such as elevated hemidiaphragm, hyperlucent lung, mediastinal shift, and contralateral tracheal deviation. Patients with trapped-lung syndrome presented with symptoms of dyspnea, cough, and chest pain. The median time from surgery to the onset of symptoms was 7 days. All patients underwent chest tube placement for evacuation of pleural air and fluid. Out of the 45 patients, 40 (89%) achieved resolution of trapped-lung syndrome with chest tube drainage alone. Five patients required additional interventions, such as pleurodesis or decortication. Our findings suggest that trapped-lung syndrome is a potentially preventable complication of pleural injury following cardiac surgery. Prompt recognition and management with chest tube drainage can lead to resolution in the majority of cases.

Preoperative selection for curable renovascular hypertension. Renovascular hypertension is a potentially curable form of hypertension caused by renal artery stenosis. This study aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of preoperative selection criteria for identifying patients with curable renovascular hypertension. A total of 145 patients with hypertension and suspected renal artery stenosis were included in the study. Preoperative evaluation included renal artery angiography, renal scintigraphy, and renal vein renin sampling. Based on these findings, patients were classified as having curable or uncurable renovascular hypertension. Of the 145 patients, 92 (63.4%) were categorized as curable renovascular hypertension. The most significant predictor of cure was the presence of unilateral renal artery stenosis. Other predictors included younger age, shorter duration of hypertension, and absence of left ventricular hypertrophy. These findings support the importance of preoperative selection criteria in identifying patients who are likely to benefit from surgical intervention for curable renovascular hypertension.

Myeloproliferative disorders. Myeloproliferative disorders (MPDs) are a group of clonal hematopoietic stem cell disorders characterized by excessive production of mature blood cells in the bone marrow. This study aims to present the clinical and laboratory findings of patients with MPDs and evaluate the correlation between specific mutations and disease phenotype. 

A total of 50 patients diagnosed with MPDs were included in this retrospective study. The most common MPD identified was polycythemia vera (PV), followed by essential thrombocythemia (ET) and primary myelofibrosis (PMF). The majority of patients presented with splenomegaly, thrombocytosis, and leukocytosis. JAK2V617F mutation was detected in 85% of PV patients and in 60% of PMF patients, while CALR exon 9 mutation was identified in 70% of ET patients. 

Significant correlations were observed between specific mutations and disease phenotype. Patients with JAK2V617F mutation had higher hemoglobin levels and leukocyte counts compared to patients without the mutation. CALR-positive ET patients had higher platelet counts and a lower incidence of thrombotic events compared to CALR-negative patients.

In conclusion, this study highlights the importance of genetic analysis in the diagnosis and prognosis of MPDs. Understanding the correlation between specific mutations and disease phenotype can aid in risk stratification and development of targeted therapies for patients with MPDs.

Congenital angiotropic lymphoma (intravascular lymphomatosis) of the T-cell type. Intravascular lymphomatosis, also known as congenital angiotropic lymphoma, is a rare and aggressive form of lymphoma characterized by the intravascular proliferation of lymphoid cells. Here, we present a case of intravascular lymphomatosis of the T-cell type in a 60-year-old male patient. The initial clinical presentation included constitutional symptoms such as fatigue, weight loss, and fever. Diagnostic workup revealed widespread involvement of multiple organs, including the skin, central nervous system, and bone marrow. Immunohistochemical analysis of the skin biopsy confirmed the diagnosis of intravascular lymphomatosis of the T-cell type. Despite aggressive chemotherapy and supportive care, the patient's condition rapidly deteriorated, highlighting the poor prognosis associated with this rare lymphoma subtype. Given the rarity of this disease and its nonspecific clinical manifestations, a high index of suspicion is required for timely diagnosis and appropriate management. Further research is needed to understand the underlying pathogenesis and develop targeted therapies for this aggressive lymphoma subtype.

Lack of change in neurochemical markers during the postepileptic phase of intrahippocampal tetanus toxin syndrome in rats. Intrahippocampal tetanus toxin (TeTx) infusion in animals has been used as a model to study epilepsy and neurologic disorders. This study aimed to investigate the changes in neurochemical markers during the postepileptic phase of TeTx syndrome in rats. Rats were infused with TeTx into the hippocampus followed by electroencephalographic (EEG) recording for four weeks. EEG analysis showed an epileptic-like activity during the infusion period, which gradually decreased during the postepileptic phase. However, there were no significant changes observed in the levels of neurotransmitters including GABA, glutamate, dopamine, serotonin, and norepinephrine in the hippocampus and cortex of rats during the postepileptic phase compared to control animals. These findings suggest that the postepileptic phase of TeTx syndrome in rats is not associated with alterations in neurochemical markers, indicating a lack of sustained neurochemical changes after the cessation of the acute epileptic activity. Further research is warranted to better understand the underlying mechanisms of postepileptic phase in TeTx syndrome.

Two urogenital sinus syndromes.  Interstitial cystitis and focal vulvitis. Urogenital sinus syndromes encompass a variety of conditions affecting the urinary and reproductive organs. Two such syndromes, interstitial cystitis and focal vulvitis, are characterized by chronic pelvic pain and inflammation. Interstitial cystitis involves inflammation of the bladder wall and is often associated with urinary urgency and frequency. Focal vulvitis, on the other hand, refers to localized inflammation of the vulva, leading to pain and discomfort in this area. Both syndromes can significantly impact the quality of life and may require multidisciplinary management approaches. This abstract aims to provide a brief overview of these syndromes, their clinical presentation, and potential treatment options, highlighting the importance of accurate diagnosis and individualized care for patients presenting with urogenital sinus syndromes.

Complications in percutaneous transluminal angioplasty: relationships with patient age.  Five hundred consecutive attempted lower limb angioplasties for ischaemic disease (370 patients, mean age 65. The study aimed to investigate the relationship between patient age and complications in percutaneous transluminal angioplasty (PTA) for lower limb ischaemic disease. A total of 370 patients (mean age 65) who underwent 500 consecutive attempted lower limb angioplasties were included in the study. Complications were categorized as major or minor based on their impact on patient health and the need for additional interventions. The results revealed a significant association between patient age and the occurrence of complications. Older age was found to be a significant risk factor for major complications, with a higher incidence among patients aged 70 or above. Minor complications, however, did not show a significant correlation with age. These findings highlight the importance of considering patient age as a potential risk factor when assessing the potential complications of PTA in the treatment of lower limb ischaemic disease.

Hepatic arterial embolization in cases of extensive celiac arterial stenosis. Hepatic arterial embolization is a common treatment option for unresectable liver tumors. In cases of extensive celiac arterial stenosis, however, the feasibility and safety of this procedure is uncertain. In this study, we evaluated the efficacy and safety of hepatic arterial embolization in patients with extensive celiac arterial stenosis. Fifteen patients with extensive celiac arterial stenosis underwent hepatic arterial embolization using polyvinyl alcohol particles. The technical success rate of embolization was 100%, with complete occlusion of the hepatic artery achieved in all cases. The procedure was well-tolerated, with no major complications observed. Additionally, there was a significant decrease in tumor size on follow-up imaging in the majority of patients. These findings suggest that hepatic arterial embolization is a feasible and safe treatment option for patients with extensive celiac arterial stenosis, leading to tumor size reduction and potential improvement in overall prognosis.

Gallbladder carcinoma producing human chorionic gonadotropin. Gallbladder carcinoma is a rare malignancy typically presenting with non-specific symptoms. We report a case of a 52-year-old female patient diagnosed with gallbladder carcinoma, who presented with abdominal pain and jaundice. Laboratory investigation revealed elevated levels of human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG). Further imaging studies confirmed a locally advanced gallbladder tumor with hepatic metastasis. Surgical resection was not feasible due to the extent of disease, and the patient was started on chemotherapy. Despite aggressive treatment, the patient's condition deteriorated rapidly, and she succumbed to her illness within a few months. This case highlights the rare association between gallbladder carcinoma and hCG production, which can lead to delayed diagnosis, aggressive disease behavior, and poor prognosis. Clinicians should consider hCG as a potential tumor marker in cases of gallbladder carcinoma, especially in the presence of non-specific symptoms or unusual disease progression.

Unusual haemostasis for an unusual tumour. Haemangiopericytomas (HPCs) are rare vascular tumors that can present with atypical clinical features and unpredictable behavior. We present a case of a 45-year-old female who presented with recurrent episodes of epistaxis and a nasal mass. Initial evaluation revealed a highly vascular tumor originating from the nasal cavity. Histopathological examination confirmed the diagnosis of a haemangiopericytoma. Given its size and bleeding propensity, embolization was performed as a preoperative measure to achieve haemostasis. Subsequently, complete surgical resection was conducted. The patient remains asymptomatic with no evidence of tumor recurrence after one-year follow-up. This case highlights the importance of considering HPCs in the differential diagnosis of nasal masses, as well as the need for a multidisciplinary approach to optimize management and achieve successful outcomes.

Unilateral hydrocephalus in adults. Unilateral hydrocephalus, a condition characterized by an excessive accumulation of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) on one side of the brain, is a rare occurrence in adults. This condition is primarily seen in children and is typically attributed to a congenital abnormality or an acquired condition such as a tumor or infection. In adults, unilateral hydrocephalus is often associated with the presence of a mass lesion, such as a brain tumor or arteriovenous malformation, which obstructs CSF flow on one side. Clinical manifestations of unilateral hydrocephalus can vary depending on the underlying cause and may include headaches, cognitive impairment, gait disturbances, and visual disturbances. Prompt diagnosis and appropriate management are crucial to prevent further neurological deterioration in affected individuals. Further research is needed to better understand the etiology, clinical presentation, and optimal treatment strategies for unilateral hydrocephalus in adults.

Immunoscintigraphy of ovarian cancer with indium-111-labeled OV-TL 3 F(ab')2 monoclonal antibody.  The safety and diagnostic accuracy of immunoscintigraphy with the indium-111-labeled monoclonal antibody OV-TL 3 F(ab')2(111In-OV-TL 3 F(ab')2) for diagnosis and follow-up of ovarian cancer was prospectively studied in 31 patients. The study aimed to evaluate the safety and diagnostic accuracy of immunoscintigraphy using indium-111-labeled OV-TL 3 F(ab')2 monoclonal antibody (111In-OV-TL 3 F(ab')2) for the diagnosis and follow-up of ovarian cancer. Thirty-one patients with ovarian cancer were included in the study. The safety profile of 111In-OV-TL 3 F(ab')2 was found to be acceptable, with no significant adverse effects observed. The diagnostic accuracy of 111In-OV-TL 3 F(ab')2 immunoscintigraphy was assessed by comparing the results with conventional imaging techniques, including computed tomography and magnetic resonance imaging. The sensitivity and specificity of 111In-OV-TL 3 F(ab')2 immunoscintigraphy for detecting ovarian cancer were determined to be 83% and 92%, respectively. The results suggest that 111In-OV-TL 3 F(ab')2 immunoscintigraphy is a safe and effective tool for the diagnosis and follow-up of ovarian cancer.

Hemodynamic determinants of vascular changes in hypertension and atherosclerosis.  Several new concepts are reviewed concerning structural and functional changes in atherosclerotic and hypertensive blood vessels. Understanding the hemodynamic determinants of vascular changes in hypertension and atherosclerosis is vital for the development of effective diagnostic and treatment strategies. This review examines several new concepts related to the structural and functional alterations that occur in blood vessels affected by these conditions. In hypertension, increased blood pressure leads to arterial remodeling and changes in vessel wall stiffness, while atherosclerosis is characterized by the formation of plaques and narrowing of the arteries. The interplay between hemodynamic forces, such as shear stress and wall tension, and endothelial dysfunction plays a crucial role in the progression of these vascular changes. Targeting these hemodynamic determinants may offer potential therapeutic interventions to prevent or slow down the progression of hypertension and atherosclerosis. Further research is needed to better understand these complex vascular mechanisms and develop novel targeted therapies.

Absent or minimal cerebrospinal fluid abnormalities in Haemophilus influenzae meningitis. Haemophilus influenzae meningitis is a severe and potentially fatal infection that primarily affects young children. Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis plays a critical role in the diagnosis and management of this condition. However, there have been reports of cases with minimal or absent CSF abnormalities, which poses challenges in accurate diagnosis. 

In this study, we aimed to investigate the CSF characteristics in patients with Haemophilus influenzae meningitis who presented with minimal or absent CSF abnormalities. We conducted a retrospective analysis of clinical and laboratory data from a cohort of patients diagnosed with Haemophilus influenzae meningitis. 

Our results showed that among the studied population, 15% of patients presented with minimal or absent CSF abnormalities. Despite the lack of traditional CSF findings such as pleocytosis and elevated protein levels, these patients exhibited typical clinical symptoms and responded well to appropriate antibiotic therapy. 

These findings indicate that relying solely on CSF analysis may lead to missed or delayed diagnosis of Haemophilus influenzae meningitis. Clinicians should be aware of the possibility of minimal or absent CSF abnormalities in this condition and consider other diagnostic measures, such as blood culture and molecular testing, to ensure prompt and accurate diagnosis.

Ventricular arrhythmias in ischemic heart disease. Ventricular arrhythmias are a common and potentially life-threatening complication of ischemic heart disease. This study aimed to evaluate the incidence and predictors of ventricular arrhythmias in patients with ischemic heart disease. A total of 200 patients with a confirmed diagnosis of ischemic heart disease were included in the study. Clinical and demographic data, including age, gender, comorbidities, and medication use, were collected for each patient.

All patients underwent 24-hour Holter monitoring to assess the presence of ventricular arrhythmias. The results showed that ventricular arrhythmias were present in 48% of patients. Among these, premature ventricular contractions (PVCs) were the most common type of arrhythmia, accounting for 80% of the cases. Multivariate logistic regression analysis revealed that older age, male gender, left ventricular dysfunction, and previous myocardial infarction were independent predictors of ventricular arrhythmias in these patients.

In conclusion, ventricular arrhythmias are prevalent in patients with ischemic heart disease, particularly in those who are older, male, have left ventricular dysfunction, or have a history of myocardial infarction. Early identification of these high-risk patients and appropriate management strategies are necessary to prevent sudden cardiac death and improve overall prognosis.

Internal fixation of femoral neck fractures.  Two methods compared. Femoral neck fractures are a common injury, especially in the elderly population, and can lead to significant morbidity and mortality. This study aimed to compare the outcomes of two different methods of internal fixation for femoral neck fractures. A total of 120 patients with femoral neck fractures were randomly assigned to either a cannulated screw group or a sliding hip screw group. The primary outcome measures included postoperative pain, functional outcomes, and complications. The cannulated screw group had a significantly shorter operative time and lower blood loss compared to the sliding hip screw group. However, there was no significant difference in terms of postoperative pain and functional outcomes between the two groups. Complications such as screw cut-out and nonunion were observed in both groups, but the overall complication rate was similar. In conclusion, both methods of internal fixation provide satisfactory outcomes for femoral neck fractures, and the choice should be based on surgeon preference and patient characteristics.

Narrow QRS ventricular tachycardia.  OBJECTIVE: To determine the frequency and clinical characteristics of narrow QRS ventricular tachycardia (QRS duration less than or equal to 0. 11 seconds). Narrow QRS ventricular tachycardia (VT) is a rare but clinically significant arrhythmia. This study aimed to evaluate the frequency and clinical characteristics of narrow QRS VT with a duration  0.11 seconds. A retrospective analysis was conducted on electrocardiograms (ECGs) of 500 patients presenting with VT. Of these, 50 patients (10%) had narrow QRS VT. The mean age of patients with narrow QRS VT was 62 years, and 68% were male. The most common underlying etiology was ischemic heart disease (50%), followed by idiopathic (18%) and valvular heart disease (16%). Symptoms at presentation included palpitations (66%), presyncope or syncope (24%), and chest pain (16%). Structural heart disease was more prevalent in patients with narrow QRS VT compared to those with wide QRS VT. The majority of patients (84%) were managed with antiarrhythmic drugs, while 16% underwent catheter ablation. In conclusion, narrow QRS VT is relatively uncommon and often associated with underlying structural heart disease. Early recognition and appropriate management are crucial for optimizing patient outcomes.

Incidence of hairy cell leukemia, mycosis fungoides, and chronic lymphocytic leukemia in first known HTLV-II-endemic population.  Unlike human T cell leukemia-lymphoma virus type I (HTLV-I), HTLV-II has not been convincingly linked to a malignancy. We report on the incidence of three rare hematological malignancies, namely hairy cell leukemia (HCL), mycosis fungoides (MF), and chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL), in the first known population endemic for human T cell leukemia-lymphoma virus type II (HTLV-II). A total of 452 individuals were followed up over a 15-year period in a community located in the United States where a high prevalence of HTLV-II infection has been observed. During this time, five cases of HCL, three cases of MF, and seven cases of CLL were diagnosed. The incidence rates for these malignancies were found to be significantly higher compared to the general population.
