These findings suggest a potential association between HTLV-II infection and the development of HCL, MF, and CLL in this particular population. Further studies are needed to elucidate the underlying mechanisms and explore potential therapeutic interventions.

Postictal psychosis after partial complex seizures: a multiple case study. Postictal psychosis (PIP) is a rare but well-recognized phenomenon following partial complex seizures (PCS). This multiple case study aims to investigate the clinical features and treatment outcomes of PIP in a cohort of patients with PCS. 

Five patients with documented PCS and subsequent PIP were identified from an epilepsy clinic in a tertiary referral center. Detailed medical histories, seizure semiology, and psychiatric symptoms were recorded. All patients underwent electroencephalography (EEG), neuroimaging, and psychiatric evaluations. 

The mean age at onset of PCS was 34 years, and the mean duration of seizures was 10 years. PIP episodes occurred within minutes to hours after the seizure activity and lasted for a mean duration of 1 week. Symptoms included delusions, hallucinations, agitation, and disorganized behavior. All patients exhibited abnormal EEG findings, with temporal lobe abnormalities being the most common. Neuroimaging showed no structural abnormalities in any of the cases. 

Treatment with antipsychotic medications resulted in resolution of psychosis in all patients. The mean follow-up duration was 2 years, and no recurrence of PIP was observed. 

In conclusion, PIP is a potential complication following PCS, characterized by acute psychotic symptoms. Prompt recognition and management with antipsychotic medications can lead to successful outcomes. Further research is warranted to better understand the underlying mechanisms and optimize treatment strategies for this unique clinical entity.

Expandable biliary metal stents for malignancies: endoscopic insertion and diathermic cleaning for tumor ingrowth. This study presents a cohort of patients who underwent endoscopic insertion of expandable biliary metal stents for the management of malignant biliary obstruction. A total of 40 patients with various primary malignancies were included. The stents were inserted successfully in all cases, with a technical success rate of 100%. Although the primary aim was palliation, 27 patients (67.5%) achieved long-term stent patency, with a median duration of 10 months. However, tumor ingrowth occurred in 8 patients (20%), leading to stent occlusion. Diathermic cleaning was performed in these cases, with a complete resolution of tumor ingrowth observed in 7 patients (87.5%). The overall complication rate was 22.5%, including cholecystitis, pancreatitis, and stent migration. In conclusion, expandable biliary metal stents provide effective palliation of malignant biliary obstruction. Diathermic cleaning is a valuable technique for managing tumor ingrowth, offering a minimally invasive alternative to stent revision or replacement. Further studies are warranted to optimize the long-term outcomes of these interventions.

Age-related hypotensive effect of placebo and active treatment in patients older than 60 years.  European Working Party on High Blood Pressure in the Elderly. This study aimed to investigate the age-related hypotensive effect of placebo and active treatment in patients over the age of 60 years. A total of 500 patients were enrolled in the study, with half receiving placebo and the other half receiving active treatment for their hypertension. Blood pressure measurements were taken at baseline and after 12 weeks of treatment. The results showed that both placebo and active treatment resulted in a significant reduction in systolic and diastolic blood pressure in the study population. However, when the data was analyzed by age group, it was found that older patients ( 75 years) experienced a greater reduction in blood pressure compared to younger patients (60-74 years) in both the placebo and active treatment groups. These findings suggest that older patients may be more responsive to the hypotensive effects of both placebo and active treatment in the management of hypertension.

Improved silver staining of nucleolar organiser regions in paraffin wax sections using an inverted incubation technique [published erratum appears in J Clin Pathol 1991 Jun;44(6):528] A new simple modification to the silver staining of nucleolar organiser regions (AgNORs) was devised which, by performing the incubation with the slide inverted, results in minimal undesirable background staining, a persistent problem. A modification to the silver staining technique for nucleolar organiser regions (AgNORs) in paraffin wax sections was developed. By inverting the slide during incubation, this modification reduces unwanted background staining. This technique addresses a common issue and improves the visualization and detection of AgNORs in histological samples.

Endoscopic ethmoidectomy and maxillary antrostomy in immunodeficient patients. Immunodeficient patients with chronic rhinosinusitis often require surgical intervention to improve their symptoms and quality of life. This study aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of endoscopic ethmoidectomy and maxillary antrostomy in this specific patient population. A total of 38 immunodeficient patients underwent the procedure, and their outcomes were assessed retrospectively. The overall surgical success rate was 84.2%, with significant improvements in symptom scores and sinonasal quality of life measures postoperatively. Complication rates were low, with only one patient experiencing a minor postoperative bleeding episode. No serious adverse events or infections were reported during the follow-up period. These findings suggest that endoscopic ethmoidectomy and maxillary antrostomy are safe and effective procedures for immunodeficient patients with chronic rhinosinusitis, offering significant symptom relief and improving their overall well-being. Further studies are warranted to confirm these results and optimize surgical outcomes in this patient population.

Hypertensive heart disease in African-Americans. Hypertensive heart disease is a major cause of morbidity and mortality, particularly among African-Americans. This population has a higher prevalence and incidence of hypertension compared to other racial/ethnic groups. The pathophysiology of hypertensive heart disease in African-Americans is complex and likely involves a combination of genetic, environmental, and socioeconomic factors. This review summarizes the current literature on the pathogenesis, clinical manifestations, and management of hypertensive heart disease in African-Americans. Key features include left ventricular hypertrophy, diastolic dysfunction, and an increased risk of heart failure and sudden cardiac death. The management of hypertensive heart disease in African-Americans should focus on blood pressure control, lifestyle modifications, and the use of antihypertensive medications that specifically target the renin-angiotensin system. Additionally, there is a need for further research to better understand the underlying mechanisms and develop targeted therapies for this high-risk population.

Cerebrospinal fluid endothelin-1 and endothelin-3 levels in normal and neurosurgical patients: a clinical study and literature review. Endothelins, specifically endothelin-1 (ET-1) and endothelin-3 (ET-3), are potent vasoconstrictors that have been implicated in several pathological conditions. This clinical study aimed to investigate the levels of ET-1 and ET-3 in the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) of normal individuals and neurosurgical patients. CSF samples were collected from 50 neurosurgical patients and 20 normal controls, and the levels of ET-1 and ET-3 were measured using enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay. Our findings indicate significantly higher levels of ET-1 and ET-3 in the CSF of neurosurgical patients compared to controls. Furthermore, a literature review provided insight into the potential diagnostic and prognostic significance of CSF endothelin levels in various neurosurgical conditions.

Different tumor-derived p53 mutants exhibit distinct biological activities. Mutations in the p53 tumor suppressor gene are commonly found in various types of cancers, and different mutant forms of p53 have been observed. However, the precise functional consequences of these distinct p53 mutants remain unclear. In this study, we aimed to investigate the diverse biological activities exhibited by different tumor-derived p53 mutants. Through in vitro assays and in vivo mouse models, we compared the effects of several commonly occurring p53 mutants on cell proliferation, apoptosis, and DNA repair. Our results revealed that different p53 mutants displayed varying abilities to induce cell cycle arrest and promote apoptosis. Additionally, we observed that certain p53 mutants exhibited impaired DNA binding and transcriptional activities compared to wild-type p53. These findings provide valuable insights into the functional heterogeneity of tumor-associated p53 mutants, which may have important implications for the development of targeted therapeutic strategies in cancer treatment.

Large diameter expanded polytetrafluoroethylene grafts for infrarenal aortic aneurysm surgery.  The performance of an expanded polytetrafluoroethylene (ePTFE) graft used for aortic aneurysm replacement was evaluated. The use of expanded polytetrafluoroethylene (ePTFE) grafts in infrarenal aortic aneurysm surgery has been widely adopted due to their excellent durability and biocompatibility. In this study, we aimed to assess the performance of these grafts in a cohort of patients undergoing aortic aneurysm replacement. 

A total of 100 consecutive patients who underwent infrarenal aortic aneurysm surgery using ePTFE grafts were included in the analysis. Clinical outcomes, including perioperative mortality, graft-related complications, and long-term survival, were evaluated. 

The overall perioperative mortality rate was 2%, with no deaths directly attributed to graft-related complications. The most common graft-related complications were graft infection (4%) and graft thrombosis (2%). The long-term survival rate at 5 years was 92%.

Our findings demonstrate that the use of ePTFE grafts in infrarenal aortic aneurysm surgery is associated with low perioperative mortality and satisfactory long-term outcomes. These grafts provide a durable and reliable option for the treatment of infrarenal aortic aneurysms.

The electrodiagnostic findings in polyneuropathies associated with IgM monoclonal gammopathies. Polyneuropathies associated with IgM monoclonal gammopathies are a heterogeneous group of disorders. We present a retrospective study of 25 patients with polyneuropathy and IgM monoclonal gammopathy, evaluating the electrodiagnostic findings and their correlation with clinical features. The majority of patients had distal symmetric sensorimotor polyneuropathy. Nerve conduction studies showed reduced compound muscle action potential amplitudes, prolonged distal motor latencies, and slowed nerve conduction velocities in most cases. Sensory nerve action potentials were also frequently affected, with reduced amplitudes and prolonged latencies. These electrodiagnostic findings correlated with clinical manifestations, such as sensory deficits, muscle weakness, and neuropathic pain. Understanding the electrodiagnostic patterns in these polyneuropathies associated with IgM monoclonal gammopathies can contribute to early diagnosis and appropriate treatment strategies for these patients. Further studies are needed to explore the underlying mechanisms and potential therapeutic interventions for this challenging group of disorders.

Treatment of chronic facial palsy by transplantation of the neurovascularized free rectus abdominis muscle. Chronic facial palsy is a debilitating condition that affects facial expression and function. Current treatment options include static and dynamic techniques, but satisfactory results are often limited. This study presents a novel approach to the treatment of chronic facial palsy using transplantation of the neurovascularized free rectus abdominis muscle.

A retrospective analysis was conducted on a cohort of patients who underwent this procedure between 2010 and 2015. Evaluation of pre- and post-operative outcomes was performed using validated facial nerve grading systems and patient-reported outcomes measures. 

Results showed significant improvement in facial symmetry and function in the majority of patients. The transplanted muscle provided dynamic movement and reanimation to the affected side of the face, resulting in improved smile, eyelid closure, and speech. Complications were minimal, with no major donor site morbidity reported.

This study demonstrates the efficacy and safety of neurovascularized free rectus abdominis muscle transplantation as a viable treatment option for chronic facial palsy. Further research is warranted to optimize patient selection and refine surgical techniques.

Association of immunoglobulin Km and Gm allotypes with specific antinuclear antibodies and disease susceptibility among connective tissue disease patients. We investigated the association between specific antinuclear antibodies (ANA) and disease susceptibility in connective tissue disease (CTD) patients, focusing on the immunoglobulin (Ig) Km and Gm allotypes. Serum samples from 200 CTD patients were analyzed for the presence of ANA using indirect immunofluorescence. ANA-positive patients were further genotyped for Ig Km and Gm allotypes. We found a significant association between specific ANA patterns and Ig Km/Gm genotypes. For example, ANA with speckled pattern was associated with Km1 and Gm3 genotypes, while ANA with homogeneous pattern was associated with Km1 and Gm5 genotypes. Additionally, specific Ig Km/Gm genotypes were found to be associated with increased susceptibility to certain CTDs, such as systemic lupus erythematosus and rheumatoid arthritis. These findings suggest a potential role for Ig Km/Gm allotypes in the pathogenesis of CTDs and the development of specific ANA patterns.

Coronary collateral recruitment: functional significance and relation to rate of vessel closure.  Studies in animals and humans have demonstrated the anatomic presence and functional significance of coronary collaterals. Coronary collaterals play a crucial role in maintaining myocardial perfusion in the presence of coronary artery disease (CAD). This study aimed to investigate the functional significance of coronary collateral recruitment and its relationship with the rate of vessel closure. Angiographic data from 150 patients with CAD were analyzed, and collateral flow index (CFI) was used as a measure of collateral recruitment. The results showed a positive correlation between CFI and the rate of vessel closure, indicating that higher collateral recruitment was associated with slower progression of CAD. Additionally, patients with well-developed collaterals had a lower incidence of myocardial infarction and better clinical outcomes. These findings highlight the importance of coronary collateral circulation in the management and prognosis of patients with CAD. Further studies are warranted to explore strategies for enhancing collateral recruitment and their potential therapeutic implications.

Emergency center ultrasonography in the evaluation of hemoperitoneum: a prospective study.  The reliability of ultrasonographic detection (US) of hemoperitoneum in blunt abdominal trauma was evaluated in a prospective study of 72 patients. The study aimed to evaluate the reliability of ultrasonographic detection of hemoperitoneum in blunt abdominal trauma. A total of 72 patients were included in this prospective study. Emergency center ultrasonography was performed to detect the presence of hemoperitoneum. The results were compared to the findings from subsequent surgical exploration or computed tomography (CT) scan. Out of the 72 patients, 41 were found to have hemoperitoneum on surgical exploration or CT scan. The ultrasound detection of hemoperitoneum showed a sensitivity of 85.4% and a specificity of 96.2%. The positive and negative predictive values were 95.3% and 88.2%, respectively. In conclusion, emergency center ultrasonography is a reliable tool for the evaluation of hemoperitoneum in patients with blunt abdominal trauma.

Ichthyosis, mental retardation, and asymptomatic spasticity. Ichthyosis is a rare genetic disorder characterized by dry, scaly skin. This case report presents a unique combination of ichthyosis, mental retardation, and asymptomatic spasticity in a 10-year-old male patient. The patient exhibited thick, fish-like scales covering the entire body, along with developmental delays and intellectual disability. Neurological examination revealed mild spasticity without any motor deficits or functional limitations. Genetic testing confirmed the presence of a known mutation in the gene responsible for ichthyosis. Further evaluation ruled out other causes of intellectual disability and spasticity. To our knowledge, this is the first reported case of ichthyosis associated with mental retardation and asymptomatic spasticity. The underlying pathophysiological mechanisms linking these conditions remain unclear. Further studies are needed to elucidate the genetic and molecular basis of this rare combination of symptoms. Clinicians should consider this association in patients presenting with ichthyosis and neurodevelopmental delay to ensure appropriate management and genetic counseling.

Thoracoscopic treatment of spontaneous pneumothorax using carbon dioxide laser. Spontaneous pneumothorax is a condition characterized by the accumulation of air in the pleural cavity, leading to lung collapse. This study aims to evaluate the efficacy and safety of thoracoscopic treatment using a carbon dioxide (CO2) laser for the management of spontaneous pneumothorax. A retrospective analysis was conducted on 40 patients who underwent thoracoscopic surgery for spontaneous pneumothorax between January 20XX and December 20XX. The surgical procedure involved the use of a CO2 laser to create multiple small lesions on the lung surface, aiming to induce adhesion and prevent air leakage. The success rate of thoracoscopic treatment using a CO2 laser was 95%, with only one patient experiencing a recurrence within six months. Additionally, postoperative pain and hospital stay were significantly reduced compared to traditional surgical approaches. The use of a CO2 laser in thoracoscopic treatment of spontaneous pneumothorax is a safe and effective technique that offers improved outcomes and patient satisfaction. Further prospective studies are warranted to validate these findings.

Incidence of gallstones in a Danish population.  Five-year incidence of gallstone disease was assessed by ultrasonography in an age- and sex-stratified random population of Danish origin aged 30, 40, 50, and 60 years.  The response rate was 82. 8% (2987/3608). The overall 5-year incidence of gallstone disease in the Danish population was found to be 10.2% (305/2987). The incidence was higher in women than in men (12. 8% vs 7. 2%) and increased significantly with age. Among individuals aged 30, 40, 50, and 60 years, the incidence rates were 5. 3%, 10. 2%, 12. 8%, and 14. 7%, respectively. Additionally, the incidence of gallstone disease was higher in individuals with a body mass index (BMI) 30 compared to those with a BMI <30 (15. 6% vs 9. 2%). These results suggest that gallstone disease is relatively common in the Danish population, particularly among older individuals and those with obesity.

Computerized neuropsychological assessment of cognitive functioning in children with epilepsy. This study aimed to evaluate cognitive functioning in children with epilepsy using computerized neuropsychological assessment. Fifty children diagnosed with epilepsy were included in the study, and their cognitive abilities were assessed using a battery of computerized tests. The results were compared with a control group of 50 typically developing children. The findings revealed significant differences in cognitive performance between the two groups. Children with epilepsy demonstrated lower scores in attention, working memory, processing speed, and executive functions compared to the control group. Furthermore, the average IQ was found to be lower in the epilepsy group compared to the control group. These findings suggest that children with epilepsy may experience difficulties in various cognitive domains, potentially impacting their academic achievement and overall quality of life. Early identification and appropriate interventions targeting these cognitive difficulties are crucial for optimizing the developmental outcomes of children with epilepsy.

Carcinoma of the ductus choledochus. Carcinoma of the ductus choledochus, also known as cholangiocarcinoma, is a malignant tumor arising from the bile duct epithelium. It is a rare form of cancer but is associated with poor prognosis due to its aggressive nature and late diagnosis. This retrospective study aimed to analyze the clinical and pathological characteristics of patients with ductus choledochus carcinoma. A total of 52 patients were included in the study, with a mean age of 62 years. The majority of patients presented with jaundice and abdominal pain. Pathological examination revealed adenocarcinoma as the most common histological subtype. Tumor stage was found to be a significant predictor of survival, with advanced stage tumors showing poorer outcomes. This study highlights the importance of early detection and aggressive management strategies for improving the prognosis of ductus choledochus carcinoma patients.

Myotonic heart disease: a clinical follow-up. A retrospective analysis was conducted to evaluate the clinical course of myotonic heart disease. The study included 75 patients diagnosed with myotonic dystrophy type 1 (DM1) who underwent follow-up evaluations over a mean period of 5 years. Cardiac symptoms were observed in 66 patients, with the majority presenting with conduction abnormalities (n=54). A significant proportion of patients (n=29) developed progressive cardiomyopathy evidenced by left ventricular dysfunction and increased wall thickness. Furthermore, 16 patients experienced sudden cardiac death during the follow-up period. These findings highlight the importance of close monitoring and prompt intervention in individuals with myotonic heart disease to mitigate complications and improve outcomes.

Clinical significance of white cell antibodies in febrile nonhemolytic transfusion reactions. Febrile nonhemolytic transfusion reactions (FNHTR) are common complications of blood transfusions. While the exact mechanism is not fully understood, the presence of white cell antibodies (WCA) has been suggested as a possible cause. This study aimed to determine the clinical significance of WCA in FNHTR.

A retrospective analysis was conducted on 150 patients who experienced FNHTR following blood transfusions. WCA levels were measured and compared between patients with and without clinical symptoms during the reaction. Additionally, the association between WCA and other clinical parameters, such as fever duration and severity, was investigated.

The results showed that patients with clinical symptoms exhibited significantly higher WCA levels compared to those without symptoms (p<0.001). Furthermore, WCA levels were positively correlated with fever duration (p=0.002) and severity (p=0.011).

In conclusion, the presence of WCA was found to be clinically significant in FNHTR, with higher levels being associated with the occurrence and severity of clinical symptoms. This highlights the importance of monitoring WCA levels in transfusion recipients to identify and potentially prevent FNHTR.

Evidence of a local immune activation in cystic brain tumors. Cystic brain tumors are rare neoplasms that present diagnostic challenges due to their complex histological features. Previous studies have suggested an association between inflammation and cyst formation in these tumors. In this study, we investigated the presence of immune cell infiltrates and cytokine expression patterns in cystic brain tumors. Immunohistochemical analysis revealed a significant infiltration of CD3+ T cells, CD20+ B cells, and CD68+ macrophages in the cystic wall compared to the solid part of the tumors. Additionally, we observed an upregulation of pro-inflammatory cytokines, including interleukin-6 and tumor necrosis factor-alpha, in the cystic wall. These findings provide evidence of a local immune activation within the cystic component of brain tumors, which may contribute to the pathogenesis and progression of these neoplasms. Further studies are warranted to elucidate the specific mechanisms underlying this immune response and its therapeutic implications.

Vegetables, fruits, and carotenoids and the risk of cancer. Previous studies have suggested that a high intake of vegetables, fruits, and carotenoids may be associated with a reduced risk of cancer. However, the evidence is still inconclusive and further research is needed to clarify these associations. This systematic review and meta-analysis aimed to summarize the current evidence on the relationship between vegetable, fruit, and carotenoid consumption and cancer risk.

A comprehensive search of electronic databases was conducted to identify relevant studies published up to a specified date. Studies that reported the association between vegetable, fruit, or carotenoid consumption and the incidence or mortality of various types of cancer were included. The quality of the included studies was assessed, and data were extracted for analysis.

Preliminary results from the included studies indicated a potential protective effect of vegetable, fruit, and carotenoid consumption against the development of certain types of cancer, including lung, colorectal, and breast cancer. However, the magnitude of the observed associations varied across studies, and the evidence was limited by heterogeneity, study design limitations, and potential confounding factors.

In conclusion, the current evidence suggests a possible beneficial role of vegetable, fruit, and carotenoid consumption in reducing the risk of certain types of cancer. However, further well-designed prospective studies and randomized controlled trials are warranted to establish the causal relationship and determine optimal intake levels for cancer prevention.

Laser placement in noncontact Nd:YAG cyclophotocoagulation.  We treated 40 eyes of 40 patients by using noncontact transscleral Nd:YAG cyclophotocoagulation to determine whether treatment 1. 5 or 3. This study aimed to investigate the efficacy and safety of noncontact transscleral Nd:YAG cyclophotocoagulation in the treatment of glaucoma. Forty eyes of 40 patients were included in the study. The treatment involved laser placement in either a 1.5 or 3-mm spot size. The outcomes measured were intraocular pressure (IOP) reduction, visual acuity, and complications. The results showed that both spot sizes achieved significant IOP reduction at six months follow-up. No statistically significant difference was observed between the two spot sizes in terms of IOP reduction. However, the 3-mm spot size group exhibited higher complication rates compared to the 1.5-mm spot size group. These complications included transient inflammation, iritis, and corneal epithelial defects. Therefore, these findings suggest that noncontact transscleral Nd:YAG cyclophotocoagulation is an effective treatment for glaucoma, with the 1.5-mm spot size showing fewer complications compared to the 3-mm spot size.

Evaluation of vigabatrin as an add-on drug in the management of severe epilepsy.  The effects of the addition of Vigabatrin, a new anti-epileptic drug, to the therapy of 128 patients with severe medically refractory epilepsy is reported. This study aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of vigabatrin as an add-on drug in the management of severe epilepsy. A total of 128 patients with medically refractory epilepsy were enrolled in the study. Vigabatrin was added to their existing anti-epileptic drug regimen and their seizure frequency and severity were monitored over a period of 12 weeks. 

The results showed a significant reduction in both the frequency and severity of seizures in patients who received vigabatrin as compared to their baseline values. The mean reduction in seizure frequency was 68%, with 55% of patients experiencing a greater than 50% reduction in seizures. 

Furthermore, vigabatrin was well-tolerated, with only mild and transient adverse effects reported. The most common adverse effects included drowsiness and dizziness. No serious adverse events or drug interactions were observed.

In conclusion, adding vigabatrin to the treatment regimen of patients with severe epilepsy resulted in a significant reduction in seizure frequency and severity. The drug was well-tolerated and showed a favorable safety profile. These findings suggest that vigabatrin could be a valuable adjunctive therapy for the management of medically refractory epilepsy. Further studies are warranted to confirm these findings and assess the long-term efficacy and safety of vigabatrin in this patient population.

Environmental risk factors in siblings with Parkinson's disease. Parkinson's disease (PD) is a neurodegenerative disorder characterized by motor symptoms such as tremors, rigidity, and bradykinesia. While genetic factors have been implicated in the development of PD, environmental influences also play a significant role. In this study, we aimed to investigate environmental risk factors in siblings with PD.

A total of 100 pairs of siblings with PD were included in the study. Data regarding potential environmental risk factors, including pesticide exposure, smoking, and rural residence, were collected through structured interviews. The results showed a higher prevalence of pesticide exposure in siblings with PD compared to controls (p<0.05). Additionally, a positive association was observed between smoking and PD risk in siblings (p<0.05). However, no significant association was found between rural residence and PD risk in siblings.

These findings emphasize the importance of considering environmental risk factors in the development of PD, particularly in individuals with familial predisposition. Further research is needed to elucidate the underlying mechanisms by which these environmental factors contribute to PD pathogenesis and to develop preventive strategies.

Periurethral colonic-type polyp simulating urethral caruncle. We present a rare case of a periurethral colonic-type polyp that simulated a urethral caruncle in a 56-year-old female patient. The patient presented with symptoms of dysuria and hematuria, and a urethral mass was observed during physical examination. Initial evaluation suggested the presence of a urethral caruncle, however, histopathological examination revealed a periurethral colonic-type polyp. This finding is extremely rare, with only a few cases reported in the literature. The diagnosis of periurethral colonic-type polyp can be challenging due to its uncommon nature and resemblance to other lesions in the periurethral region. Clinicians should consider this entity as a differential diagnosis in patients presenting with urethral masses to ensure appropriate management and treatment.

Oxidation reactions in Parkinson's disease. Parkinson's disease (PD) is a neurodegenerative disorder characterized by the loss of dopamine-producing cells in the substantia nigra. While the etiology of PD is multifactorial and poorly understood, there is increasing evidence implicating oxidative stress as a significant contributor to disease pathogenesis. This review aims to explore the role of oxidation reactions in PD.

Numerous studies have shown elevated levels of oxidative stress markers in the brains and peripheral tissues of PD patients. Oxidative damage to various biomolecules, including proteins, lipids, and DNA, has been observed in PD pathology. Mitochondrial dysfunction, impaired antioxidant defense mechanisms, and inflammatory processes are proposed mechanisms linking oxidative stress to PD.

Furthermore, genetic mutations in key genes involved in redox signaling and antioxidant defense pathways have been associated with increased susceptibility to PD. Emerging evidence suggests that these genetic factors may interact with environmental toxins and other risk factors, further enhancing oxidative stress-mediated damage.

Research into the development of therapeutic strategies targeting oxidative stress is ongoing. Antioxidant compounds, mitochondrial-targeted therapies, and modulators of redox signaling pathways present promising approaches in ameliorating PD symptoms. However, more in-depth studies are needed to better understand the complex interplay between oxidation reactions and PD to develop efficient preventive and therapeutic strategies.

Cosmetic, functional, independent: self-help aids. Self-help aids play a crucial role in maintaining independence and improving functionality among individuals with physical disabilities or limitations. This study aimed to investigate the impact of cosmetic, functional, and independent self-help aids on the overall well-being of individuals with such conditions. A total of 50 participants were enrolled in the study, each using a combination of self-help aids tailored to their specific needs. Results showed a significant improvement in overall quality of life and psychological well-being among participants who used self-help aids. Additionally, these aids were found to enhance mobility, self-care, and participation in daily activities. The findings highlight the importance of self-help aids in promoting independence, functionality, and overall well-being in individuals with physical disabilities or limitations. Further research is warranted to explore the long-term effects and benefits of these aids.

Surgical and prosthesis-related complications using the Groningen button voice prosthesis.  Prosthesis-assisted tracheoesophageal speech has advanced speech rehabilitation appreciably. The Groningen button voice prosthesis is commonly used for tracheoesophageal speech rehabilitation in laryngectomized patients. However, there is limited literature available on the surgical and prosthesis-related complications associated with its use. This study aims to evaluate these complications and their management.

A retrospective analysis was conducted on 97 laryngectomized patients who underwent placement of a Groningen button voice prosthesis. Surgical complications included temporary fistula formation (10.3%), prosthesis misplacement (7.2%), and surgical wound infection (4.1%). Prosthesis-related complications included prosthesis dislodgement (11.3%), leakage around the prosthesis (7.2%), and prosthesis blockage (6.2%). Management strategies varied depending on the complication, ranging from conservative treatment to surgical intervention.

The study highlights the importance of considering and addressing the potential surgical and prosthesis-related complications associated with the Groningen button voice prosthesis. Early detection and appropriate management of these complications are crucial to ensure optimal speech rehabilitation outcomes in laryngectomized patients. Further research and standardized guidelines are needed to effectively prevent and manage these complications.

The osteogenetic potential of fracture haematoma. Fracture hematoma plays a crucial role in bone healing and the initiation of the fracture repair process. This study aimed to evaluate the osteogenetic potential of fracture hematoma in a rat model. Fractures were induced in the tibias of 40 rats, and the fracture hematoma was collected at different time points post-fracture. Histological analysis revealed the presence of mesenchymal cells, osteoblasts, and osteoclasts within the fracture hematoma. Gene expression analysis showed upregulation of osteogenic markers, including Runx2 and alkaline phosphatase, indicating the presence of osteogenic cells within the hematoma. These findings suggest that fracture hematoma has the potential to contribute to bone healing and may serve as a valuable source of osteoprogenitor cells for bone repair therapies.

Anisocoria in unilateral ophthalmic disease.  Pupillary diameters in the affected and unaffected eyes of 327 patients with uniocular red eye were assessed during fixation of a distant target. Anisocoria, or unequal pupil size, is often observed in patients with unilateral ophthalmic disease. In this study, pupillary diameters were measured in both the affected and unaffected eyes of 327 patients presenting with uniocular red eye. During fixation of a distant target, the pupil sizes were compared between the two eyes. Results revealed a significant difference in pupillary diameter between the affected and unaffected eyes, with the affected eye displaying a smaller pupil size compared to the unaffected eye. This asymmetry in pupillary size suggests the presence of an underlying ophthalmic pathology affecting the pupillary control mechanisms. Overall, the assessment of anisocoria can serve as a valuable clinical sign to aid in the diagnosis and management of unilateral ophthalmic diseases.

Outpatient management of schizophrenia. Outpatient management plays an essential role in the treatment of schizophrenia, as it allows for ongoing support and monitoring of patients in a community setting. This abstract aims to highlight the various aspects of outpatient management for individuals with schizophrenia. It addresses the importance of medication adherence, psychoeducation, and psychosocial interventions such as cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) and supported employment. The use of antipsychotic medications, both first-generation and second-generation, is crucial in reducing symptom severity and preventing relapse. Furthermore, psychoeducation helps patients and their families understand the nature of the illness, treatment options, and coping strategies. Psychosocial interventions improve functional outcomes and include CBT to address cognitive deficits and supported employment programs to enhance vocational skills and integration into the workforce. The integration of these components in outpatient management provides comprehensive care and improved long-term outcomes for individuals with schizophrenia.

Local failure and related complications after definitive treatment of carcinoma of the prostate by irradiation or surgery. Treatment of carcinoma of the prostate with irradiation or surgery may result in local failure, leading to complications and potential disease progression. This abstract aims to discuss the incidence, risk factors, and management strategies for local failure and its complications following definitive treatment of prostate cancer. Both radiation therapy and surgery can result in residual tumor burden or recurrence, leading to local failure. The incidence of local failure varies depending on the treatment modality and tumor characteristics. Risk factors for local failure include high pre-treatment prostate-specific antigen levels, higher tumor stage, and positive surgical margins. Complications of local failure may include urinary incontinence, erectile dysfunction, urethral stricture, and rectal toxicity. Management strategies for local failure encompass salvage therapies such as salvage prostatectomy, salvage radiation therapy, and systemic therapies. Appropriate patient selection and a multidisciplinary approach are crucial for optimizing outcomes and minimizing complications following treatment for carcinoma of the prostate.

A comparative study of terbinafine versus griseofulvin in 'dry-type' dermatophyte infections. This study aimed to compare the effectiveness and safety of terbinafine and griseofulvin in the treatment of 'dry-type' dermatophyte infections. A total of 120 patients with clinically diagnosed dry-type dermatophyte infections were randomized to receive either terbinafine or griseofulvin for a duration of 6 weeks. The primary outcome measure was the rate of mycological cure, defined as negative fungal culture and negative direct microscopy at the end of treatment. Secondary outcome measures included clinical cure rate, time to cure, and incidence of adverse events. The results showed that terbinafine was significantly more effective than griseofulvin in achieving mycological cure (85% vs 60%, p<0.05) and clinical cure (80% vs 55%, p<0.05). Additionally, terbinafine had a shorter time to cure compared to griseofulvin (4.5 weeks vs 5.8 weeks, p<0.05). Both treatments were well-tolerated with no serious adverse events reported. In conclusion, terbinafine is a more effective and faster-acting treatment option for 'dry-type' dermatophyte infections compared to griseofulvin.

Degenerative lesions in the articular cartilage after meniscectomy: preliminary experimental study in dogs. This study aimed to investigate the degenerative lesions that occur in the articular cartilage following meniscectomy using a canine model. Six dogs were subjected to meniscectomy surgery in one knee joint while the contralateral knee joint served as a control. After a follow-up period of 6 months, the dogs were euthanized and the knee joint specimens were examined histologically. The results demonstrated significant degenerative changes in the articular cartilage of the meniscectomy group compared to the control group. These changes included fibrillation, loss of proteoglycans, and cartilage erosion. In addition, there was evidence of subchondral bone remodeling and synovial inflammation in the meniscectomy group. These findings suggest that meniscectomy leads to progressive degeneration of the articular cartilage, highlighting the importance of alternative surgical interventions to preserve joint health.

The use of bromodeoxyuridine cytokinetic studies as a prognostic indicator of cancer of the head and neck. Cancer of the head and neck is a significant health issue worldwide, with prognosis and treatment response varying among individuals. This study aimed to investigate the utility of bromodeoxyuridine (BrdU) cytokinetic studies as a prognostic indicator in this patient population. A retrospective analysis was conducted on 150 patients diagnosed with head and neck cancer who underwent BrdU cytokinetic studies. Results showed a significant correlation between the proliferation index as measured by BrdU incorporation and overall survival (p<0.001). Higher proliferation indices were associated with worse prognosis and decreased survival rates. Additionally, the proliferation index was found to be an independent prognostic factor, even when controlling for other known variables. Therefore, BrdU cytokinetic studies may serve as a valuable tool for predicting patient outcomes and aiding in treatment decision-making for cancer of the head and neck. Further prospective studies are warranted to validate these findings.

Benign parotid tumors: a 24-year experience.  The medical records of 125 patients benign parotid neoplasms surgically treated over a 24-year period were retrospectively reviewed; 128 tumors were excised. The aim of this study was to review the clinical characteristics, histopathological findings, and surgical outcomes of patients with benign parotid tumors over a 24-year period. A total of 125 patients with 128 tumors were included in the analysis. The mean age of the patients was 48 years, with a slight female predominance. The most common presenting symptom was a painless mass in the parotid region. Histopathological examination revealed pleomorphic adenoma in 82% of cases, followed by Warthin's tumor in 12% of cases. Surgical excision was the primary treatment modality, with complete tumor resection achieved in all cases. Recurrence rate was found to be 6.25%, with all recurrent tumors being pleomorphic adenomas. In conclusion, surgical excision is a safe and effective treatment for benign parotid tumors, with low recurrence rates.

Serum lipids and lipoproteins are less powerful predictors of extracranial carotid artery atherosclerosis than are cigarette smoking and hypertension The effect of serum lipids and lipoproteins on extracranial carotid artery atherosclerosis (CAS) was studied in patients who underwent carotid arteriography. Patients who underwent carotid arteriography were studied to investigate the impact of serum lipids and lipoproteins on extracranial carotid artery atherosclerosis (CAS). The extent of CAS was assessed using a severity score based on arteriographic findings. Analysis of serum lipids and lipoproteins revealed that higher levels of low-density lipoprotein cholesterol (LDL-C) and triglycerides were associated with an increased severity of CAS. However, these associations were relatively weak compared to other risk factors such as cigarette smoking and hypertension. Cigarette smoking was found to have the strongest association with CAS severity, followed by hypertension. The findings suggest that serum lipids and lipoproteins have a limited predictive value for the development and progression of CAS, highlighting the importance of other modifiable risk factors in the pathogenesis of this condition.

Evidence of a local immune activation in cystic brain tumors. This study aimed to investigate the presence of immune activation in cystic brain tumors through the analysis of immune cell infiltration and expression of immune markers. Tissue samples from 20 patients with cystic brain tumors were examined using immunohistochemistry. The results revealed a significant infiltration of immune cells, including lymphocytes and macrophages, within the tumor microenvironment. Moreover, there was a marked upregulation of immune markers, such as major histocompatibility complex II and CD68, suggesting an activation of the local immune response. These findings indicate that cystic brain tumors are associated with a local immune activation, which may have implications for the development of targeted immunotherapeutic strategies. Further research is needed to elucidate the specific mechanisms underlying this immune activation and its clinical significance in cystic brain tumors.

Selection of patients with stage B prostate cancer for radical prostatectomy.  There are several areas of concern in dealing with clinical stage B disease. The optimal management of clinical stage B prostate cancer remains unclear. This study aimed to determine factors associated with favorable outcomes following radical prostatectomy in patients with stage B disease. A total of 187 patients with clinical stage B prostate cancer who underwent radical prostatectomy were included in the analysis. Clinicopathologic variables, including age, prostate-specific antigen (PSA) level, Gleason score, and tumor volume, were assessed for their association with biochemical recurrence-free survival. The results showed that younger age, lower preoperative PSA level, lower Gleason score, and smaller tumor volume were significantly associated with improved biochemical recurrence-free survival. These findings suggest that careful consideration of these factors can help identify patients with stage B prostate cancer who are most likely to benefit from radical prostatectomy. Further studies are needed to validate these findings and determine the long-term outcomes of radical prostatectomy in this patient population.

A new syndrome: hearing loss and familial salivary gland insensitivity to aldosterone in two brothers.  Two male siblings presented in infancy with hyponatremia. They were found to have elevated plasma renin and aldosterone levels, indicating aldosterone resistance. They also had sensorineural hearing loss, which had not been previously reported in association with aldosterone resistance. Genetic testing revealed a homozygous mutation in the mineralocorticoid receptor gene (MR) in both siblings, confirming the diagnosis of pseudohypoaldosteronism type 1. The hearing loss in these patients could be explained by the expression of MR in the inner ear. This case highlights a novel genetic syndrome characterized by both aldosterone resistance and sensorineural hearing loss. Further studies are needed to elucidate the underlying mechanisms and potential targeted therapies for this condition.

Biliary pain in postcholecystectomy patients without biliary obstruction. Biliary pain is a common complaint in postcholecystectomy patients, even in the absence of biliary obstruction. This study aimed to investigate the potential causes of biliary pain in these patients. Thirty-seven postcholecystectomy patients with biliary pain, but no evidence of biliary obstruction on imaging studies, were included in the study. Laboratory tests, including liver function tests and serum amylase, were normal in all patients. Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) was performed in all patients to evaluate the biliary system. Results showed that 20 patients (54%) had evidence of sphincter of Oddi dysfunction, 10 patients (27%) had microlithiasis or sludge in the common bile duct, and 7 patients (19%) had non-specific findings. This study suggests that sphincter of Oddi dysfunction and residual stones/sludge can contribute to biliary pain in postcholecystectomy patients, highlighting the importance of considering these factors in the management of biliary pain in these patients.

Neonatal diarrhea at a maternity hospital in Rangoon Between 1981 and 1986, 1,540 infants born at the Central Women's Hospital in Rangoon were transferred to the Sick Baby Unit because of diarrhea (15. In this study, the incidence and characteristics of neonatal diarrhea were investigated in 1,540 infants born at a maternity hospital in Rangoon between 1981 and 1986. These infants were transferred to the Sick Baby Unit due to diarrhea complications. The results showed that diarrhea affected 15% of the infants, with the majority being males. The diarrhea episodes were mostly watery and occurred within the first week of life. The study highlights the need for appropriate management and preventive strategies to reduce the burden of neonatal diarrhea in this population.

Heterogeneity in spasmodic dysphonia.  Neurologic and voice findings.  Spasmodic dysphonia is a disturbance of phonation with laryngeal spasms. Spasmodic dysphonia is a rare neurological disorder characterized by involuntary and abnormal contractions of the laryngeal muscles during speech production, resulting in a strained or strangled voice quality. This study aimed to investigate the heterogeneity in clinical manifestations of spasmodic dysphonia and its correlation with neurologic and voice findings. A retrospective analysis of 50 patients with spasmodic dysphonia was conducted, evaluating their medical records, neurological examination findings, and acoustic and perceptual voice analysis results. The study revealed significant heterogeneity in the clinical presentation of spasmodic dysphonia, with variations in the age of onset, severity of voice symptoms, and associated neurologic findings. Additionally, acoustic and perceptual voice analysis findings demonstrated distinct profiles of voice impairment among different subtypes of spasmodic dysphonia. These findings emphasize the importance of personalized management strategies considering the heterogeneity in spasmodic dysphonia. Further research is warranted to elucidate the underlying mechanisms and develop targeted treatments for this complex disorder.

Drug response of head and neck tumors in native-state histoculture.  We describe a chemosensitivity testing of head and neck tumors, in which a native-state histoculture, ie, a three-dimensional culture system that maintains important in vivo properties, including tissue architecture, was used. A total of 23 head and neck tumor samples were obtained from surgical specimens and cultured in a native-state histoculture system. The tumor response to nine different chemotherapeutic agents was evaluated using a fluorescence-based assay. The results showed a wide variation in drug response among the tumor samples, indicating the heterogeneity of head and neck tumors. Interestingly, certain tumors exhibited significant sensitivity to specific drugs, suggesting potential personalized treatment options. Furthermore, the histoculture system maintained the tissue architecture and important in vivo properties, allowing for a more accurate assessment of drug response compared to traditional two-dimensional cell culture systems. In conclusion, native-state histoculture provides a valuable tool for evaluating the drug sensitivity of head and neck tumors and may aid in the development of personalized treatment strategies.

Blood pressure measurements during dental checkups representative of 26-hour registration.  The effect of dental checkups on blood pressure was investigated. The purpose of this study was to investigate the effect of dental checkups on blood pressure measurements and to determine if such measurements could be representative of a 26-hour registration. A total of 100 patients who visited a dental clinic for routine checkups were included in the study. Blood pressure measurements were taken before and after the checkup using an automated blood pressure monitor. In addition, ambulatory blood pressure monitoring (ABPM) was performed for a period of 26 hours, starting immediately after the checkup. The results showed a significant increase in systolic blood pressure (SBP) and diastolic blood pressure (DBP) immediately after the dental checkup compared to baseline measurements. However, the blood pressure measurements obtained during the dental checkup were highly correlated with the average measurements recorded during the 26-hour ABPM. These findings suggest that blood pressure measurements obtained during dental checkups can be representative of a 26-hour registration and may be used as a quick and reliable screening tool for monitoring blood pressure changes in dental patients.

Central airway obstruction due to cytomegalovirus-induced necrotizing tracheitis in a patient with AIDS. We present a case of a 34-year-old male with AIDS who presented with progressive dyspnea and stridor. Flexible bronchoscopy revealed extensive necrosis and sloughing of the tracheal mucosa, resulting in central airway obstruction. Histopathological examination of the tracheal tissue revealed necrotizing tracheitis with abundant cytomegalovirus (CMV) inclusion bodies. The patient was immediately started on antiviral therapy with ganciclovir, along with supportive measures including oxygen therapy and bronchodilators. Despite aggressive medical management, the patient's respiratory condition deteriorated rapidly, necessitating emergent tracheostomy for airway stabilization. Unfortunately, the patient developed severe complications including respiratory distress syndrome and multiorgan dysfunction syndrome, ultimately leading to his demise. CMV-induced necrotizing tracheitis is a rare and life-threatening complication in immunocompromised individuals, particularly in those with advanced HIV infection. Prompt diagnosis and early initiation of antiviral therapy are crucial in improving patient outcomes, however, the prognosis remains poor in most cases. Further research is warranted to explore potential preventive strategies and innovative treatment approaches for this devastating condition.

Cerebrospinal fluid fistula and endoscopic sinus surgery.  Seven cases of cerebrospinal fluid fistulae occurring as a result of endoscopic sinus surgery in a total of 800 ethmoidectomies are discussed, along with 1 case referred for consultation. Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) fistulae are rare but serious complications of endoscopic sinus surgery (ESS). We present seven cases of CSF fistulae occurring in patients who underwent ethmoidectomy as part of ESS, out of a total of 800 ethmoidectomies. In all cases, the fistulae were successfully managed with prompt diagnosis and appropriate treatment. One additional case was referred for consultation, which also had a CSF fistula following ESS. The patients presented with symptoms of persistent clear rhinorrhea and headache. Imaging studies, including CT and MRI, confirmed the presence of CSF leakage. All patients underwent surgical repair of the fistulae using various techniques, including endoscopic, external, or combined approaches. We emphasize the importance of early recognition and prompt management of CSF fistulae to prevent potential complications such as meningitis and pneumocephalus.

Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease from allogeneic dura: a review of risks and safety. Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD) is a rare, rapidly progressive, and fatal neurodegenerative disorder. While most cases are sporadic, there have been reports of iatrogenic transmission, particularly through contaminated neurosurgical instruments or allogeneic tissues. In this review, we present a case of CJD transmission from allogeneic dura mater grafts and discuss the associated risks and safety measures. A 54-year-old female presented with progressive cognitive decline, myoclonus, and visual disturbances following a previous craniotomy with dura mater graft for meningioma resection. The diagnosis of CJD was confirmed by characteristic clinical features, EEG findings, and detection of 14-3-3 protein in the cerebrospinal fluid. This case highlights the importance of considering CJD transmission risks associated with allogeneic dura mater grafts and the need for stringent donor selection, proper tissue processing, and effective sterilization techniques to minimize such transmission. Understanding these risks is crucial for neurosurgeons and healthcare professionals involved in allogeneic tissue transplantation to ensure patient safety.

Nitrite from inflammatory cells--a cancer risk factor in ulcerative colitis? Elevated levels of luminal nitrite and a lowered luminal pH were found in 77 percent of patients with acute ulcerative colitis. This study aimed to investigate the potential role of nitrite from inflammatory cells as a risk factor for cancer in patients with ulcerative colitis. Elevated levels of luminal nitrite were observed in 77 percent of patients with acute ulcerative colitis, along with a decreased luminal pH. These findings suggest a significant association between nitrite production and the inflammatory process in ulcerative colitis. Given that chronic inflammation is a known risk factor for the development of colorectal cancer, the presence of increased luminal nitrite in ulcerative colitis patients may contribute to their higher risk of developing colorectal adenocarcinoma. Further research is needed to elucidate the underlying mechanisms and potential therapeutic implications of this association.

Isolated congenital stapes ankylosis: surgical results in 32 ears and a review of the literature.  Isolated congenital stapes ankylosis is described in 32 operated ears from 28 patients. The study evaluated the surgical outcomes and reviewed the existing literature on isolated congenital stapes ankylosis in 32 ears from 28 patients. The mean age at presentation was 20.9 years. The most common presenting symptom was conductive hearing loss, followed by tinnitus and vertigo. Otoscopy revealed a fixed stapes in all cases. All patients underwent surgery, and the stapes was mobilized using various techniques including stapedectomy and stapedotomy. Postoperative audiograms showed significant improvement in hearing thresholds, with an average air-bone gap closure of 16 dB. Complications such as sensorineural hearing loss, vertigo, and tympanic membrane perforation were rare. The literature review identified a total of 71 reported cases of isolated congenital stapes ankylosis, with a male predominance and a mean age at presentation similar to the study cohort. In conclusion, surgical intervention for isolated congenital stapes ankylosis is a safe and effective treatment option for improving hearing outcomes in this patient population.

Protective and curative effects of rifampicin in Acanthamoeba meningitis of the mouse. Acanthamoeba is a free-living amoeba that can cause severe meningitis in humans. In this study, we investigated the protective and curative effects of rifampicin, an antibiotic commonly used for treating bacterial infections, in Acanthamoeba meningitis in mice. Mice were infected with Acanthamoeba and divided into three groups: a control group receiving no treatment, a prophylactic group receiving rifampicin prior to infection, and a therapeutic group receiving rifampicin after infection. We found that rifampicin significantly reduced the mortality rate in both the prophylactic and therapeutic groups compared to the control group. Additionally, mice in the therapeutic group showed a decreased inflammatory response and reduced brain tissue damage. These findings suggest that rifampicin has both protective and curative effects in Acanthamoeba meningitis and could be a potential treatment option for this life-threatening infection.

US-guided fine-needle aspiration biopsy of gallbladder masses.  Ultrasonically (US) guided fine-needle aspiration biopsy was performed in 88 patients who had gallbladder masses. The aim of this study was to evaluate the diagnostic accuracy and safety of US-guided fine-needle aspiration biopsy (FNAB) in patients with gallbladder masses. A total of 88 patients with gallbladder masses underwent US-guided FNAB, and the results were compared to histopathological examination after surgical resection. The sensitivity, specificity, positive predictive value, and negative predictive value of US-guided FNAB in diagnosing gallbladder masses were calculated. The overall diagnostic accuracy of US-guided FNAB was found to be 92%. The procedure was well-tolerated with no major complications observed. The results suggest that US-guided FNAB is a safe and accurate diagnostic tool for evaluating gallbladder masses, allowing for better preoperative planning and management decisions. This technique may help reduce unnecessary surgeries and improve patient outcomes.

Differences in the membrane interaction of scrapie amyloid precursor proteins in normal and scrapie- or Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease-infected brains. Scrapie amyloid precursor proteins (PrPSc) play a crucial role in the pathogenesis of sheep scrapie and human transmissible spongiform encephalopathies such as Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD). This study aims to elucidate the differences in membrane interaction between normal PrPSc and PrPSc from scrapie- or CJD-infected brains. Utilizing immunofluorescence and immunogold electron microscopy techniques, we show that normal PrPSc molecules exhibit a predominantly intracellular localization, while PrPSc from infected brains display a distinct localization pattern on the plasma membrane. Additionally, biochemical analyses demonstrate differential membrane association of PrPSc isoforms, with scrapie and CJD strains exhibiting increased membrane binding compared to normal PrPSc. This altered membrane interaction may be attributed to specific conformational changes and post-translational modifications in PrPSc during disease progression. Furthermore, the differential membrane binding of PrPSc isoforms may have implications for the pathogenic mechanisms and progression of scrapie and CJD, providing potential targets for therapeutic interventions.

Role of cell-mediated immunity to staphylococci in blepharitis. Blepharitis is a common inflammatory condition affecting the eyelids, often caused by staphylococcal infection. The immune response to staphylococci in blepharitis remains poorly understood. This study aimed to investigate the role of cell-mediated immunity (CMI) in the pathogenesis of blepharitis. Peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMCs) were isolated from patients with blepharitis and healthy controls, and their ability to mount a CMI response against staphylococcal antigens was assessed. Results showed that patients with blepharitis had significantly lower levels of staphylococcal-specific CMI compared to healthy controls. Furthermore, a positive correlation was observed between CMI response and clinical improvement in patients receiving intravenous immunoglobulin therapy. These findings suggest that a compromised CMI response to staphylococci may contribute to the development and persistence of blepharitis. Targeting CMI pathways could therefore be a potential therapeutic approach for managing this common ocular condition.

Effects of acute ethanol ingestion and burn injury on serum immunoglobulin.  Previous studies have found that acute ethanol ingestion before burn injury caused further impairment of mitogenic response of B lymphocytes compared with burn injury alone. In this study, the effects of acute ethanol ingestion and burn injury on serum immunoglobulin levels were investigated. A total of 30 male Wistar rats were divided into four groups: control, ethanol, burn injury, and ethanol + burn injury. The rats in the ethanol groups received an oral administration of ethanol (2 g/kg) 30 minutes prior to the burn injury. Burn injury was induced by placing a brass rod, heated to 100C, on the dorsal skin of the rats for 15 seconds. Blood samples were taken at 24 hours post-injury for the measurement of serum immunoglobulin levels using enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA). Results showed that acute ethanol ingestion before burn injury significantly decreased serum immunoglobulin levels compared to burn injury alone. These findings suggest that acute ethanol ingestion exacerbates the impairment of B lymphocyte function caused by burn injury, leading to a decrease in serum immunoglobulin levels.

Closure of leaking filtering blebs with cyanoacrylate tissue adhesive. Filtration surgery is commonly performed for the treatment of glaucoma. However, postoperative complications such as leaking filtering blebs can occur, leading to suboptimal outcomes. In this study, we aimed to assess the efficacy and safety of cyanoacrylate tissue adhesive in the closure of leaking filtering blebs. Fifteen patients with leaking filtering blebs were included in the study. Cyanoacrylate tissue adhesive was applied to the leaking site under topical anesthesia. The success rate of closure was evaluated at 1 week, 1 month, and 6 months postoperatively. Our results showed that cyanoacrylate tissue adhesive effectively sealed the leak in all cases without any major complications. Closure of leaking filtering blebs with cyanoacrylate tissue adhesive appears to be a safe and effective alternative in managing this postoperative complication.

Proximal posterior cerebral artery occlusion simulating middle cerebral artery occlusion. We present a case of proximal posterior cerebral artery (PCA) occlusion that clinically mimicked middle cerebral artery (MCA) occlusion. A 53-year-old male with a history of hypertension and smoking presented with sudden onset left hemiparesis and aphasia. Initial brain imaging showed no acute ischemic changes in the MCA territory, but subsequent magnetic resonance angiography revealed occlusion of the proximal PCA. The patient received intravenous thrombolysis and showed significant improvement in symptoms. This case highlights the importance of considering PCA occlusion in the differential diagnosis of stroke patients presenting with clinical features suggestive of MCA occlusion, especially in the absence of radiographic evidence of MCA occlusion.

Spinal cord inhibitory mechanisms in Parkinson's disease. Parkinson's disease is a neurodegenerative disorder characterized by motor symptoms such as tremors, rigidity, and bradykinesia. While the primary pathological feature is the loss of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra, recent evidence suggests involvement of other neural circuits. In this study, we investigated the role of spinal cord inhibitory mechanisms in Parkinson's disease. Using animal models and postmortem human spinal cord tissue, we found a significant reduction in the expression of inhibitory neurotransmitters such as GABA and glycine in the spinal cord of Parkinson's disease patients. Furthermore, electrophysiological recordings revealed increased excitability of spinal cord neurons in these patients. These findings suggest that impairment of spinal cord inhibitory mechanisms contributes to the motor symptoms of Parkinson's disease. Targeting these mechanisms could provide a novel therapeutic approach for the management of this devastating disorder.

Effects of pill-giving on maintenance of placebo response in patients with chronic mild depression Fifty outpatients with mild, chronic, mood-reactive depression whose mood improved markedly after a 10-day single-blind placebo trial were randomly assigned in a double-blind design either to have their placebo medication discontinued or to have it maintained for an additional 6 weeks. This study aimed to investigate the effects of pill-giving on the maintenance of placebo response in patients with chronic mild depression. Fifty outpatients who had shown significant improvement in mood after a 10-day single-blind placebo trial were included. They were randomly assigned to either discontinue their placebo medication or to continue taking it for an additional 6 weeks in a double-blind design. The results showed that patients who continued to take the placebo medication maintained the improvement in their mood, while those who discontinued the medication experienced a significant decline in mood. These findings suggest that pill-giving has a significant impact on the maintenance of placebo response in patients with chronic mild depression and highlight the importance of continued treatment in achieving sustained positive outcomes.

Cardiopulmonary resuscitation and the patient with cancer.  The records of 114 cancer patients suffering cardiopulmonary arrests (CPA) during a 3-year period at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center (MSKCC) were retrospectively reviewed to identify variables predicting final outcome in these patients. The overall survival rate to hospital discharge among the 114 cancer patients who experienced cardiopulmonary arrests (CPA) was 5.3%. 
Variables including age, gender, cancer type, cancer stage, location of CPA, and immediate cause of CPA were analyzed to predict final outcome. 
Univariate analysis identified age, cancer stage, and immediate cause of CPA as significant predictors of survival. 
Multivariate analysis revealed that advanced age and higher cancer stage were independent predictors of poor outcome. 
Patients with solid tumors had significantly worse prognosis compared to those with hematologic malignancies. 
The location of CPA did not significantly affect survival. 
In conclusion, age and cancer stage are important prognostic factors for survival in cancer patients experiencing CPA. 
These findings can help clinicians in making informed decisions regarding resuscitation efforts in this critically ill patient population.

Ultrasonography in the differentiation of complicated and uncomplicated acute pyelonephritis.  Differentiation of uncomplicated pyelonephritis versus complicated pyelonephritis has always been problematic. Acute pyelonephritis is a common infectious condition that can be further classified as either uncomplicated or complicated based on the presence of certain clinical features. Differentiating between the two is crucial for determining the appropriate management and prognosis of patients. This study aimed to investigate the utility of ultrasonography in distinguishing between complicated and uncomplicated acute pyelonephritis.

A total of 80 patients with diagnosed acute pyelonephritis were included in this prospective study. Ultrasonography was performed within 24 hours of admission to assess for the presence of complications such as abscess, renal stones, or obstruction. The results were compared to the gold standard of computed tomography (CT) scan findings.

The ultrasonography findings demonstrated a sensitivity of 82% and a specificity of 89% in distinguishing between uncomplicated and complicated acute pyelonephritis. Positive and negative predictive values were calculated as 89% and 82%, respectively. These results indicate that ultrasonography is a reliable imaging modality in the differentiation of complicated and uncomplicated acute pyelonephritis, providing valuable information to guide appropriate management decisions and optimize patient outcomes.

Nondiagnosed left main ostial stenosis partly due to the use of 5 French coronary angiographic catheters. Left main ostial stenosis is a rare but clinically significant condition that can lead to severe coronary artery disease and potentially life-threatening cardiac events. We present a case of a 57-year-old male patient who experienced angina pectoris and exertional dyspnea. Coronary angiography using 5 French catheters failed to identify the left main ostial stenosis. Subsequent computed tomography angiography revealed significant stenosis in the left main coronary artery, prompting the initiation of appropriate medical therapy and subsequent percutaneous coronary intervention. This case highlights the limitations of using 5 French catheters in the diagnosis of left main ostial stenosis and emphasizes the importance of considering alternative imaging modalities, such as computed tomography angiography, when clinical suspicion remains high despite negative angiographic findings. Early recognition and treatment of left main ostial stenosis are crucial in improving patient outcomes and preventing adverse cardiac events.

Moustache appearance in craniopharyngiomas: unique magnetic resonance imaging and computed tomographic findings of perifocal edema. Craniopharyngiomas are rare benign tumors derived from remnants of Rathke's pouch. We present two cases of craniopharyngioma with unique magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) and computed tomographic (CT) findings of perifocal edema presenting as a moustache appearance. Both cases had characteristic MRI findings of a solid-cystic mass arising from the sella turcica, with an eccentric enhancing mural nodule. In addition, perifocal edema in the form of a moustache-shaped hyperintensity on T2-weighted MRI and hypodensity on CT was observed. This moustache appearance has not been described previously in the literature and may represent a specific imaging finding associated with craniopharyngiomas. The presence of perifocal edema may be attributable to the tumor's close proximity to the hypothalamus and pituitary stalk, resulting in disruption of cerebrospinal fluid flow and inflammation. Recognizing this unique imaging finding can aid in the correct diagnosis and management of craniopharyngiomas. Further studies are needed to determine the prevalence and significance of the moustache appearance in craniopharyngiomas.

Germfree animals and technics in surgical research. The use of germfree animals in surgical research has become increasingly important in recent years due to their ability to provide a controlled environment for studying the effects of surgical interventions. This method involves the use of animals that are free from any known pathogens or microbiota, allowing researchers to study the direct impact of surgical procedures without confounding factors.

In this study, we aimed to investigate the utility of germfree animals in surgical research by comparing surgical outcomes in germfree and conventional animals. We designed an experimental model using mice undergoing a standardized surgical procedure. We assessed various parameters including wound healing, inflammation, and infection rates in both groups.

Our results showed that germfree animals exhibited improved wound healing, reduced inflammation, and a lower incidence of surgical site infection compared to conventional animals. These findings suggest that the absence of microbiota in germfree animals may contribute to improved surgical outcomes by minimizing the risk of infection and enhancing the wound healing process.

In conclusion, the use of germfree animals in surgical research offers a valuable tool for understanding the underlying mechanisms of surgical interventions and may help guide the development of more effective surgical techniques and strategies. Further studies are warranted to explore the full potential of germfree animals in surgical research.

Results of treatment of displaced patellar fractures by partial patellectomy. This study presents the results of treatment of displaced patellar fractures by partial patellectomy in a cohort of patients. A retrospective analysis was conducted on 25 patients who underwent partial patellectomy for displaced patellar fractures. The mean age of the patients was 41 years and the mean follow-up period was 3 years. The functional outcomes were assessed using the Modified Bstman scoring system. The mean score for knee function was 86.5, indicating a satisfactory outcome. Radiographic evaluation showed good alignment and bony union in all cases. Complications were observed in 5 patients, including postoperative infection and patellar tendon rupture. The results suggest that partial patellectomy is a viable option for the treatment of displaced patellar fractures in selected cases. However, careful patient selection, meticulous surgical technique, and appropriate postoperative rehabilitation are essential to minimize complications and achieve optimal functional outcomes. Further studies with larger sample sizes and longer follow-up periods are warranted to validate these findings.

Overnight admission of outpatient strabismus patients.  The trend to outpatient strabismus surgery prompted us to determine the frequency of, and the reasons for, postoperative overnight hospital admission following such surgery. As the popularity of outpatient strabismus surgery increases, it becomes important to evaluate the need for postoperative overnight hospital admission and understand the factors influencing this decision. In this study, we aimed to determine the frequency and reasons for overnight admission of patients undergoing outpatient strabismus surgery. 

A retrospective analysis of medical records was conducted for patients who underwent strabismus surgery in an outpatient setting. The data collected included patient demographics, surgical details, anesthesia type, and postoperative outcomes. 

Among the 500 patients included in the analysis, 15% required overnight admission. The most common reasons for admission were postoperative pain control (45%), persistent nausea and vomiting (25%), and concern for potential complications (20%). The mean length of stay for admitted patients was 1.7 days. 

These findings highlight the importance of individualized patient care planning and appropriate postoperative monitoring, even in the context of outpatient strabismus surgery. Further research is warranted to develop guidelines for identifying patients who may benefit from overnight admission and to optimize postoperative pain management and complication prevention strategies in this setting.

Therapy of persistent human papillomavirus disease with two different interferon species. Persistent human papillomavirus (HPV) infection is a significant public health concern, with the potential to progress to cervical cancer and other malignancies.
