Current treatment options for persistent HPV infection are limited, and there is a need for effective therapeutic strategies. This study aimed to evaluate the efficacy of treatment with two different species of interferon (IFN) in patients with persistent HPV disease. 

A total of 83 patients with persistent HPV infection were enrolled in the study. They were randomly assigned to receive either IFN-alpha or IFN-gamma therapy. Treatment was administered for a duration of 12 weeks, and patients were followed up for a period of 24 weeks. 

Results showed that both IFN-alpha and IFN-gamma therapy were effective in reducing HPV viral load and achieving clinical remission. However, the response rate was higher in the IFN-gamma group compared to the IFN-alpha group (76% vs. 60%, respectively). Adverse events were mild and transient, with no significant differences observed between the two treatment groups.

In conclusion, treatment with both IFN-alpha and IFN-gamma is effective in the management of persistent HPV infection. However, IFN-gamma therapy may offer superior clinical outcomes. Further research is needed to optimize treatment protocols and explore the long-term efficacy and safety of IFN therapy in this patient population.

Dissociation between pain and autonomic disturbances in cluster headache. Cluster headache (CH) is a severe headache disorder characterized by excruciating unilateral pain accompanied by autonomic disturbances. However, few studies have investigated the relationship between pain and autonomic symptoms in CH. This study aimed to determine whether pain intensity and frequency correlate with the severity of autonomic symptoms in CH patients. A total of 50 CH patients were enrolled and evaluated for pain intensity using a visual analog scale (VAS) and autonomic symptoms using the Autonomic Symptom Questionnaire (ASQ). Pearson correlation analysis was performed to assess the relationship between pain intensity and ASQ scores. Surprisingly, our results showed no significant correlation between pain intensity and the severity of autonomic symptoms in CH patients. This dissociation suggests that pain and autonomic disturbances may have separate underlying mechanisms in CH. Further research is needed to elucidate the pathophysiology of autonomic symptoms in CH and to develop targeted treatment strategies for these debilitating symptoms.

Reduction of the membrane fluidity of human breast cancer cells by tamoxifen and 17 beta-estradiol. Tamoxifen is a commonly used hormonal therapy for breast cancer, but its mechanism of action is not fully understood. In this study, we investigated the effect of tamoxifen and 17 beta-estradiol on the membrane fluidity of human breast cancer cells. We found that both tamoxifen and 17 beta-estradiol significantly reduced the membrane fluidity of breast cancer cells. This effect was dose-dependent and more pronounced with tamoxifen compared to 17 beta-estradiol. Furthermore, the reduction in membrane fluidity was accompanied by alterations in the lipid composition of the cell membrane. These findings suggest that tamoxifen and 17 beta-estradiol may exert their anti-cancer effects, at least in part, by modulating the biophysical properties of the cell membrane. Further studies are needed to elucidate the underlying molecular mechanisms and potential clinical implications of these findings.

Application of coronary angioplasty to the septal perforator arteries. Coronary angioplasty has been widely used to treat ischemic heart disease. However, the application of this technique to septal perforator arteries has been limited. In this study, we present the outcomes of coronary angioplasty performed on septal perforator arteries in patients with myocardial ischemia. A total of 27 patients underwent this procedure and were followed up for a median duration of 12 months. The majority of patients (81%) showed improvement in angina symptoms, as evidenced by reduced frequency and severity of chest pain episodes. Additionally, there was a significant improvement in exercise capacity and myocardial perfusion, as assessed by stress testing and nuclear imaging. No major complications were observed during the procedure or during follow-up, suggesting that coronary angioplasty on septal perforator arteries is a safe and effective treatment option for patients with myocardial ischemia.

Biotype as determinant of natural immunising effect of cholera. The role of biotype in determining the natural immunizing effect of cholera has been investigated in this study. A total of 250 patients with cholera were examined, and their biotypes were determined using standard biochemical tests. The patients were then monitored for the development of immunity against cholera. It was found that patients infected with the El Tor biotype showed a significantly higher rate of natural immunization compared to those infected with the classical biotype (p<0.05). This suggests that the biotype of the infecting cholera strain may play a role in the development of natural immunity. Further studies are needed to investigate the underlying mechanisms and implications of these findings.

Adventitial red blood cells produce intimal platelet accumulation in cerebral arteries of cats following subarachnoid hemorrhage. Subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) is associated with significant morbidity and mortality, with the rupture of an intracranial aneurysm being the most common cause. This study aimed to investigate the role of adventitial red blood cells (RBCs) in promoting intimal platelet accumulation in cerebral arteries following SAH. SAH was induced in cats, and cerebral arteries were analyzed for platelet accumulation using immunohistochemistry and electron microscopy. The results demonstrated a significant increase in platelet accumulation in the intima of cerebral arteries, particularly in areas where adventitial RBCs were observed. Further analysis revealed that adventitial RBCs release reactive oxygen species, leading to the activation of platelets and their subsequent accumulation in the intimal layer. Inhibition of reactive oxygen species production significantly reduced intimal platelet accumulation. These findings suggest that adventitial RBCs contribute to the pathogenesis of cerebral artery vasospasm following SAH by promoting intimal platelet accumulation. Targeting the release of reactive oxygen species from adventitial RBCs may be a potential therapeutic strategy for preventing cerebral vasospasm and improving outcomes in SAH patients.

Treatment of cutaneous T cell lymphoma with a combination of low-dose interferon alfa-2b and retinoids. Cutaneous T cell lymphoma (CTCL) is a rare type of non-Hodgkin lymphoma that primarily affects the skin. Various treatment modalities have been used with varying degrees of success. In this retrospective study, we evaluated the effectiveness of a combination therapy involving low-dose interferon alfa-2b and retinoids in the treatment of CTCL. Twenty-four patients with newly diagnosed or refractory CTCL were included in the study. The treatment regimen consisted of subcutaneous injections of low-dose interferon alfa-2b three times a week, along with oral retinoids daily. The objective response rate was 75%, with 11 complete responses and 6 partial responses observed. The combination therapy showed significant efficacy in controlling disease progression and improving overall survival. Adverse effects were mild and manageable. Overall, the combination of low-dose interferon alfa-2b and retinoids appears to be a promising treatment option for patients with CTCL. Further prospective studies are warranted to confirm these findings and explore the optimal dosage and duration of treatment.

Cervical spine stabilization.  A three-dimensional, biomechanical evaluation of rotational stability, strength, and failure mechanisms. Cervical spine stabilization is crucial in preventing further injury and improving patient outcomes. This study aimed to evaluate the rotational stability, strength, and failure mechanisms of a three-dimensional cervical stabilization technique. Biomechanical testing was conducted using cadaveric cervical spines subjected to rotational loads. Measurements of rotational range of motion and torque were taken to assess stability and strength. Failure mechanisms were analyzed through meticulous examination of the damage patterns in the specimens. Results demonstrated that the three-dimensional stabilization technique provided significant resistance to rotational forces, effectively limiting range of motion and torque. Failure mechanisms primarily involved fracture or dislocation at the stabilized vertebral levels. These findings support the efficacy of three-dimensional cervical stabilization in achieving rotational stability and strength. Further studies should explore clinical outcomes and long-term effectiveness of this technique in real-world scenarios.

Response of the Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome to treatment of associated small-cell lung carcinoma.  We evaluated the outcome in 16 patients with Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome (LEMS) associated with histologically verified small-cell carcinoma (SCC). Patients were treated with various modalities including surgery, chemotherapy, and radiation therapy. Improvement in LEMS symptoms was observed in all patients following treatment of the associated SCC. Of the 16 patients, 8 achieved complete remission of LEMS, while the remaining 8 showed partial remission. Interestingly, the response to treatment was not influenced by the stage of the SCC or the presence of metastases. Furthermore, the duration of LEMS symptoms prior to treatment did not impact the degree of improvement. These findings suggest a strong correlation between LEMS and SCC, and highlight the importance of early diagnosis and prompt initiation of treatment for both conditions. Further studies are warranted to elucidate the underlying mechanisms and explore targeted therapies for LEMS associated with SCC.

Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease--more than a renal disease.  Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD) is the most common genetic disease, affecting a half million Americans. ADPKD is characterized by the development of multiple fluid-filled cysts in both kidneys, leading to progressive kidney enlargement and loss of renal function. However, recent evidence suggests that ADPKD is not solely a renal disease, as it is associated with the development of extrarenal manifestations. These include hepatic cysts, intracranial aneurysms, cardiac valvular defects, and abdominal wall hernias. These extrarenal manifestations can significantly impact patient morbidity and mortality. Furthermore, ADPKD is now recognized as a systemic disorder involving dysregulated signaling pathways and crosstalk between renal epithelial cells and multiple other tissues. This has important implications for clinical management and highlights the need for holistic, multi-organ assessments of patients with ADPKD. Understanding the pathogenesis of extrarenal manifestations in ADPKD may provide valuable insights into disease progression and facilitate the development of targeted therapies capable of impacting these non-renal manifestations.

True hermaphrodite with bilateral ovotestes, bilateral gonadoblastomas and dysgerminomas, 46,XX/46,XY karyotype, and a successful pregnancy. True hermaphroditism is a rare condition characterized by the presence of both ovarian and testicular tissue. We report a case of a 32-year-old individual with true hermaphroditism who presented with bilateral ovotestes, bilateral gonadoblastomas, dysgerminomas, and a 46,XX/46,XY karyotype. Interestingly, despite the presence of multiple tumor formations, the patient was able to achieve a successful pregnancy. This case highlights the complexity and variability of true hermaphroditism and emphasizes the importance of individualized management strategies. Comprehensive evaluation and counseling should be provided to patients with this condition to address their unique reproductive and fertility concerns. Further research is needed to elucidate the underlying genetic and molecular mechanisms that contribute to the development of true hermaphroditism and its associated tumors.

What to do when an x-ray film suggests lung cancer. When an X-ray film suggests lung cancer, it is crucial to follow a systematic approach for diagnosis and management. Firstly, a thorough history and physical examination should be conducted to assess the patient's risk factors and symptoms. This should be followed by obtaining additional imaging studies such as CT scan or MRI to further evaluate the lung lesion. Suspicious nodules or masses may require further investigation through biopsy, either by bronchoscopy or percutaneous needle aspiration. Additionally, it is important to stage the cancer to determine the extent of disease and plan appropriate treatment. This involves additional imaging studies, such as PET scan, and potentially invasive procedures like mediastinoscopy or endobronchial ultrasound. A multidisciplinary approach involving radiologists, pulmonologists, oncologists, and thoracic surgeons is essential for optimal management and outcome in patients with suspected lung cancer.

Epstein-Barr virus small nuclear RNAs are not expressed in permissively infected cells in AIDS-associated leukoplakia. Leukoplakia is a potentially malignant disorder of the oral mucosa commonly associated with human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection. The Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) has been implicated in the pathogenesis of AIDS-associated leukoplakia due to its ability to persistently infect B lymphocytes. However, the role of EBV small nuclear RNAs (EBERs) in the development of leukoplakia remains unclear. In this study, we investigated the expression of EBERs in permissively infected cells in AIDS-associated leukoplakia. Using in situ hybridization, we found that EBERs were not expressed in the lesional epithelium of AIDS-associated leukoplakia, despite the presence of EBV DNA. These findings suggest that while EBV may play a role in the development of AIDS-associated leukoplakia, the expression of EBERs is not essential for the maintenance of EBV infection in the lesional epithelium. Further research is needed to elucidate the specific mechanisms by which EBV contributes to the pathogenesis of leukoplakia in HIV-infected individuals.

Attributes and survival patterns of multiple primary cutaneous malignant melanoma.  From a series of 1495 patients with primary cutaneous malignant melanoma (PCMM), 26 patients (1. 3%) were found to have multiple primary cutaneous malignant melanomas (MPMM) over a 20-year period. The median age at diagnosis of the first MPMM was 54 years, and the median follow-up was 75 months. The majority of patients (65.4%) were female and had fair skin type (73.1%). The most common subtype of MPMM was superficial spreading melanoma (42.3%), followed by lentigo maligna melanoma (30.8%). The most common site of the first primary MPMM was the trunk (34.6%). The overall survival rate at 5 years was 82.9%. The presence of ulceration and higher Breslow thickness were significantly associated with worse survival outcomes. These findings highlight the importance of close surveillance and early detection of MPMM in patients with a history of PCMM.

Synchronous positive and negative myoclonus due to pontine hemorrhage. We present a case of a 62-year-old male who developed synchronous positive and negative myoclonus following a pontine hemorrhage. The patient initially presented with sudden onset of altered mental status and right-sided weakness. Brain imaging revealed a pontine hemorrhage. Within hours, the patient developed synchronous positive myoclonus involving the face, neck, and upper extremities, alternating with negative myoclonus characterized by brief lapses in muscle tone. Electroencephalography (EEG) showed normal background activity with occasional generalized spike-wave discharges. Treatment with levetiracetam and clonazepam resulted in partial improvement of myoclonus. To our knowledge, this is the first reported case of synchronous positive and negative myoclonus following a pontine hemorrhage. Further studies are needed to better understand the pathophysiology and treatment options for this rare condition.

Elevation of skeletal muscle isoform of serum creatine kinase in heterozygous familial hypercholesterolaemia. Heterozygous familial hypercholesterolaemia (FH) is a genetic disorder characterized by elevated cholesterol levels and an increased risk of cardiovascular disease. We report a case of an asymptomatic patient with heterozygous FH who presented with markedly elevated levels of serum creatine kinase (CK). Further investigations revealed no evidence of skeletal muscle damage or inflammation. This finding prompted us to investigate the presence of muscle isoforms of CK in serum, which were indeed elevated. The elevation of skeletal muscle isoform of CK in the context of FH has not been previously reported. This case highlights the importance of considering FH as a potential cause of elevated CK levels, even in the absence of clinical symptoms of muscle disease. Further research is needed to elucidate the underlying mechanisms linking FH and CK elevation.

Immunohistochemical demonstration of keratin in ameloblastoma as an indication of tumor differentiation. Ameloblastoma is a rare odontogenic tumor with variable biological behavior. Differentiating between its different subtypes and predicting its clinical behavior is challenging. This study aimed to investigate the correlation between immunohistochemical staining for keratin and tumor differentiation in ameloblastoma. Seventy-nine cases of ameloblastoma were analyzed retrospectively for immunohistochemical staining of keratin using the streptavidin-biotin-peroxidase complex method. The staining intensity was evaluated and compared to clinicopathological parameters. The results showed that keratin staining was positive in all cases of ameloblastoma, with varying staining intensities. There was a significant correlation between keratin staining intensity and tumor differentiation (p<0.05), suggesting that keratin staining could serve as an indication of tumor differentiation in ameloblastoma. Further studies are needed to validate these findings and explore the potential of keratin staining as a prognostic indicator in ameloblastoma.

Supported employment: an alternative model for vocational rehabilitation of persons with severe neurologic, psychiatric, or physical disability. Supported employment is a widely accepted model for vocational rehabilitation of individuals with severe neurologic, psychiatric, or physical disabilities. This model involves assisting individuals in finding and maintaining competitive employment in integrated work settings. The goal is to enhance the individual's quality of life by promoting independence, self-esteem, and community integration. This article presents an overview of the supported employment model, highlighting its key principles and components. It also discusses the evidence supporting the effectiveness of supported employment in improving employment outcomes and overall well-being for individuals with disabilities. Furthermore, the article explores the challenges and barriers to implementing supported employment programs and provides recommendations for successful implementation and sustainability. Overall, supported employment offers a promising approach to vocational rehabilitation, providing individuals with disabilities the opportunity to achieve meaningful and fulfilling employment.

Triiodothyronine and brain excitability.  We investigated mechanisms involved in thyroid hormone action on brain excitability. Triiodothyronine (T3) is a potent regulator of brain function and has been implicated in modulating brain excitability. However, the specific mechanisms underlying its effects on neuronal activity are still not fully understood. In this study, we aimed to investigate the molecular and cellular mechanisms involved in thyroid hormone action on brain excitability.

Using a combination of in vitro and in vivo experiments, we found that T3 administration increased neuronal excitability in the hippocampus and cortex. This effect was mediated through the upregulation of key neurotransmitter receptors, including glutamate receptors, and the activation of intracellular signaling pathways involved in synaptic plasticity.

Furthermore, we demonstrated that T3-induced changes in brain excitability were dependent on the activation of thyroid hormone receptors and were reversible upon the removal of T3.

These findings provide novel insights into the mechanisms by which thyroid hormone regulates brain excitability and suggest potential therapeutic targets for disorders characterized by altered neuronal excitability, such as epilepsy and mood disorders. Further studies are warranted to elucidate the specific molecular pathways involved and to explore the clinical implications of these findings.

Mucocele of the cystic duct remnant in eight liver transplant recipients: findings at cholangiography, CT, and US.  The case histories and radiologic studies of eight liver transplant recipients who developed a mucocele of the allograft cystic duct remnant were retrospectively evaluated. Mucocele of the cystic duct remnant is a rare complication in liver transplant recipients. In this retrospective study, we evaluated the case histories and radiologic findings of eight liver transplant recipients who developed a mucocele of the allograft cystic duct remnant. Cholangiography, computed tomography (CT), and ultrasound (US) were performed to assess the presence and characteristics of the mucocele. All patients presented with nonspecific abdominal pain, along with elevated liver enzymes and bilirubin levels. Cholangiography revealed dilatation of the cystic duct remnant, while CT and US showed a cystic lesion in the region of the cystic duct. Prompt surgical intervention was performed in all cases, resulting in resolution of symptoms and normalization of liver function tests. Recognition of this rare complication is crucial for early diagnosis and management in liver transplant recipients.

Ascites revealing peritoneal and hepatic extramedullary hematopoiesis with peliosis in agnogenic myeloid metaplasia: case report and review of the literature. Agnogenic myeloid metaplasia (AMM), also known as primary myelofibrosis, is a rare myeloproliferative neoplasm characterized by bone marrow fibrosis and extramedullary hematopoiesis. Peliosis is a rare vascular disorder characterized by blood-filled cystic spaces within parenchymal organs. We present a case of a 59-year-old male who presented with abdominal distension and was found to have ascites. Imaging studies revealed hepatomegaly and diffuse nodular lesions in the liver. Histopathological examination of the liver and peritoneal biopsy showed extensive extramedullary hematopoiesis with associated peliosis. A diagnosis of AMM with peritoneal and hepatic extramedullary hematopoiesis and peliosis was made. This case highlights the rare association between AMM and peliosis, which has only been reported in a few cases in the literature. It emphasizes the importance of considering AMM in the differential diagnosis of patients presenting with ascites and hepatic nodules. Further studies are required to better understand the pathogenesis and clinical significance of this association.

Closed heart cryoablation of the His bundle using an anterior septal approach.  His bundle cryosurgical ablation using a closed heart anterior septal approach was used in 6 patients. Closed heart cryoablation of the His bundle using an anterior septal approach was performed in six patients. Successful ablation of the His bundle was achieved in all cases, resulting in complete heart block. Post-procedural follow-up revealed no recurrence of atrioventricular conduction, and all patients remained asymptomatic with stable cardiac rhythm. There were no major complications or adverse events associated with the procedure. This anterior septal approach provides a feasible and effective alternative to traditional open-heart surgery for His bundle cryosurgical ablation. Further studies are warranted to evaluate long-term outcomes and compare the efficacy of this technique with other approaches.

Dysgeusia, gustatory sweating, and crocodile tears syndrome induced by a cerebellopontine angle meningioma. Cerebellopontine angle meningiomas are typically benign tumors that arise from the arachnoid cap cells of the meninges. These tumors often present with symptoms related to compression of adjacent cranial nerves. In this case report, the authors describe a 54-year-old female patient who presented with dysgeusia, gustatory sweating, and crocodile tears syndrome, all of which were attributed to a cerebellopontine angle meningioma. Dysgeusia, characterized by a distorted sense of taste, is a rare but recognized symptom of intracranial tumors. Gustatory sweating, or Frey's syndrome, occurs due to aberrant reinnervation of the parasympathetic fibers supplying the sweat glands after damage to the auriculotemporal nerve. Crocodile tears syndrome, characterized by involuntary lacrimation during eating, is also attributed to this aberrant reinnervation. Magnetic resonance imaging revealed a well-defined, contrast-enhancing lesion at the cerebellopontine angle. The patient underwent surgical resection of the tumor, with resolution of the aforementioned symptoms postoperatively. This case highlights the importance of recognizing unusual neurologic manifestations of cerebellopontine angle meningiomas, as they can guide the diagnosis and appropriate management of these tumors.

Esophageal involvement in pemphigus vulgaris: a clinical, histologic, and immunopathologic study. Pemphigus vulgaris (PV) is an autoimmune blistering disorder primarily affecting the skin and mucous membranes. Esophageal involvement in PV is rare, but can significantly affect the patient's quality of life. This study aimed to evaluate the clinical, histologic, and immunopathologic features of esophageal involvement in PV. A retrospective analysis of patients with histologically confirmed PV and esophageal symptoms was conducted. Clinical and endoscopic findings were recorded, and esophageal biopsies were examined histologically and immunopathologically. The study identified 15 patients with esophageal involvement in PV. The most common esophageal symptoms were dysphagia and odynophagia. Esophageal biopsies showed characteristic histologic changes, including intraepithelial acantholysis, suprabasal cleft formation, and eosinophilic infiltration. Immunopathologic studies revealed deposition of immunoglobulin G and complement components along the intercellular spaces. In conclusion, esophageal involvement in PV is characterized by distinct clinical, histologic, and immunopathologic features, which should be considered in the diagnostic workup and management of PV patients.

Amyloidosis associated bleeding diatheses in the surgical patient. Amyloidosis is a rare disorder characterized by the deposition of abnormal protein, called amyloid, in various organs and tissues. One of the complications seen in surgical patients with amyloidosis is bleeding diatheses, which refers to a heightened tendency to bleed. This can present as surgical site bleeding, perioperative hemorrhage, or excessive bleeding from minor trauma. The mechanisms underlying the bleeding diatheses in amyloidosis are complex and involve multiple factors such as platelet dysfunction, vascular fragility, and coagulation abnormalities. In this review, we summarize the current understanding of amyloidosis-associated bleeding diatheses in the surgical patient population. We discuss the clinical presentation, diagnostic evaluation, and management strategies for these patients. Additionally, we highlight the importance of a multidisciplinary approach involving hematologists, surgeons, and anesthesiologists in the perioperative care of patients with amyloidosis to optimize patient outcomes and minimize perioperative bleeding complications.

Portal vein resection with a new antithrombogenic catheter. Portal vein resection is a complex surgical procedure often required in the treatment of hepatobiliary and pancreatic malignancies. However, it is associated with a high risk of thrombotic complications. In this study, we present our experience with a new antithrombogenic catheter used during portal vein resection. A total of 30 patients undergoing portal vein resection between 2015 and 2020 were included. The new antithrombogenic catheter was used in all patients. The primary outcomes assessed were the incidence of thrombotic complications and the perioperative mortality rate. Secondary outcomes included blood loss, length of hospital stay, and overall survival. Our results showed a low incidence of thrombotic complications (10%) and a perioperative mortality rate of 3.3%. The use of the new antithrombogenic catheter was associated with reduced blood loss, shorter hospital stay, and improved overall survival. In conclusion, the use of the new antithrombogenic catheter during portal vein resection appears to be a safe and effective technique in preventing thrombotic complications and improving patient outcomes.

Refractory hypoglycemia secondary to topical salicylate intoxication.  We describe a case of severe refractory hypoglycemia secondary to topical salicylate intoxication. The patient, a 45-year-old male, presented with altered mental status and profound hypoglycemia. Initial laboratory investigations revealed undetectable blood glucose levels and metabolic acidosis. Despite aggressive intravenous glucose administration, the patient remained hypoglycemic with persistent neurologic symptoms. Further history revealed the use of a topical salicylate-containing ointment for chronic joint pain. Salicylate levels were found to be significantly elevated in both serum and urine. After discontinuation of the salicylate ointment and initiation of hemodialysis, the patient's hypoglycemia gradually resolved. This case highlights the importance of considering topical salicylate intoxication as a potential cause of refractory hypoglycemia and emphasizes the need for prompt identification and appropriate management to prevent serious complications.

Gastrointestinal disease and oral contraception. There is limited research exploring the association between gastrointestinal (GI) diseases and oral contraception. This study aimed to investigate the relationship between these two factors in a population-based sample. Data was collected from medical records of 500 women attending a GI clinic over a 3-year period. The prevalence of oral contraceptive use was determined, along with the occurrence of GI diseases. The results showed that 25% of the women had a history of oral contraceptive use, with the majority using combined hormonal contraceptives. The prevalence of GI diseases was significantly higher in women who had used oral contraception compared to those who had not (p<0.05). Specifically, there was an increased risk of developing inflammatory bowel disease and gastroesophageal reflux disease in women who had used oral contraceptives. However, no significant association was found between oral contraception and irritable bowel syndrome or peptic ulcer disease. These findings suggest a potential link between oral contraception and certain GI diseases, but further research is needed to confirm and elucidate this association.

Desensitization in the management of vancomycin hypersensitivity.  Vancomycin is the preferred antimicrobial agent in the treatment of methicillin-resistant staphylococcal infections. Vancomycin hypersensitivity is a concern in patients with methicillin-resistant staphylococcal infections who require treatment with this antibiotic. To investigate the effectiveness of desensitization in managing vancomycin hypersensitivity, we conducted a retrospective analysis of 45 patients who underwent the desensitization protocol. The protocol involved gradually increasing the dose of vancomycin over several hours with careful monitoring for adverse reactions. Data on patient demographics, underlying medical conditions, vancomycin hypersensitivity symptoms, and outcomes were collected and analyzed. Our results demonstrated a successful desensitization process in 42 out of 45 patients (93.3%), with no severe allergic reactions reported during the procedure. Three patients experienced mild adverse reactions that were promptly treated and did not require discontinuation of vancomycin. These findings suggest that desensitization is a viable option for managing vancomycin hypersensitivity, enabling the continued use of this important antimicrobial agent in patients with methicillin-resistant staphylococcal infections. Further prospective studies are warranted to confirm these results and optimize the desensitization protocol.

Admissions to the intensive care unit after complications of anaesthetic techniques over 10 years.  2. Complications of anaesthetic techniques can lead to serious adverse events and require admission to the intensive care unit (ICU) for management. In this retrospective study, we aimed to investigate the incidence and nature of admissions to the ICU following complications of anaesthetic techniques over a 10-year period. Medical records of patients who were admitted to the ICU due to anaesthetic complications between January 2010 and December 2019 were reviewed. A total of 256 admissions were analyzed, with an average annual admission rate of 25.6 cases. The most common complications leading to ICU admission were respiratory distress (43.8%), cardiovascular instability (28.1%), and neurological complications (16.4%). Our findings highlight the importance of continuous monitoring and prompt recognition of complications during anaesthetic procedures to minimize the risk of ICU admissions and improve patient outcomes.

The epithelial changes associated with squamous cell carcinoma of the vulva: a review of the clinical, histological and viral findings in 78 women. Squamous cell carcinoma of the vulva is a rare but aggressive malignancy. This study aims to summarize the clinical, histological, and viral findings associated with epithelial changes in 78 women diagnosed with this type of vulvar cancer. Results show that the majority of patients presented with vulvar pruritus and/or pain, and the most common histological subtype was keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma. Human papillomavirus (HPV) infection was detected in a significant proportion of cases. Other associated findings include the presence of atypical squamous cells and high-grade dysplasia. These findings emphasize the importance of early detection and proper management of epithelial changes to improve outcomes for women with vulvar carcinoma.

Total parathyroidectomy and autotransplantation in hyperplasia of the parathyroid gland. Parathyroidectomy is a commonly performed procedure for the treatment of hyperplasia of the parathyroid gland. This study aimed to investigate the outcomes of total parathyroidectomy with autotransplantation in patients with parathyroid gland hyperplasia. A total of 47 patients underwent the procedure at a single center over a five-year period. The majority of patients experienced resolution of symptoms related to hypercalcemia postoperatively. Serum calcium levels were within normal range in most patients following surgery. Complications were reported in a minority of cases and were successfully managed. There were no instances of recurrent hyperplasia during the follow-up period. Overall, total parathyroidectomy with autotransplantation appears to be a safe and effective treatment option for patients with hyperplasia of the parathyroid gland. Further studies with longer follow-up periods are warranted to confirm these findings.

Absence of acetylcholine-induced current in epithelial cells from thymus glands and thymomas of myasthenia gravis patients. Myasthenia gravis (MG) is an autoimmune disorder characterized by muscle weakness and fatigue. Previous studies have shown a deficiency in acetylcholine receptors in the neuromuscular junctions of MG patients. However, the involvement of thymus gland epithelial cells and thymomas in MG pathogenesis remains poorly understood. 

In this study, we investigated the presence of acetylcholine-induced current in epithelial cells derived from thymus glands and thymomas of MG patients. Epithelial cells were isolated and cultured, and whole-cell patch-clamp recordings were performed to measure the acetylcholine-induced current. 

Surprisingly, we found an absence of acetylcholine-induced current in all thymus gland epithelial cells and thymomas obtained from MG patients. In contrast, epithelial cells derived from control individuals exhibited robust acetylcholine-induced currents. 

These findings suggest that the deficiency in acetylcholine receptors in MG may extend beyond the neuromuscular junctions and involve thymus gland epithelial cells. Dysfunction of these cells could potentially contribute to the autoimmune response and pathogenesis of MG. Further investigations are warranted to elucidate the underlying mechanisms and implications of this finding in MG.

The technicon H6000 analyzer discriminates chronic lymphocytic leukemia from other B-cell leukemias through automatic assessment of large unstained cells. In this study, the performance of the Technicon H6000 analyzer in discriminating chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) from other B-cell leukemias was evaluated. The analyzer utilizes automatic assessment of large unstained cells (LUC) as a tool for differentiation. A total of 100 samples, including 50 CLL cases and 50 cases of other B-cell leukemias, were analyzed using the H6000 analyzer. The results demonstrated a sensitivity of 92% and a specificity of 90% for distinguishing CLL from other B-cell leukemias. This automated method offers a rapid and reliable approach for the identification of CLL, potentially aiding in the diagnosis and management of patients with this form of leukemia. Further validation studies are warranted to confirm the clinical utility of this technology.

Attachment of bacteria to tonsillar epithelium during acute tonsillitis. Acute tonsillitis is a commonly encountered condition characterized by inflammation of the tonsils. Bacterial infection is often implicated as the underlying cause, but the mechanisms by which bacteria attach to tonsillar epithelium remain poorly understood. This study aimed to investigate the attachment of bacteria to tonsillar epithelium during acute tonsillitis. Tonsil specimens were collected from patients presenting with acute tonsillitis, and immunofluorescence staining was performed to visualize bacterial attachment. Results showed that several types of bacteria, including Streptococcus pyogenes and Haemophilus influenzae, were found to be attached to the tonsillar epithelium. Furthermore, the degree of bacterial attachment correlated with the severity of clinical symptoms. These findings provide valuable insights into the pathogenesis of acute tonsillitis and may inform the development of targeted therapeutic strategies to prevent bacterial attachment and subsequent inflammation.

Recovery from disturbed colonic transit time after alcohol withdrawal.  The effects of alcohol withdrawal on total and segmental transit time were evaluated in 20 chronic alcoholic subjects.  After withdrawal, colorectal transit time significantly increased from 24. The effects of alcohol withdrawal on colonic transit time were studied in 20 chronic alcoholic subjects. Following alcohol withdrawal, there was a significant increase in both total and segmental transit time of the colon. Before withdrawal, the mean total transit time was 24.2 hours and increased to 37.5 hours after withdrawal, indicating a delay in colonic transit. The segmental transit time also showed a significant prolongation in all segments of the colon. These findings suggest that chronic alcohol use affects colonic motility, and withdrawal from alcohol can lead to disturbed colonic transit time. Further studies are needed to elucidate the underlying mechanisms and implications of these changes in colonic motility after alcohol withdrawal.

Role of tolerance in cloxacillin treatment of experimental Staphylococcus aureus endocarditis. The role of tolerance in the treatment of experimental Staphylococcus aureus endocarditis with cloxacillin was investigated. Rabbits with aortic valve endocarditis were randomly assigned to receive either cloxacillin or saline as a control. The animals were treated with daily intramuscular injections of cloxacillin for a period of two weeks. Blood cultures were obtained on days 0, 7, and 14 to monitor bacterial growth. The results revealed that despite initial bactericidal activity, cloxacillin treatment resulted in the emergence of tolerant strains of S. aureus in all animals. These tolerant strains showed reduced susceptibility to cloxacillin and exhibited lower rates of bacterial clearance from the bloodstream compared to the control group. This study highlights the significance of tolerance in the development of treatment failure and the need for alternative therapeutic strategies to combat endocarditis caused by drug-tolerant S. aureus strains.

Management of local and regional recurrence after mastectomy or breast-conserving treatment. Local and regional recurrence after mastectomy or breast-conserving treatment is a significant concern for breast cancer patients. This study aimed to examine the management strategies and outcomes of recurrent disease in a cohort of women who underwent either mastectomy or breast-conserving treatment. A retrospective analysis was conducted on 230 patients who experienced recurrence between 2005 and 2015. The majority of recurrences occurred within the first five years after initial treatment. Local recurrence was more common in the breast-conserving treatment group, while regional recurrence was more common in the mastectomy group. Treatment options for local recurrence included repeat surgery, radiation therapy, and systemic therapy, while regional recurrence was primarily managed with systemic therapy and lymph node dissection. Improved survival rates were observed in patients who underwent aggressive multimodal treatment. Overall, this study highlights the importance of individualized management strategies to optimize outcomes for breast cancer patients experiencing local and regional recurrence.

Doppler color-flow images from a stenosed arterial model: interpretation of flow patterns. Doppler color-flow imaging is widely used in the assessment of vascular diseases, including arterial stenosis. This study aimed to evaluate the interpretation of flow patterns obtained from Doppler color-flow images of a stenosed arterial model. A pulsatile flow circuit with a stenotic segment was created, and Doppler color-flow images were obtained using a high-resolution ultrasound system. The flow patterns were analyzed based on the velocity, direction, and turbulence of the blood flow. Three distinct flow patterns were observed: laminar flow, disturbed flow, and turbulent flow. Laminar flow was characterized by uniform velocity and direction, while disturbed flow showed irregular velocity and direction. Turbulent flow exhibited high-velocity jets and flow recirculation. These findings were consistent with previous studies in clinical settings. Overall, Doppler color-flow imaging successfully identified flow patterns in the stenotic arterial model, which may aid in the diagnosis and management of arterial stenosis in clinical practice.

Primary solid neoplasms of the greater omentum.  Primary solid tumors of the greater omentum are rare, with only 42 reported cases. Primary solid neoplasms of the greater omentum are exceedingly rare, with only 42 reported cases in the literature. The majority of these tumors are malignant, and the most common histological subtype is gastrointestinal stromal tumor (GIST). Other reported histologies include leiomyosarcoma, liposarcoma, and adenocarcinoma. Clinical presentation is often non-specific, with the most common symptoms being abdominal pain, bloating, and weight loss. Imaging modalities such as computed tomography (CT) and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) aid in the diagnosis and staging of these tumors. Surgical resection is the mainstay of treatment, with adjuvant therapy being considered for certain subtypes. Prognosis is variable and dependent on tumor type, stage, and completeness of resection. Long-term survival rates range from 24% to 69%, with a reported median survival of 39 months. Further research is needed to better understand the etiology, optimal management strategies, and prognostic factors for primary solid neoplasms of the greater omentum.

Prediction of cognitive change as a function of preoperative ability status among temporal lobectomy patients seen at 6-month follow-up. This study aimed to investigate the relationship between preoperative ability status and cognitive change among temporal lobectomy patients at a 6-month follow-up. A total of 45 patients who underwent temporal lobectomy for intractable epilepsy participated in the study. Preoperative ability status was assessed using standardized cognitive tests, including measures of verbal memory, visual memory, attention, and executive function. Cognitive change was assessed by comparing postoperative performance on the same tests with preoperative baseline scores. Results showed that patients with lower preoperative ability status had significantly greater cognitive decline compared to those with higher preoperative ability status across all cognitive domains. Specifically, patients with lower preoperative ability status demonstrated significant declines in verbal memory, visual memory, attention, and executive function. These findings suggest that preoperative ability status may serve as a predictor of cognitive change following temporal lobectomy and highlight the importance of considering preoperative cognitive functioning when planning surgical interventions for epilepsy patients. Further research is needed to explore potential interventions to mitigate cognitive decline in this patient population.

Long-time survival of a patient with glioblastoma and Turcot's syndrome. Glioblastoma, a rare and aggressive brain tumor, is associated with poor prognosis and limited treatment options. Turcot's syndrome, a genetic disorder characterized by the development of multiple colorectal adenomas and central nervous system tumors, further complicates therapeutic strategies. We present a case of a 42-year-old male with both glioblastoma and Turcot's syndrome who has achieved long-time survival (>5 years) following a multi-modal treatment approach. The patient underwent surgical resection of the brain tumor, followed by radiation therapy and concurrent chemotherapy with temozolomide. Additionally, genetic counseling led to the identification of a germline mutation in the MMR gene, prompting regular surveillance for colorectal adenomas. This case highlights the importance of a comprehensive treatment plan and genetic testing in achieving favorable outcomes for patients with glioblastoma and Turcot's syndrome. Further studies are warranted to evaluate the potential implications of genomic profiling on treatment decisions in this rare population.

Changes in surgical treatments: the example of hysterectomy versus conization for cervical carcinoma in situ.  From 1969 through 1985, 4584 women in the state of New Mexico were diagnosed with carcinoma in situ of the cervix. This study compared the outcomes of hysterectomy versus conization as surgical treatments for cervical carcinoma in situ. The medical records of 4584 women diagnosed with carcinoma in situ of the cervix between 1969 and 1985 in New Mexico were reviewed. Of these, 3474 underwent hysterectomy and 1110 underwent conization. The rates of recurrence and survival were analyzed for both groups. The results showed that the recurrence rate was significantly lower in the hysterectomy group compared to the conization group. However, there was no significant difference in overall survival between the two groups. These findings suggest that hysterectomy may be a more effective treatment option for women with carcinoma in situ of the cervix, as it reduces the risk of disease recurrence compared to conization.

Gastroduodenal mucosa in uraemia: endoscopic and histological correlation and prevalence of helicobacter-like organisms.  This study aimed to determine the prevalence of endoscopic and histological gastroduodenitis as well as helicobacter-like organisms in patients with end stage renal failure undergoing maintenance dialysis treatment. A total of 100 patients with end-stage renal failure on maintenance dialysis treatment were included in this study. All patients underwent upper gastrointestinal endoscopy, and biopsies were obtained from the gastric and duodenal mucosa. The endoscopic findings were classified according to the Sydney system, and histological analysis was performed to determine the presence of gastroduodenitis. Additionally, the presence of helicobacter-like organisms was assessed using special stains. The overall prevalence of gastroduodenitis was found to be 64%, with gastritis being the most common finding. Helicobacter-like organisms were identified in 36% of the patients. There was a significant correlation between the presence of helicobacter-like organisms and the severity of gastritis. These results demonstrate a high prevalence of gastroduodenal mucosal abnormalities in patients with end-stage renal failure and highlight the importance of considering helicobacter-like organisms in the management of these patients.

Arterial oxygen desaturation during gastrointestinal endoscopy This prospective study evaluated the incidence and severity of arterial oxygen desaturation during gastrointestinal endoscopy. Arterial oxygen desaturation is a potential complication of gastrointestinal endoscopy. This prospective study aimed to determine the incidence and severity of arterial oxygen desaturation during this procedure. A total of 150 patients undergoing gastrointestinal endoscopy were included in the study. Arterial oxygen saturation (SpO2) levels were continuously monitored using pulse oximetry before, during, and after the procedure. The results showed that arterial oxygen desaturation occurred in 35% of patients during gastrointestinal endoscopy. The severity of desaturation varied, with mild desaturation (SpO2  90%) observed in 20% of patients, moderate desaturation (SpO2 80-89%) in 12%, and severe desaturation (SpO2 < 80%) in 3%. Factors associated with a higher risk of desaturation included older age, higher body mass index, and longer duration of the procedure. These findings highlight the importance of continuous monitoring and appropriate interventions to prevent and manage arterial oxygen desaturation during gastrointestinal endoscopy.

The development of infratentorial atrophy in patients with idiopathic cerebellar ataxia of late onset: a CT study. The purpose of this study was to investigate the development of infratentorial atrophy in patients with idiopathic cerebellar ataxia of late onset using computed tomography (CT). Fifty patients diagnosed with idiopathic cerebellar ataxia of late onset were included in the study. CT scans were obtained at baseline and at a follow-up examination after an average of 5 years. The degree of infratentorial atrophy was assessed by measuring the brainstem-to-infratentorial supratentorial area ratio. The results showed a significant increase in the degree of infratentorial atrophy over the follow-up period. Age at onset and disease duration were found to be significant predictors of the degree of infratentorial atrophy. These findings suggest that infratentorial atrophy is a progressive process in patients with idiopathic cerebellar ataxia of late onset and that it may be associated with disease severity and progression.

Imaging the gallbladder: a historical perspective.  After Wilhelm Conrad Roentgen's discovery of the X-ray in 1895, it was initially thought that gallstones could not be visualized. However, advancements in imaging technology have allowed for the visualization of the gallbladder and the detection of gallstones. Initially, cholecystography, involving the ingestion of a contrast agent followed by X-ray imaging, was the main diagnostic tool for gallbladder imaging. However, this method had limitations, including the difficulty in visualizing small stones and the potential for adverse reactions to the contrast agent. Subsequent developments, such as the introduction of ultrasound in the 1950s and computed tomography (CT) in the 1970s, revolutionized gallbladder imaging. These non-invasive techniques provided clearer and more detailed images, enabling more accurate diagnosis of gallstones and other gallbladder pathologies. Today, various imaging modalities, including magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP), and cholescintigraphy, offer a range of options for gallbladder evaluation, improving patient care and treatment decisions.

Nosocomial infections due to Xanthomonas maltophilia (Pseudomonas maltophilia) in patients with cancer.  From December 1985 to May 1986, Xanthomonas maltophilia (formerly known as Pseudomonas maltophilia) was isolated at an increased rate at our institution; 52 isolates of X. We conducted a retrospective study to assess the prevalence and clinical characteristics of nosocomial infections caused by Xanthomonas maltophilia (formerly known as Pseudomonas maltophilia) in cancer patients. A total of 52 isolates of X. maltophilia were obtained from December 1985 to May 1986 at our institution. The majority of infections occurred in patients with hematological malignancies (64.6%) and solid tumors (35.4%). The most common site of infection was the respiratory tract (46.2%), followed by bloodstream (25.0%), urinary tract (9.6%), surgical site (9.6%), and others (9.6%). The strains showed high levels of resistance to commonly used antibiotics, highlighting the importance of choosing appropriate antimicrobial therapy for these infections. Furthermore, these infections were associated with a prolonged hospital stay and increased mortality. Strict infection control measures, including hand hygiene, environmental cleaning, and antimicrobial stewardship, are crucial in preventing and managing X. maltophilia infections in cancer patients.

Hypertension during pregnancy in insulin-dependent diabetic women. The aim of this study was to investigate the prevalence and risk factors of hypertension during pregnancy in women with insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus (IDDM). A total of 342 pregnant women with IDDM were enrolled in the study and followed up throughout their pregnancies. The prevalence of hypertension during pregnancy in this population was found to be significantly higher than in the general pregnant population. Risk factors associated with the development of hypertension included pre-pregnancy hypertension, higher systolic and diastolic blood pressure, higher body mass index, longer diabetes duration, and poor glycemic control. Furthermore, hypertensive women with IDDM had higher rates of adverse pregnancy outcomes, including preeclampsia, preterm delivery, and cesarean section. These findings highlight the importance of closely monitoring blood pressure and glycemic control in pregnant women with IDDM, and implementing appropriate interventions to prevent and manage hypertension during pregnancy in this high-risk population.

Optimal escort for interhospital transport of pediatric emergencies. Transporting pediatric patients between hospitals for specialized care can be challenging and requires an optimal escort system to ensure their safety and well-being. This study aimed to evaluate the efficacy and feasibility of an escort system for interhospital transport of pediatric emergencies. A retrospective analysis was conducted on pediatric patients who were transported using the escort system over a five-year period. The results showed that the escort system effectively facilitated the safe transfer of pediatric patients, with a low rate of adverse events and complications during transport. The system included appropriately trained medical personnel, specialized equipment, and a well-established communication network. It allowed for prompt medical interventions and continuous monitoring of vital signs throughout the transport process. The findings of this study highlight the importance of a comprehensive and organized escort system in ensuring the optimal care and outcomes for pediatric patients during interhospital transport of emergencies. Further studies are warranted to evaluate the long-term impact and cost-effectiveness of this escort system.

Relative effects of brain and non-brain injuries on neuropsychological and psychosocial outcome. The present study aimed to investigate the relative effects of brain and non-brain injuries on neuropsychological and psychosocial outcomes. A total of 100 participants with a history of traumatic brain injury (TBI) were recruited and divided into two groups: those with brain injuries limited to the central nervous system (CNS) and those with additional non-brain injuries. Neuropsychological tests were administered to assess cognitive functioning, while psychosocial outcomes were measured using standardized questionnaires assessing quality of life, mood, and social functioning. Results revealed that participants with both brain and non-brain injuries exhibited significantly poorer cognitive performance compared to those with brain injuries alone. Additionally, individuals with combined injuries reported lower levels of quality of life, increased depressive symptoms, and greater social impairment. These findings highlight the detrimental impact of non-brain injuries on both cognitive and psychosocial outcomes in TBI patients, emphasizing the importance of comprehensive evaluation and management strategies for individuals with multiple injuries.

Intraoperative ultrasonography and the detection of liver metastases in patients with colorectal cancer. Liver metastases are a common occurrence in patients with colorectal cancer, and their detection is important for accurate staging and treatment planning. Intraoperative ultrasonography (IOUS) has been proposed as a reliable tool for detecting liver metastases during surgery. This study aims to evaluate the diagnostic accuracy of IOUS in detecting liver metastases in patients with colorectal cancer. A systematic review of the literature was conducted, and relevant studies were included. The results showed that IOUS had a high sensitivity and specificity for detecting liver metastases, with a pooled sensitivity of 85% and a pooled specificity of 92%. IOUS can be considered an effective intraoperative imaging modality for the detection of liver metastases in patients with colorectal cancer, potentially improving surgical outcomes and patient management.

Subscapular elastofibroma in a young pitcher.  A case report. We present a case report of a 23-year-old professional pitcher who presented with a subscapular elastofibroma, a rare benign soft tissue tumor. The patient reported pain and discomfort in the subscapular region during overhead activities, which progressively worsened over the course of several months. Physical examination revealed a palpable, non-tender mass in the left subscapular region. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) confirmed the diagnosis of elastofibroma, showing a well-defined, lobulated mass with intermediate signal intensity on T1-weighted images and high signal intensity on T2-weighted images. The patient underwent surgical excision of the tumor, and histological examination confirmed the diagnosis. Post-operative rehabilitation included physical therapy to regain range of motion and strengthen the shoulder muscles. At 6-month follow-up, the patient was pain-free and had resumed full, unrestricted pitching activities. This case highlights the importance of considering elastofibroma as a differential diagnosis in young athletes presenting with subscapular pain and limited shoulder mobility.

Photodynamic therapy with chloroaluminum-sulfonated phthalocyanine. Photodynamic therapy (PDT) is a promising approach for the treatment of various diseases, including cancer. Chloroaluminum-sulfonated phthalocyanine (AlSPc) is a photosensitizer used in PDT to generate cytotoxic reactive oxygen species upon light activation. This study aimed to investigate the efficacy of AlSPc-mediated PDT in cancer cell lines and animal models. In vitro experiments revealed that AlSPc-PDT induced significant cell death in a dose- and light-dependent manner. Furthermore, in vivo studies using xenograft mouse models demonstrated that AlSPc-PDT effectively inhibited tumor growth and prolonged overall survival. Mechanistic studies revealed that AlSPc-PDT induced apoptosis and disrupted tumor vasculature. Importantly, AlSPc-PDT showed minimal toxicity to normal tissues. These findings highlight the therapeutic potential of AlSPc-mediated PDT for cancer treatment and warrant further investigation to optimize treatment parameters and understand the underlying molecular mechanisms.

Laparoscopic guided cholecystectomy. Laparoscopic guided cholecystectomy is a minimally invasive surgical procedure for the removal of the gallbladder. This technique involves the use of laparoscopic instruments and video imaging to visualize and dissect the gallbladder, allowing for a faster recovery time, reduced postoperative pain, and improved cosmetic outcomes when compared to traditional open cholecystectomy.

We present a retrospective analysis of 100 patients who underwent laparoscopic guided cholecystectomy for gallstone disease. The mean age of the patients was 52 years old, with a female predominance. The most common presenting symptom was right upper quadrant pain, and the majority of patients had preoperative evidence of gallstones on imaging.

The procedure was successfully completed in all cases, with no conversions to open surgery. The mean operative time was 60 minutes, and the average length of hospital stay was 1 day. Postoperative complications were minimal, with only 3 cases of bile duct injury requiring subsequent intervention.

Laparoscopic guided cholecystectomy is a safe and effective treatment option for gallstone disease. It offers several advantages over open surgery, including reduced morbidity, shorter hospital stay, and improved patient satisfaction. This technique should be considered as the standard of care for patients requiring gallbladder removal.

Sudden death caused by coronary artery aneurysms: a late complication of Kawasaki disease. Kawasaki disease is a systemic vasculitis that primarily affects children and can result in the development of coronary artery aneurysms. This case report describes a rare late complication of Kawasaki disease, namely sudden death caused by coronary artery aneurysms. The patient, a previously healthy 10-year-old boy, presented with sudden cardiac arrest and was found to have extensive coronary artery aneurysms on postmortem examination. The report highlights the importance of close monitoring and long-term follow-up of patients with Kawasaki disease, particularly those with known coronary artery involvement. Early detection and appropriate management of coronary artery aneurysms in Kawasaki disease patients are crucial to prevent life-threatening complications such as sudden death.

Differentiation of ventricular tachyarrhythmias. Ventricular tachyarrhythmias are a significant cause of morbidity and mortality in patients with structural heart disease. Differentiating between different types of ventricular tachyarrhythmias is crucial for appropriate management and treatment. This review article provides an overview of the various ventricular tachyarrhythmias, including ventricular fibrillation, monomorphic ventricular tachycardia, polymorphic ventricular tachycardia, and torsades de pointes. The clinical manifestations, electrocardiographic findings, and underlying mechanisms of these arrhythmias are discussed. Additionally, various diagnostic modalities, including electrophysiological studies and cardiac imaging, are described for accurate diagnosis. The importance of risk stratification and appropriate therapy, including antiarrhythmic medications, implantable cardioverter-defibrillator placement, and catheter ablation, is emphasized. Clinicians should have a thorough understanding of the different ventricular tachyarrhythmias to provide optimal management and improve patient outcomes. Further research is needed to explore novel diagnostic and therapeutic strategies in the field of ventricular tachyarrhythmias.

Antenatal spontaneous perforation of the extrahepatic biliary tree. Antenatal spontaneous perforation of the extrahepatic biliary tree is a rare condition that presents with acute abdominal symptoms in the newborn period. The exact etiology of this condition is unclear, but theories suggest that it may be due to developmental abnormalities or ischemia during fetal life. Diagnosis is challenging and requires a high index of suspicion, as symptoms can mimic other common neonatal gastrointestinal emergencies. Imaging studies such as abdominal ultrasound and magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography can aid in the diagnosis. Prompt surgical intervention is usually required to prevent further complications such as sepsis and biliary peritonitis. Prognosis varies depending on the extent of injury and associated anomalies. This abstract highlights the importance of early recognition and management of antenatal spontaneous perforation of the extrahepatic biliary tree to improve outcomes in affected newborns.

Dystrophin analysis in Duchenne and Becker muscular dystrophy carriers: correlation with intracellular calcium and albumin. In this cross-sectional study, 30 carriers of Duchenne and Becker muscular dystrophies were evaluated for dystrophin analysis, intracellular calcium levels, and albumin levels. The results showed a wide range of dystrophin levels among the carriers, with some having normal levels and others displaying varying degrees of deficiency. There was a positive correlation between dystrophin levels and albumin levels, suggesting a potential role of albumin in stabilizing dystrophin. Interestingly, carriers with lower dystrophin levels exhibited higher intracellular calcium levels, indicating possible calcium dysregulation in these individuals. These findings provide insights into the pathophysiology of muscular dystrophies and suggest that monitoring dystrophin levels, as well as intracellular calcium and albumin levels, may aid in the management and prognosis of carriers of Duchenne and Becker muscular dystrophies.

Lateral deviation of the eyes on forced lid closure in patients with cerebral lesions. Lateral deviation of the eyes on forced lid closure, also known as Parinaud syndrome, is a clinical manifestation commonly observed in patients with cerebral lesions. This retrospective study aimed to investigate the prevalence and clinical characteristics of this phenomenon in a cohort of patients diagnosed with cerebral lesions. The medical records of 120 patients were reviewed, and 45% of them exhibited lateral deviation of the eyes on forced lid closure. The majority of patients (86%) had a history of traumatic brain injury, while other etiologies included stroke and brain tumors. Notably, patients with frontal lobe lesions were more likely to present with this sign compared to those with lesions in other areas of the brain. In conclusion, lateral deviation of the eyes on forced lid closure is a relevant clinical finding in patients with cerebral lesions, particularly those with frontal lobe involvement.

Small bile duct abnormalities in sarcoidosis. Sarcoidosis is a multisystem granulomatous disease that can affect various organs, including the liver. While hepatic involvement is common in sarcoidosis, small bile duct abnormalities in this condition have not been widely reported. We present two cases of sarcoidosis with small bile duct abnormalities. Case 1 demonstrated multiple small bile duct strictures with segmental dilation, while case 2 showed irregular narrowing and beading of intrahepatic bile ducts on magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography. Both cases were confirmed histopathologically, showing non-caseating granulomas around the bile ducts. These findings emphasize the importance of considering sarcoidosis in the differential diagnosis of small bile duct abnormalities, particularly in patients with known systemic involvement. Further studies are needed to understand the mechanisms and clinical implications of these findings.

Extramammary Paget's disease of the bronchial epithelium. Extramammary Paget's disease (EMPD) is a rare malignancy primarily affecting skin and mucosal surfaces. However, EMPD involvement of the bronchial epithelium is exceptionally rare with only a few reported cases in the literature. Here, we present a case of bronchial EMPD in a 62-year-old male who presented with chronic cough and hemoptysis. Histopathological examination of the bronchial biopsy revealed characteristic pagetoid cells with abundant cytoplasm and enlarged nuclei, consistent with Paget's disease. Immunohistochemistry demonstrated positive staining for cytokeratin 7 and negative staining for cytokeratin 20, supporting the diagnosis of EMPD. This case highlights the importance of considering EMPD as a differential diagnosis in patients with bronchial lesions, particularly in the presence of characteristic histopathological findings.

Wilson's disease: 35 years' experience.  Thirty-seven Chinese patients fulfilling the criteria for Wilson's disease seen during a 35-year period were reviewed. Wilson's disease is an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by impaired copper transport, leading to copper accumulation in various organs, including the liver and brain. In this retrospective study, we review the clinical presentation, laboratory findings, and treatment outcomes of 37 Chinese patients with Wilson's disease over a 35-year period. The most common presenting symptoms were hepatomegaly, jaundice, and neuropsychiatric manifestations. Laboratory investigations revealed elevated liver enzymes, decreased serum ceruloplasmin levels, and Kayser-Fleischer rings on ophthalmologic examination. Treatment with chelating agents, such as penicillamine or trientine, resulted in clinical improvement and normalization of liver function in the majority of patients. However, a subset of patients with advanced liver disease required liver transplantation. Our study highlights the importance of early diagnosis and appropriate management in improving outcomes for patients with Wilson's disease.

Treatment of manifest and impending pathologic fractures of the femoral neck by cemented hemiarthroplasty.  Thirty-four patients with manifest or impending pathologic fractures of the femoral neck were treated between 1971 and 1987. In this study, we present the results of treating 34 patients with manifest or impending pathologic fractures of the femoral neck using cemented hemiarthroplasty. The fractures were caused by underlying conditions such as metastatic carcinoma, multiple myeloma, and primary lymphoma. The patients were followed up for an average of 2 years postoperatively. The majority of patients experienced improvement in pain and functional status following surgery. Complications included three cases of dislocation and two cases of deep infection. Revision surgery was required in five patients. Our results suggest that cemented hemiarthroplasty is a reliable and effective treatment option for patients with manifest or impending pathologic fractures of the femoral neck, providing pain relief and functional improvement.

Implementation of cancer prevention guidelines in clinical practice.  Data from several sources, including consumer surveys, physician surveys, and medical record audits, indicate that consumers do not receive cancer screening tests as recommended by the National Cancer Institute, the American Cancer Society, and the U. S. Preventive Services Task Force. This gap in cancer prevention practices highlights the need for effective implementation of cancer prevention guidelines in clinical practice. Various strategies have been proposed to improve the adherence to these guidelines, including provider education, patient reminders, and system-level interventions. However, studies assessing the impact of these strategies have yielded mixed results. This review aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of different implementation strategies on the adherence to cancer prevention guidelines. A systematic search of electronic databases yielded a total of 15 studies that met the inclusion criteria. Findings suggest that provider education and patient reminders can improve adherence to cancer prevention guidelines, while system-level interventions may have limited impact. Further research is warranted to identify the most effective strategies for implementing cancer prevention guidelines in clinical practice.

Longitudinal study of diagnoses in children of women with unipolar and bipolar affective disorder. Children of women with unipolar and bipolar affective disorder (UPAD and BPAD) have an increased risk of developing psychiatric disorders. However, little is known about the specific diagnoses that these children may receive over time. This longitudinal study aimed to investigate the diagnoses in children of women with UPAD and BPAD throughout their childhood and adolescence. The study sample included 300 children born to mothers diagnosed with either UPAD or BPAD. Data on psychiatric diagnoses were collected at regular intervals from birth until the age of 18 years. Preliminary results indicate that children of women with UPAD had higher rates of anxiety and depressive disorders, while children of women with BPAD had higher rates of bipolar and disruptive behavior disorders. These findings highlight the importance of early identification and intervention in children at high genetic risk for affective disorders.

Contracturing granulomatous myositis: a separate entity. Contracturing granulomatous myositis (CGM) is a rare inflammatory disorder affecting skeletal muscle. It is characterized by the presence of granulomatous inflammation with subsequent fibrosis and contractures. Historically, CGM has been considered a variant of idiopathic inflammatory myopathy, such as polymyositis or dermatomyositis. However, emerging evidence suggests that CGM may represent a distinct entity with unique clinical and pathological features. This review aims to summarize the current understanding of CGM, including its clinical presentation, pathological findings, diagnostic criteria, and treatment options. CGM typically presents with progressive muscle weakness and contractures, often involving the proximal muscles. Histopathological examination reveals granulomatous inflammation with multinucleated giant cells, fibrosis, and myofiber degeneration. Laboratory investigations are usually unremarkable, with muscle enzyme levels within normal limits. High-dose corticosteroids are the mainstay of treatment, with several case reports suggesting potential benefit from immunosuppressive agents and physical therapy. Further research is warranted to better characterize CGM and optimize its management.

Malignant glandular triton tumor. Malignant glandular triton tumor (MGTT) is a rare and aggressive type of soft tissue sarcoma that arises from the transformation of normal Schwann cells into malignant glandular structures. MGTT primarily affects the head and neck region, with a predilection for the parotid and submandibular glands. Here, we present a case report of a 55-year-old male who presented with a painless mass in the left parotid gland. Histopathological examination revealed a malignant glandular triton tumor, characterized by the presence of both malignant glandular and rhabdomyoblastic components. Immunohistochemical analysis showed positive staining for epithelial markers, S100, and myogenic markers, confirming the dual nature of the tumor. Due to the aggressive nature of MGTT and high propensity for metastasis, complete surgical resection followed by adjuvant radiotherapy was performed. This case highlights the importance of early recognition and comprehensive management of MGTT for improved outcomes. Further studies are needed to better understand the pathogenesis and identify potential therapeutic targets for this rare malignancy.

Clinicopathologic and flow cytometric DNA study of medullary thyroid carcinoma.  Sixty-one patients with medullary thyroid carcinoma were investigated to establish relationships between the neoplasm's DNA content, other clinicopathologic factors, and patient survival (at least 5 years' follow-up). The authors conducted a study involving sixty-one patients diagnosed with medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC) to examine the correlation between DNA content of the neoplasm, clinicopathologic factors, and long-term patient survival. Clinicopathologic factors such as age, sex, tumor size, lymph node involvement, distant metastases, and stage were analyzed. Flow cytometric DNA analysis was performed to determine the DNA content of the tumor cells. Follow-up data of at least 5 years were collected to assess patient survival. The results indicated a significant association between DNA content and several clinicopathologic factors, including tumor size, lymph node involvement, and stage. Furthermore, patients with a higher DNA content showed a lower survival rate compared to those with a lower DNA content, suggesting that DNA content could serve as a prognostic marker in MTC.

Complications of general anesthesia for Nd:YAG laser resection of endobronchial tumors.  We studied the incidence and mechanisms of cardiovascular complications and postoperative respiratory insufficiency associated with GA and Nd:YAG laser endobronchial tumor resection. A total of 42 patients undergoing Nd:YAG laser resection of endobronchial tumors under general anesthesia (GA) were included in this study. Data on cardiovascular complications, such as hypotension, tachycardia, and arrhythmias, as well as postoperative respiratory insufficiency, were collected and analyzed. 

The incidence of cardiovascular complications was found to be 31%, with hypotension being the most common complication (22%). Tachycardia and arrhythmias were observed in 14% and 9% of the patients, respectively. Postoperative respiratory insufficiency occurred in 9% of the patients.

The mechanisms underlying these complications were multifactorial, with hypotension primarily attributed to anesthesia-induced vasodilation and blood loss during the procedure. Tachycardia and arrhythmias were mainly associated with sympathetic stimulation and inhalation of laser plume. Postoperative respiratory insufficiency was linked to airway obstruction and respiratory depression.
