These findings highlight the importance of close monitoring of cardiovascular parameters and respiratory status during Nd:YAG laser resection of endobronchial tumors under GA, as well as the need for appropriate management strategies to minimize complications and ensure patient safety.

Demonstration of the genuine iso-12p character of the standard marker chromosome of testicular germ cell tumors and identification of further chromosome 12 aberrations by competitive in situ hybridization. The authors investigated the genetic characteristics of testicular germ cell tumors (TGCTs) using competitive in situ hybridization (CISH) and found that the standard marker chromosome of TGCTs is genuinely iso-12p. They further identified additional chromosome 12 aberrations in these tumors. CISH revealed a high frequency of iso-12p in the analyzed TGCT samples, confirming its role as a specific genetic marker. Additionally, CISH enabled the detection of other chromosome 12 aberrations, highlighting the importance of this technique in understanding the genetic alterations and potential diagnostic and therapeutic implications in TGCTs. This study contributes to the knowledge of TGCT genetics and may aid in the early detection and management of these tumors.

The failure of serial pneumatic cuff venous occlusion plethysmography to predict patients at risk for pulmonary emboli after trauma. Serial pneumatic cuff venous occlusion plethysmography (pCOPG) is often used as a screening tool to identify patients at risk for pulmonary emboli (PE) following trauma. However, its efficacy in predicting PE remains controversial. In this study, we retrospectively analyzed data from trauma patients who underwent pCOPG and subsequent imaging for suspected PE. Among the 100 patients included in the analysis, 25% had confirmed PE. Interestingly, pCOPG failed to identify any of the patients with PE. Furthermore, there was no significant correlation between pCOPG results and the presence or absence of PE on imaging. These findings suggest that pCOPG may not be an effective tool for predicting patients at risk for PE after trauma and alternative screening methods should be considered.

Pathological changes in levator palpebrae superioris muscle treated with botulinum toxin in a case of carotico-cavernous fistula. Botulinum toxin is commonly used to treat various muscle disorders by inducing temporary paralysis. However, its effect on the levator palpebrae superioris muscle in the context of carotico-cavernous fistula is not well-documented. We present a case report of a patient with carotico-cavernous fistula who underwent botulinum toxin injection into the levator palpebrae superioris muscle to relieve symptoms of ptosis. Histopathological examination of the muscle was performed to assess any pathological changes resulting from the treatment. It was observed that the muscle showed signs of denervation atrophy and fibrosis, consistent with the temporary paralysis induced by botulinum toxin. These findings suggest that botulinum toxin treatment may lead to histological alterations in the levator palpebrae superioris muscle, which should be taken into consideration when using this therapy in patients with carotico-cavernous fistula. Further studies are necessary to evaluate the long-term effects of such treatment.

Surgical complications of continuous ambulatory peritoneal dialysis.  Surgical experience with 260 consecutive patients with chronic renal failure receiving continuous ambulatory peritoneal dialysis (CAPD) at one medical center from 1980 to 1989 is reviewed. A retrospective study was conducted to analyze the surgical complications associated with continuous ambulatory peritoneal dialysis (CAPD) in patients with chronic renal failure. A total of 260 consecutive patients undergoing CAPD at a single medical center from 1980 to 1989 were included in the analysis. The study aimed to identify the types and frequencies of surgical complications in this patient population. Surgical complications were observed in 45.4% of the patients, with peritonitis being the most common complication (32.3%). Other complications included catheter dysfunction, exit-site infection, hernia, and bowel perforation. These complications resulted in hospitalization, prolonged duration of CAPD treatment, and increased healthcare costs. Awareness and management of surgical complications in patients undergoing CAPD are essential for optimizing treatment outcomes and reducing morbidity and mortality. Further research is needed to develop strategies for preventing and managing these complications.

Botulinum A toxin for the treatment of adult-onset spasmodic torticollis. Adult-onset spasmodic torticollis, a focal dystonia characterized by involuntary contractions of neck muscles, can greatly impact quality of life. The efficacy of botulinum A toxin (BTX-A) in treating this condition was investigated in a cohort of 28 adult patients. Patients received intramuscular injections of BTX-A into affected neck muscles and were followed up for 12 weeks. A significant improvement in subjective symptom severity, as measured by the Toronto Western Spasmodic Torticollis Rating Scale, was observed in 82.1% of patients. Furthermore, neck posture and pain were significantly reduced after BTX-A treatment. No major adverse events were reported. BTX-A appears to be an effective and safe treatment option for adult-onset spasmodic torticollis.

Carcinoma of the cervix: value of MR imaging in detecting parametrial involvement.  In patients with cervical carcinoma, precise knowledge of parametrial tumor extension affects the therapeutic decision between surgery and radiation therapy. In this study, we assessed the value of magnetic resonance (MR) imaging in detecting parametrial involvement in patients with carcinoma of the cervix. Forty-five patients with histologically proven cervical carcinoma underwent MR imaging before treatment. The MR images were evaluated for the presence of parametrial involvement, which was confirmed by histopathology in 38 patients who underwent surgery. The sensitivity, specificity, and accuracy of MR imaging in detecting parametrial involvement were determined. MR imaging showed a sensitivity of 97.4%, specificity of 60.0%, and accuracy of 93.3% in detecting parametrial involvement. Our findings indicate that MR imaging is a valuable tool in detecting parametrial tumor extension in patients with cervical carcinoma. The accurate assessment of parametrial involvement can aid in better therapeutic decision-making between surgery and radiation therapy.

Noninvasive assessment of cardiac output in children using impedance cardiography.  This study evaluated the effect of intracardiac shunting on the accuracy of thoracic bioimpedance-derived cardiac output determinations. Impedance cardiography is a noninvasive method used to assess cardiac output in children. This study aimed to investigate the impact of intracardiac shunting on the accuracy of thoracic bioimpedance-derived cardiac output measurements in this population. A total of 50 children with intracardiac shunting and 50 without shunting were included in the analysis. Cardiac output was measured using impedance cardiography and compared to the reference standard method. The results demonstrated that children with intracardiac shunting had significantly lower accuracy of cardiac output measurements compared to those without shunting. The presence of intracardiac shunting resulted in an overestimation of cardiac output values. These findings highlight the importance of considering the impact of intracardiac shunting when using impedance cardiography for cardiac output assessment in children. Further studies are warranted to explore potential strategies for improving the accuracy of cardiac output measurements in this population.

Spinal cord compression from a thoracic paraganglioma: case report. Paragangliomas are rare neuroendocrine tumors that arise from paraganglia located along the sympathetic and parasympathetic pathways. While paragangliomas can occur anywhere along the neuroaxis, thoracic paragangliomas are extremely rare. We report a case of a 42-year-old male who presented with progressive lower extremity weakness and numbness. Imaging studies revealed a large paraspinal mass compressing the spinal cord at the T4-T5 level. The patient underwent surgical resection of the mass, and histopathological examination confirmed the diagnosis of a paraganglioma. Immunohistochemical staining demonstrated positivity for chromogranin and synaptophysin, supporting the neuroendocrine nature of the tumor. Postoperatively, the patient's neurological symptoms improved significantly. This case highlights the importance of considering thoracic paragangliomas in the differential diagnosis of spinal cord compression, even in the absence of classic paraganglioma locations. Early recognition and surgical intervention can lead to favorable outcomes in patients with thoracic paragangliomas. Further studies are needed to elucidate the molecular mechanisms underlying the development and progression of these rare tumors.

Is emotional disturbance a precipitator or a consequence of chronic pain? The present study examined the relationship between psychological factors and pain in order to assess the contribution of emotional disturbance to the perpetuation of pain. The study aimed to investigate whether emotional disturbance serves as a precipitator or a consequence of chronic pain. A total of 250 participants with chronic pain were included in the study and completed self-report measures assessing pain intensity, emotional well-being, pain catastrophizing, and pain-related disability. Structural equation modeling was used to analyze the data. The results revealed a bidirectional relationship between emotional disturbance and pain. Higher levels of emotional disturbance were associated with increased pain intensity, pain catastrophizing, and pain-related disability. Conversely, higher levels of pain intensity, pain catastrophizing, and pain-related disability also predicted increased emotional disturbance. These findings suggest that emotional disturbance and chronic pain perpetuate each other, highlighting the importance of considering emotional factors in the assessment and management of chronic pain.

Use of the Collings knife electrode for percutaneous access in difficult endourology cases. The Collings knife electrode has been increasingly utilized as a percutaneous access tool in challenging endourology cases. A retrospective analysis was conducted on 25 endourology procedures where the Collings knife electrode was employed for percutaneous access. The procedures included percutaneous nephrolithotomy, retrograde intrarenal surgery, and percutaneous nephrostomy. The Collings knife electrode demonstrated high success rates of 92% for achieving percutaneous access, with minimal complications observed. Notably, the Collings knife electrode proved particularly useful in cases with complex anatomy, urinary tract obstructions, or previous surgical interventions. Its unique design, featuring a sharp cutting wire and a shape memory alloy sheath, allowed for precise and controlled access through various tissues and calices. Furthermore, the Collings knife electrode was effective in facilitating direct visualization, minimizing blood loss, and shortening operative times. Collectively, these findings suggest that the Collings knife electrode is a valuable tool for percutaneous access in difficult endourology cases, improving procedural outcomes and patient safety.

Optimum results of the surgical treatment of carotid territory ischemia. This study aimed to determine the optimum results of surgical treatment for carotid territory ischemia. A retrospective analysis was conducted on a cohort of patients who underwent surgical intervention for carotid artery disease. The primary outcome measures included perioperative stroke, long-term stroke, and overall mortality rates. Secondary outcome measures included restenosis, perioperative complications, and functional status post-surgery. Data from 150 patients were analyzed, with a mean follow-up period of 3 years. The perioperative stroke rate was found to be 2.7%, while the long-term stroke rate was 4%. Overall mortality rate was 1.3%. Restenosis occurred in 6.7% of cases. Perioperative complications were observed in 10% of patients. Functional status significantly improved post-surgery, with 80% of patients reporting no or minimal disability. These findings highlight the favorable outcomes of surgical treatment for carotid territory ischemia in terms of stroke prevention and functional improvement.

Percutaneous transluminal angioplasty of crural arteries.  The authors dilated 103 stenosed crural arteries in 71 patients. This retrospective study evaluated the efficacy and safety of percutaneous transluminal angioplasty (PTA) in the treatment of stenosed crural arteries. The medical records of 71 patients who underwent PTA for crural artery stenosis between January 2010 and December 2018 were reviewed. A total of 103 crural arteries were dilated during the study period. The majority of patients (n=53) had critical limb ischemia, while the remaining 18 patients had claudication. The technical success rate of PTA was 95.1%, with only five arteries requiring additional intervention. The primary patency rate at 1 and 3 years was 84.3% and 69.8%, respectively. The limb salvage rate at 3 years was 83.1%. Procedure-related complications were observed in 12.9% of patients, with only one major complication requiring surgical intervention. In conclusion, PTA is a safe and effective treatment option for crural artery stenosis, resulting in favorable limb salvage and patency rates.

Aneurysmal dilatation in saphenous vein bypass grafts. Aneurysmal dilatation of saphenous vein bypass grafts (SVGs) is a rare but significant complication that can lead to graft failure and subsequent revascularization procedures. This report aims to provide an overview of the pathogenesis, clinical presentation, and management of aneurysmal dilatation in SVGs. The etiology of this condition is multifactorial, with risk factors including graft size, hemodynamic changes, and atherosclerosis. The clinical presentation can vary, ranging from asymptomatic to acute graft occlusion or rupture. Diagnosis is typically made through imaging modalities such as Doppler ultrasound or angiography. Management options include observation, endovascular treatment, or surgical intervention, depending on the size and location of the aneurysm. Prevention strategies include careful patient selection, proper graft harvesting techniques, and long-term surveillance. Further research is needed to improve our understanding of this condition and optimize treatment outcomes.

Calcium and calcium binding in human gallstone disease. The formation of gallstones is a common disorder affecting the biliary tract, and the underlying mechanisms remain poorly understood. Calcium has been implicated in the pathogenesis of gallstone disease; however, the specific role of calcium and its binding proteins in this condition has not been well characterized. This study aimed to investigate the association between calcium and calcium binding proteins in human gallstone disease. Gallstone samples and adjacent normal gallbladder tissue were collected from patients undergoing cholecystectomy. Immunohistochemical staining was performed to evaluate the expression of calcium binding proteins, including S100A4, S100A6, and S100B, in both groups. The results showed that the expression of S100A4 and S100A6 was significantly higher in gallstone samples compared to normal gallbladder tissue. Additionally, calcium deposits were observed in both groups, with a higher prevalence in gallstone samples. These findings suggest a potential involvement of calcium and calcium binding proteins in the pathogenesis of gallstone disease. Further research is needed to elucidate the underlying mechanisms and explore potential therapeutic targets.

Porokeratoses: immunohistochemical, light and electron microscopic evaluation. Porokeratoses are a group of disorders characterized by the presence of cornoid lamellae, a specific histopathological finding. The etiology and pathogenesis of porokeratoses remain unclear, but they are believed to involve both genetic and environmental factors. This study aimed to evaluate porokeratoses by immunohistochemical, light, and electron microscopic methods to gain further insight into their pathogenesis.

Immunohistochemical staining was performed to assess the expression of various markers related to keratinocyte differentiation, proliferation, and inflammation. Light microscopy was used to examine the histological features of the lesions, while electron microscopy allowed for high-resolution visualization of the ultrastructural changes.

The results of this study revealed alterations in markers related to epidermal differentiation and proliferation, supporting the hypothesis that porokeratoses arise from abnormal keratinocyte proliferation and differentiation. Additionally, inflammatory infiltrates were observed in the lesional epidermis, suggesting an immune-mediated component in their pathogenesis. Ultrastructural changes, such as abnormal keratinization and altered intercellular junctions, further supported the hypothesis of disturbed epidermal differentiation.

Overall, this study provides valuable insights into the pathogenesis of porokeratoses and may contribute to the development of targeted therapeutic approaches for their management. Further research is warranted to elucidate the precise mechanisms underlying the development and progression of these intriguing skin disorders.

Effect of electrocautery on wound healing in midline laparotomy incisions. Electrocautery is commonly used during surgery to achieve hemostasis and facilitate dissection. However, its impact on wound healing in midline laparotomy incisions is not well understood. This study aimed to evaluate the effect of electrocautery on wound healing in a controlled experimental setting. Wistar rats were subjected to midline laparotomy incisions, with one group undergoing electrocautery and the other serving as a control. Evaluation of wound healing parameters, including wound strength, inflammation, and scar formation, was performed at various time points postoperatively. Results showed that wounds subjected to electrocautery exhibited delayed healing, characterized by decreased wound strength, increased inflammation, and impaired scar formation compared to the control group. These findings suggest that caution should be exercised when using electrocautery in midline laparotomy incisions to minimize its detrimental effects on wound healing. Further studies are warranted to explore strategies for enhancing wound healing in the presence of electrocautery.

Percutaneous transperineal prostate cryosurgery using transrectal ultrasound guidance: animal model. Prostate cryosurgery is a minimally invasive technique utilized in the treatment of localized prostate cancer. In this study, we aimed to develop an animal model for percutaneous transperineal prostate cryosurgery using transrectal ultrasound guidance. The procedure was performed on ten male rabbits under general anesthesia. A transrectal ultrasound probe was used to visualize the prostate gland and guide the insertion of cryoprobes into the targeted areas. Cryoablation was then performed by circulating liquid nitrogen through the probes. Prostate tissue samples were collected before and after cryosurgery for histopathological analysis. The results demonstrated successful targeting and cryoablation of the prostate gland without major complications or adverse effects. The animal model developed in this study provides a promising platform for further research and development of percutaneous transperineal prostate cryosurgery techniques.

Metastatic small cell tumor of bone with 'true' rosettes and glial fibrillary acidic protein positivity. Metastatic small cell tumor of bone is a rare malignancy characterized by aggressive behavior and poor prognosis. A case study is presented of a 50-year-old male who presented with bone pain and was eventually diagnosed with metastatic small cell tumor of bone. Histopathological examination revealed the presence of 'true' rosettes, a characteristic feature of this tumor. Immunohistochemical analysis showed positivity for glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP), suggesting a neural origin. The patient underwent chemotherapy and radiation therapy, but unfortunately succumbed to the disease six months after diagnosis.

This case highlights the importance of recognizing the unique histological features and immunohistochemical patterns of metastatic small cell tumor of bone. The presence of 'true' rosettes and GFAP positivity can aid in distinguishing this tumor from other bone malignancies. Early and accurate diagnosis is crucial for appropriate management and treatment planning in patients with metastatic small cell tumor of bone. Further studies are needed to better understand the underlying mechanisms and develop targeted therapies for this rare and aggressive malignancy.

The butterfly rash and the malar flush. A 45-year-old female presented with a butterfly-shaped erythematous rash on the central face, specifically the cheeks and bridge of the nose, accompanied by a malar flush. The rash appeared intermittent and worsened with sun exposure. The patient denied any systemic symptoms like fever, joint pain, or malaise, but reported mild fatigue and occasional headaches. Physical examination revealed no abnormalities in vital signs, except for the aforementioned rash. Laboratory investigations showed no significant abnormalities, including normal complete blood count, renal and hepatic function tests, and antinuclear antibody screening. Further evaluation with a skin biopsy revealed evidence of immune complex deposition at the dermal-epidermal junction, suggestive of a lupus erythematosus (LE) variant. Follow-up examination and a thorough medical history corroborated the suspicion of cutaneous lupus erythematosus. Treatment with topical corticosteroids and sun protection measures was initiated, resulting in improvement of the rash. The case highlights the importance of recognizing the butterfly rash and malar flush as clinical manifestations of LE, necessitating appropriate diagnosis and management.

Toxic epidermal necrolysis after bone marrow transplantation: study of nine cases. Toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN) is a severe and life-threatening cutaneous adverse reaction predominantly associated with medication use. While bone marrow transplantation (BMT) has been implicated in the development of TEN, there remains limited understanding of this rare complication in the transplant setting. This retrospective study aimed to investigate the incidence, clinical features, risk factors, and outcomes of TEN after BMT. 

A total of nine cases of TEN following BMT were identified from a single center over a 5-year period. The median age of the patients was 28 years, and seven of them were male. The mean time from BMT to the onset of TEN was 21 days. Common implicated agents included antibiotics, antiviral drugs, and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs. Severe mucosal involvement was observed in all cases, with a mean body surface area involvement of 71%.

Mortality in this cohort was high, with six out of nine cases resulting in death. Factors associated with poor prognosis included older age, comorbidities, and delayed discontinuation of offender drugs. These findings underscore the importance of monitoring for potential adverse drug reactions, prompt recognition of TEN in the BMT setting, and cautious medication management to minimize morbidity and mortality in this vulnerable patient population.

Radical prostatectomy for clinical stage T1-2N0M0 prostatic adenocarcinoma: long-term results. The long-term results of radical prostatectomy for clinical stage T1-2N0M0 prostatic adenocarcinoma are presented in this study. A total of 500 patients with clinically localized prostate cancer underwent radical prostatectomy between 1990 and 2005. The median follow-up period was 15 years. The overall survival rate at 10, 15, and 20 years was 91%, 85%, and 78%, respectively. The disease-specific survival rate at the same time points was 98%, 95%, and 90%, respectively. The overall biochemical recurrence-free survival rate at 10, 15, and 20 years was 84%, 78%, and 72%, respectively. On multivariate analysis, preoperative prostate-specific antigen (PSA) level, pathological Gleason score, and surgical margin status were significant predictors of biochemical recurrence-free survival. Complications occurred in 18% of patients, with urinary incontinence and erectile dysfunction being the most common. In conclusion, radical prostatectomy remains an effective treatment option for clinical stage T1-2N0M0 prostatic adenocarcinoma, with favorable long-term oncological outcomes. However, patients should be counseled about the risk of urinary incontinence and erectile dysfunction.

Bacterial meningitis: an update. Bacterial meningitis remains a significant global health concern with high morbidity and mortality rates. This article aims to provide an update on the clinical presentation, diagnosis, treatment, and prevention of bacterial meningitis. The most common pathogens causing meningitis include Streptococcus pneumoniae, Neisseria meningitidis, and Haemophilus influenzae type b. However, there has been a global shift in the epidemiology of bacterial meningitis due to widespread vaccination efforts against these pathogens. Newer pathogens such as Listeria monocytogenes and non-typable H. influenzae have emerged as important causes of meningitis, particularly in specific populations. Rapid and accurate diagnosis through cerebrospinal fluid analysis and modern molecular diagnostic techniques remains crucial for appropriate management. Initial treatment involves prompt administration of empirical antibiotics, with adjustment based on culture results and antimicrobial susceptibility testing. Vaccination remains the cornerstone for prevention, and the development of new vaccines against emerging pathogens holds promise in reducing the burden of bacterial meningitis. Continued surveillance, public health measures, and antimicrobial stewardship are vital for effective control and prevention of bacterial meningitis.

X-linked spinal muscular atrophy (Kennedy's syndrome). X-linked spinal muscular atrophy, also known as Kennedy's syndrome, is a rare neurodegenerative disorder that predominantly affects males. This disorder is caused by a mutation in the androgen receptor gene, resulting in the progressive degeneration of lower motor neurons in the spinal cord and brainstem. 

Clinically, patients typically present with muscle weakness and atrophy, initially affecting the proximal muscles of the extremities and eventually progressing to involve the bulbar and respiratory muscles. Other features may include fasciculations, tremor, and gynecomastia. 

Diagnosis is confirmed through genetic testing, demonstrating the presence of the androgen receptor gene mutation. Electromyography can also be utilized to assess the severity and distribution of motor neuron involvement. 

Management involves symptomatic and supportive care, with interventions such as physical and occupational therapy, orthopedic support, and respiratory assistance as necessary. Despite the progressive nature of the disease, the prognosis can vary widely between individuals. Further research is required to elucidate potential targeted therapies for this devastating condition.

Molecular analysis of acute promyelocytic leukemia breakpoint cluster region on chromosome 17. The acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL) breakpoint cluster region (BCR) on chromosome 17 has been the focus of molecular analysis in this study. The aim was to gain a better understanding of the genetic abnormalities associated with APL. A total of 30 APL patients were included in the analysis. Fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) and reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) were performed to detect the BCR gene rearrangements. The results revealed that all 30 patients exhibited BCR gene rearrangements, with the most common fusion being PML-RARA. Additionally, the study identified other rare fusion types, including PLZF-RARA and STAT5b-RARA. The findings contribute to our knowledge of the molecular characteristics of APL and may have implications for targeted therapies in the future.

Incidence of cutaneous T cell lymphoma and other rare skin cancers in a defined population.  Between 1970 and 1984 in Rochester, Minnesota, rare skin cancers developed in 15 local residents: cutaneous T cell lymphoma (six subjects), dermatofibrosarcoma protuberans (four), adenocarcinoma of sweat glands (two), Merkel cell carcinoma (one), liposarcoma (one), and extramammary Paget's disease (one). This study aimed to determine the incidence of cutaneous T cell lymphoma (CTCL) and other rare skin cancers in a specific population. The research was conducted between 1970 and 1984 in Rochester, Minnesota. A total of 15 individuals who were local residents developed rare skin cancers during this period. The most common rare skin cancer identified was CTCL, with six subjects affected. Other rare skin cancers observed included dermatofibrosarcoma protuberans (four cases), adenocarcinoma of sweat glands (two cases), Merkel cell carcinoma (one case), liposarcoma (one case), and extramammary Paget's disease (one case). This information provides valuable insight into the incidence of these rare skin cancers within a defined population.

The Marinesco-Sjogren syndrome examined by computed tomography, magnetic resonance, and 18F-2-fluoro-2-deoxy-D-glucose and positron emission tomography. Marinesco-Sjogren syndrome (MSS) is a rare autosomal recessive disorder characterized by cerebellar ataxia, cataracts, intellectual disability, and skeletal abnormalities. The purpose of this study was to evaluate the radiologic manifestations of MSS using computed tomography (CT), magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), and positron emission tomography (PET) with 18F-2-fluoro-2-deoxy-D-glucose (FDG). Imaging findings of seven patients with genetically confirmed MSS were retrospectively reviewed. CT and MRI showed cerebellar atrophy and vermis hypoplasia, which correlated with the severity of ataxia. FDG-PET revealed global cerebral hypometabolism, most prominently in the thalamus and cerebellum. Furthermore, PET allowed visualization of previously unseen abnormalities, such as hypometabolism in the basal ganglia. These findings contribute to the understanding of the pathophysiology of MSS and may aid in the diagnosis and monitoring of disease progression. However, future studies with larger sample sizes are warranted to confirm these findings.

Neuroexcitatory plasma amino acids are elevated in migraine. Elevated levels of neuroexcitatory plasma amino acids have been found in patients with migraine. The study aimed to investigate the relationship between these amino acids and the development of migraine attacks. Plasma samples were collected from individuals diagnosed with migraine and healthy controls. The levels of aspartate, glutamate, and glycine were measured using high-performance liquid chromatography. The results showed significantly higher levels of aspartate and glutamate in migraine patients compared to controls. However, no significant difference was observed in glycine levels between the two groups. Furthermore, a positive correlation was found between the severity of migraine attacks and the levels of aspartate and glutamate. These findings suggest that elevated levels of neuroexcitatory amino acids may play a role in the pathophysiology of migraine and could potentially serve as targets for therapeutic interventions. Further research is needed to elucidate the underlying mechanisms and explore potential treatment strategies for migraine.

Medical treatment and prevention of peptic ulcer disease.  Many agents seem to be equally effective for the treatment of peptic ulcer disease. Peptic ulcer disease (PUD) is a common digestive disorder that affects millions of people worldwide. The management of PUD involves both medical treatment and prevention strategies. This review aims to evaluate the efficacy of various agents for the treatment and prevention of PUD.

Numerous agents have been studied for the treatment of PUD, including proton pump inhibitors (PPIs), histamine H2-receptor antagonists (H2RAs), Helicobacter pylori eradication therapies, and cytoprotective agents. Overall, PPIs have been shown to be the most effective agents in healing both gastric and duodenal ulcers, with H2RAs being less potent. H. pylori eradication therapies have been proven effective in treating and preventing PUD, and their use is recommended in all patients with H. pylori infection. Cytoprotective agents, such as sucralfate and misoprostol, have limited evidence supporting their efficacy in ulcer healing but may have a role in preventing NSAID-induced ulcers.

In terms of prevention, the main focus is on H. pylori eradication and avoiding risk factors, including nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) use and cigarette smoking. This can significantly reduce the recurrence rates of PUD.

In conclusion, the treatment of PUD involves a combination of targeted therapy for H. pylori eradication, acid suppression with PPIs or H2RAs, and cytoprotective agents in select cases. Prevention strategies primarily revolve around H. pylori eradication and avoiding risk factors. While many agents show effectiveness in treating and preventing PUD, the choice of treatment should be individualized based on the patient's risk factors, underlying etiology, and tolerability of the medication.

Cause of death in an emergency department A retrospective review was done of 601 consecutive emergency department deaths.  Nontrauma causes accounted for 77% of the deaths and this group had an average age of 64 years and a male to female ratio of 1. A retrospective review was conducted on 601 emergency department deaths to determine the causes of death. Nontraumatic causes accounted for 77% of the deaths, with an average age of 64 years and a male to female ratio of 1. The specific causes of death within the nontrauma group were analyzed, including cardiovascular diseases, respiratory diseases, infections, and other medical conditions. The study provides valuable information on the leading causes of death in the emergency department and highlights the need for timely and appropriate medical interventions to improve patient outcomes.

Carboplatin in childhood brain tumors. Carboplatin has been widely used as a chemotherapeutic agent in the treatment of solid tumors, including childhood brain tumors. This review aims to summarize the current evidence on the efficacy and safety of carboplatin in this specific patient population. 

Several studies have demonstrated the effectiveness of carboplatin in inducing tumor regression and improving survival outcomes in children with brain tumors. It has shown promising results in high-grade gliomas, medulloblastomas, and ependymomas, either as a single agent or in combination with other chemotherapeutic drugs. 

The optimal dosage and schedule of carboplatin administration are still a matter of debate, with variations across different trials. Adverse events associated with carboplatin treatment include myelosuppression, neurotoxicity, ototoxicity, and renal toxicity. Close monitoring of blood counts, neurologic status, and renal function is essential during carboplatin therapy in children. 

Overall, carboplatin represents a valuable therapeutic option for the management of childhood brain tumors. However, further investigations are needed to establish standardized protocols and identify potential predictive markers of response to carboplatin treatment in this specific population.

The operative management of coexisting thyroid and parathyroid disease.  Three hundred eight patients who underwent operation for hyperparathyroidism were studied. Coexistence of thyroid and parathyroid disease is a common clinical scenario, yet there is limited literature regarding the optimal management approach. This study aimed to analyze the operative management and outcomes of patients with coexisting thyroid and parathyroid disease. 

Three hundred eight patients who underwent surgery for hyperparathyroidism were retrospectively reviewed. Among them, 72 patients (23.4%) had concomitant thyroid pathology. The majority of thyroid lesions were benign nodules (n=66), while six patients had thyroid cancer. 

Thyroidectomy was performed in 32 patients, either as a separate procedure or concurrently with parathyroidectomy. The remaining 40 patients underwent parathyroidectomy alone. Postoperatively, no significant differences were observed in parathyroid hormone levels or calcium levels between the two groups. 

In conclusion, the management of coexisting thyroid and parathyroid disease should be individualized, considering the characteristics of each lesion and the patient's overall health. Collaboration between endocrine surgeons and thyroid specialists is pivotal for optimal patient outcomes. Further studies are needed to establish standardized guidelines for the management of these challenging cases.

Surgical aspects of sclerosing encapsulating peritonitis. Sclerosing encapsulating peritonitis (SEP) is a rare condition characterized by the formation of a fibrotic membrane around the small intestine, leading to bowel obstruction. The aim of this study was to describe the surgical aspects and outcomes of SEP in a series of 25 patients. The mean age of the patients was 47 years, and the most common presenting symptoms were abdominal pain and distension. Preoperative imaging studies showed signs of bowel obstruction in all patients. Surgical treatment consisted of adhesiolysis and excision of the fibrotic membrane. Intraoperative findings included dense adhesions and encapsulation of the small bowel. Postoperatively, all patients experienced symptomatic relief, with no recurrence of symptoms during follow-up. Complications included wound infection and enterocutaneous fistula, which were managed conservatively. In conclusion, surgical treatment of SEP involves adhesiolysis and excision of the fibrotic membrane, resulting in favorable outcomes and resolution of symptoms. Further studies are needed to evaluate long-term outcomes and optimal surgical techniques for SEP.

Immunohistologic localization of alpha, mu, and pi class glutathione S-transferases in human tissues. Glutathione S-transferases (GSTs) are enzymes that play a crucial role in detoxification processes by catalyzing the conjugation of glutathione to various electrophilic compounds. In this study, the immunohistologic localization of alpha, mu, and pi class GSTs in human tissues was investigated. 

Tissue specimens from various organs including liver, lung, kidney, and gastrointestinal tract were obtained from autopsy cases and subjected to immunohistochemical analysis using specific antibodies against alpha, mu, and pi class GSTs. 

The results revealed distinct patterns of immunoexpression of GSTs in different tissue types. The alpha class GSTs were predominantly localized in hepatocytes and renal tubular cells, while the mu class GSTs were found in the epithelial lining of the respiratory and gastrointestinal tracts. The pi class GSTs showed a widespread distribution in various tissues, including hepatocytes, bronchial epithelium, and renal tubules. 

These findings provide valuable insights into the tissue-specific expression patterns of different GST isoforms, which may have implications for understanding their role in detoxification processes and their potential as therapeutic targets in diseases involving oxidative stress and xenobiotic metabolism.

Comparison of shunt fraction estimation using transcolonic iodine-123-iodoamphetamine and technetium-99m-pertechnetate in a group of dogs with experimentally-induced chronic biliary cirrhosis. In this study, transcolonic iodine-123-iodoamphetamine (IMP) and technetium-99m-pertechnetate (99mTc) were used to estimate the shunt fraction in a group of dogs with experimentally-induced chronic biliary cirrhosis. The dogs were divided into two groups, with one group receiving IMP and the other receiving 99mTc. The shunt fraction was measured using a gamma camera system. The results showed that both IMP and 99mTc provided reliable estimations of the shunt fraction. There was a strong correlation between the two methods (r = 0.82, p < 0.001). The mean shunt fraction in the dogs with chronic biliary cirrhosis was significantly higher compared to a control group of healthy dogs (p < 0.001). This study suggests that both transcolonic IMP and 99mTc can be used to accurately estimate the shunt fraction in dogs with chronic biliary cirrhosis. These findings may have important implications for the diagnosis and management of this condition in veterinary medicine.

Decreased local toxicity with subcutaneous diamorphine (heroin): a preliminary report. This study investigated the potential benefits of subcutaneous administration of diamorphine (heroin) in reducing local toxicity compared to intravenous administration. A total of 25 participants with prior opioid dependence were enrolled in the study. They received either subcutaneous or intravenous injections of diamorphine in a crossover design, with a two-week washout period between each administration route. The results showed that subcutaneous administration resulted in significantly reduced local toxicity compared to intravenous administration, as indicated by lower rates of abscess formation, thrombophlebitis, and tissue necrosis. These preliminary findings suggest that subcutaneous diamorphine delivery may offer a safer alternative to intravenous administration in individuals with opioid dependence. Further studies are warranted to confirm these results and explore the potential benefits in a larger population.

Progression of stage T1 bladder tumors after intravesical bacillus Calmette-Guerin [published erratum appears in J Urol 1991 Apr;145(4):840] Of 221 patients with superficial bladder tumors (stages Ta, Tis and T1) treated by transurethral resection and an initial 6-week course of intravesical bacillus Calmette-Guerin (BCG) 195 were evaluated after 3 months for local response. Intravesical bacillus Calmette-Guerin (BCG) is a common treatment for patients with superficial bladder tumors. However, some patients experience progression of their tumors despite this therapy. In this study, we evaluated 221 patients with stage T1 bladder tumors who underwent transurethral resection and received an initial 6-week course of intravesical BCG. After 3 months, 195 patients were evaluated for local response. Unfortunately, we found that despite treatment with BCG, there was progression of the tumors in some patients. This highlights the need for further investigation into alternative treatment options for patients with superficial bladder tumors who do not respond to intravesical BCG.

Indwelling epidural catheters for pain control in gynecologic cancer patients. Indwelling epidural catheters have been widely used for pain control in various surgical procedures, but their utilization in gynecologic cancer patients remains limited. This study aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of indwelling epidural catheters for postoperative pain control in this specific patient population. A retrospective analysis was conducted on gynecologic cancer patients who received indwelling epidural catheters for pain management following surgery. The primary outcome measures included pain scores, analgesic consumption, and side effects related to the epidural catheter. Secondary outcome measures included patient satisfaction and overall postoperative recovery. The results demonstrated that indwelling epidural catheters effectively controlled postoperative pain in gynecologic cancer patients, as evidenced by significantly lower pain scores and reduced analgesic consumption. Few adverse events related to the catheter were reported, indicating the safety of this technique. Patient satisfaction was high, and postoperative recovery was generally favorable. Therefore, indwelling epidural catheters can be considered a feasible option for pain management in gynecologic cancer patients undergoing surgery. Further prospective studies are warranted to validate these findings.

Outpatient laparoscopic laser cholecystectomy. Laparoscopic cholecystectomy is a well-established procedure for the treatment of gallbladder disease. However, concerns regarding postoperative pain and length of hospital stay have led to the development of outpatient laparoscopic cholecystectomy. This study aimed to evaluate the feasibility and safety of this approach using laser technology. A total of 100 patients with symptomatic cholelithiasis were enrolled, and all underwent laparoscopic cholecystectomy as outpatients. The surgical procedure was successfully completed in all cases, with a mean operative time of 65 minutes. Postoperative pain was adequately managed with oral analgesics, and no major complications were encountered. The average length of hospital stay was less than 24 hours. These findings demonstrate that outpatient laparoscopic laser cholecystectomy can be safely and effectively performed, reducing the need for hospitalization and potentially improving patient satisfaction.

Marijuana smoking as a possible cause of tongue carcinoma in young patients. Marijuana smoking has been suggested as a potential risk factor for the development of various malignancies. However, the association between marijuana smoking and tongue carcinoma in young patients has not been extensively explored. This paper presents two cases of tongue carcinoma in young individuals with a history of chronic marijuana smoking. Both patients exhibited similar clinical presentations, including a painful tongue lesion and difficulty in swallowing. Histopathological examination confirmed the diagnosis of squamous cell carcinoma in both cases. The authors discuss the potential mechanisms by which marijuana smoking could contribute to the development of tongue carcinoma, including the direct carcinogenic effect of marijuana smoke and its role in immune suppression. Further research is needed to establish a definitive link between marijuana smoking and tongue carcinoma in young patients and to determine appropriate preventive measures.

Use of activated charcoal to reduce elevated serum phenobarbital concentration in a neonate.  The course of a neonate administered activated charcoal orally for elevated phenobarbital concentration is described. Phenobarbital is a commonly used anticonvulsant medication in neonates, but its therapeutic window is narrow, and overdose can lead to respiratory depression and central nervous system depression. This case report describes the successful use of activated charcoal to reduce an elevated serum phenobarbital concentration in a neonate. The neonate presented with lethargy and respiratory depression after accidental ingestion of a high dose of phenobarbital. Activated charcoal was administered orally within one hour of ingestion, resulting in a significant reduction in serum phenobarbital concentration within 24 hours. The neonate's symptoms resolved, and no adverse effects associated with activated charcoal were observed. This case demonstrates the effectiveness and safety of activated charcoal in reducing phenobarbital overdose in neonates and highlights the importance of timely intervention in managing drug toxicity in this population. Further studies are warranted to establish standardized guidelines for the use of activated charcoal in neonatal drug overdose.

Infrarenal abdominal aortic disease: a review of the retroperitoneal approach. The retroperitoneal approach has gained recognition as an alternative surgical technique for infrarenal abdominal aortic disease. This review aims to provide an overview of the retroperitoneal approach in the management of aortic pathologies. The advantages of this approach include direct access to the aorta, avoidance of intraperitoneal structures, and reduced risk of bowel complications. Additionally, the retroperitoneal approach offers better exposure of the proximal and distal aorta, allowing for precise anastomosis. Various surgical procedures using the retroperitoneal approach, such as open repair, endovascular repair, and hybrid techniques, are discussed. Overall, the retroperitoneal approach holds promise as an effective and safe option for the treatment of infrarenal abdominal aortic disease.

Prognosticating study for cervical myelopathy using evoked spinal cord potentials. Cervical myelopathy is a common cause of spinal cord dysfunction, characterized by compression of the spinal cord in the neck region. Diagnosis and prognosis for this condition are often challenging. Evoked spinal cord potentials (ESCPs) have been proposed as a potential tool to aid in prognostication. This review aims to evaluate the existing literature on the use of ESCPs in predicting outcomes in cervical myelopathy patients.

Multiple studies have demonstrated the utility of ESCPs in predicting the severity and progression of cervical myelopathy. Significant correlations have been found between ESCP parameters and clinical symptoms, such as motor and sensory deficits. Additionally, ESCPs have been shown to provide valuable information on the extent of spinal cord involvement and the presence of subclinical pathology.

However, the heterogeneity in study design, patient populations, and outcomes assessed limits the generalizability of these findings. Further large-scale, prospective studies are warranted to establish the clinical utility of ESCPs in predicting prognosis and guiding treatment decisions for cervical myelopathy patients.

Mammographic follow-up of low-suspicion lesions: compliance rate and diagnostic yield. The aim of this study was to evaluate the compliance rate and diagnostic yield of mammographic follow-up for low-suspicion lesions. A retrospective analysis of 500 patients who underwent mammographic follow-up for low-suspicion lesions was conducted. Compliance rate was calculated as the proportion of patients who attended the recommended follow-up examination within the specified time frame. Diagnostic yield was determined by the number of follow-up examinations that resulted in a change in diagnosis or the detection of a significant lesion. The overall compliance rate was found to be 80%, with higher rates observed in older patients and patients with a previous history of breast cancer. The diagnostic yield was 12%, indicating that a small but significant number of lesions were identified or reclassified during follow-up. These findings highlight the importance of regular mammographic follow-up for low-suspicion lesions in order to detect potential malignancies and ensure timely intervention.

An analysis of abnormalities of the retinoblastoma gene in human ovarian and endometrial carcinoma. The retinoblastoma gene (RB1) plays a crucial role in regulating cell cycle progression and suppressing tumor growth. Mutations in this gene have been implicated in the development and progression of various types of cancers, including ovarian and endometrial carcinoma. In this study, we aimed to analyze the presence of abnormalities in the RB1 gene in ovarian and endometrial carcinoma samples. 

Tissue samples from 100 patients diagnosed with ovarian carcinoma and 80 patients diagnosed with endometrial carcinoma were collected and analyzed. DNA extraction was performed, followed by polymerase chain reaction (PCR) amplification of the RB1 gene exons. Sanger sequencing was then utilized to identify any mutations or genetic alterations in the gene.

Our results revealed that 28% of ovarian carcinoma samples and 35% of endometrial carcinoma samples exhibited abnormalities in the RB1 gene. These abnormalities included point mutations, deletions, and insertions. Additionally, a high frequency of loss of heterozygosity at the RB1 locus was observed.

Overall, our findings highlight the significance of RB1 gene abnormalities in ovarian and endometrial carcinoma, suggesting their potential as diagnostic and prognostic markers in these malignancies. Further investigations are warranted to elucidate the molecular mechanisms underlying RB1 dysfunction and its implications in tumor progression and therapeutic resistance in these gynecologic cancers.

Adenocarcinoma arising in Barrett's esophagus after total gastrectomy A 64-yr-old Japanese male who underwent a partial gastrectomy for a duodenal ulcer at the age of 21, a total resection of the remnant stomach for a stomal ulcer at age 25, and in whom Barrett's esophagus was diagnosed at age 47, was found to have a tumor at the distal esophagus and was operated on by thoracic esophagectomy. A 64-year-old Japanese male with a history of partial gastrectomy, total resection of the remnant stomach, and Barrett's esophagus presented with a distal esophageal tumor. He underwent thoracic esophagectomy for tumor resection.

Chronic diarrhea in essential mixed cryoglobulinemia: a manifestation of visceral vasculitis? Gastrointestinal involvement occurs frequently in essential mixed cryoglobulinemia, and most often involves the liver and spleen. Chronic diarrhea has been observed as a possible manifestation of visceral vasculitis in patients with essential mixed cryoglobulinemia. This condition commonly affects the liver and spleen, leading to gastrointestinal involvement. The pathogenesis, clinical presentation, and treatment options for chronic diarrhea in essential mixed cryoglobulinemia have been explored. Various diagnostic methods, including laboratory tests and imaging studies, have been utilized to confirm the association between chronic diarrhea and visceral vasculitis. Treatment modalities, such as immunosuppressive therapy, have shown promising results in alleviating gastrointestinal symptoms and improving overall patient outcomes. Further research is needed to better understand the underlying mechanisms of chronic diarrhea in essential mixed cryoglobulinemia and develop targeted interventions for this manifestation of the disease.

Fatigue failure of noncemented porous-coated implants. Noncemented porous-coated implants have gained popularity in the field of orthopedic surgery. However, concerns have been raised regarding their long-term performance and fatigue resistance. The present study aims to investigate the fatigue failure of noncemented porous-coated implants through mechanical testing and failure analysis. A total of 50 explanted implants were retrieved from patients who underwent revision surgery due to implant failure. These implants were subjected to fatigue loading in a biomechanical testing system, and the failure modes and locations were analyzed. The results reveal that fatigue failure in noncemented porous-coated implants commonly occurs at the bone-implant interface and is often associated with damage to the coating layer. Understanding the mechanisms of fatigue failure in these implants can aid in improving their design and enhancing their longevity in clinical applications.

Microscopic pulmonary tumor embolism causing subacute cor pulmonale: a difficult antemortem diagnosis [published erratum appears in Mayo Clin Proc 1991 Apr;66(4):439] Microscopic pulmonary tumor embolism is difficult to diagnose. Microscopic pulmonary tumor embolism is a rare and challenging diagnosis to make before death. This case report highlights the difficulties in its antemortem diagnosis, as well as its association with subacute cor pulmonale. 

The patient presented with dyspnea, pleuritic chest pain, and hemoptysis. Despite extensive investigations, including computed tomography (CT) scans, transthoracic echocardiography, and laboratory tests, the cause of the patient's symptoms remained elusive. Autopsy findings revealed multiple small tumor emboli within the pulmonary microvasculature. 

Microscopic pulmonary tumor embolism can mimic other more common conditions such as pulmonary embolism or infectious pneumonia. It may present with non-specific symptoms, making it challenging to diagnose. Physicians should maintain a high index of suspicion for this condition, especially in patients with known malignancies or unexplained respiratory symptoms. Early recognition and diagnosis are crucial for appropriate management and potentially improving patient outcomes.  Overall, this case highlights the importance of considering microscopic pulmonary tumor embolism as a differential diagnosis in patients with unexplained respiratory symptoms.

Heart weights of white men 20 to 39 years of age.  An analysis of 218 autopsy cases. An analysis of 218 autopsy cases of white men aged 20 to 39 years was conducted to determine heart weights and their correlation with age and body weight. The mean heart weight in this population was found to be 368 grams, with a standard deviation of 52 grams. There was a significant positive correlation between heart weight and body weight (r=0.63, p<0.001). However, no significant correlation was found between heart weight and age (r=0.07, p=0.270). Subgroup analysis revealed that individuals with cardiovascular diseases had significantly higher heart weights compared to those without cardiovascular diseases (p=0.002). These findings suggest that heart weight is mainly influenced by body weight rather than age in this population, and cardiovascular diseases may contribute to the increase in heart weight. Further research is needed to explore other factors that may influence heart weight in this population.

Air in the fissure for the ligamentum teres: new sign of intraperitoneal air on plain radiographs. Intraperitoneal air is often an important radiographic finding associated with various abdominal pathologies. The detection of intraperitoneal air is typically achieved through advanced imaging modalities such as computed tomography (CT) scans or ultrasound. Here, we present a new sign of intraperitoneal air on plain radiographs, specifically in the form of air in the fissure for the ligamentum teres. 

A retrospective analysis was conducted on 50 patients presenting with acute abdominal pain and undergoing both plain radiographs and CT scans. In 10 patients, air in the fissure for the ligamentum teres was identified on plain radiographs, and subsequent CT scans confirmed the presence of intraperitoneal air. This new sign was found to be reliable in identifying intraperitoneal air, with a sensitivity of 80% and a specificity of 95%. 

Recognition of this new sign on plain radiographs can provide valuable information for the prompt identification and management of patients with potential intraperitoneal pathology, avoiding the need for additional imaging modalities.

99mTc HM-PAO SPECT in pediatric migraine. Pediatric migraine is a common and debilitating condition, often associated with significant functional impairment. Accurate diagnosis is crucial for appropriate management and treatment. This study aims to evaluate the role of 99mTc HM-PAO SPECT in pediatric migraine patients. Twenty-eight children with a clinical diagnosis of migraine were recruited for this study. All participants underwent 99mTc HM-PAO SPECT imaging during a migraine attack and a headache-free period. The SPECT images were then analyzed and compared between the two groups. The results showed significantly increased regional cerebral blood flow (rCBF) in regions including the thalamus, temporal cortex, and basal ganglia during a migraine attack compared to the headache-free period. These findings suggest that 99mTc HM-PAO SPECT imaging can provide valuable information about the pathophysiology of pediatric migraine and may serve as a useful tool in the diagnosis and management of this condition.

A T-cell neoplasia showing clinicopathologic features of malignant histiocytosis with novel chromosomal abnormalities and N-ras mutation.  Malignant histiocytosis (MH) is a distinct disease entity defined clinically and morphologically. We report a case of T-cell neoplasia showing clinicopathologic features of malignant histiocytosis (MH) with novel chromosomal abnormalities and an N-ras mutation. The patient, a 56-year-old male, presented with generalized lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly, and peripheral blood involvement by atypical histiocytes. Histologic examination of lymph nodes and bone marrow revealed an infiltrate composed of cells displaying histiocytic and T-cell immunophenotypes. Immunohistochemical and molecular studies confirmed the presence of both histiocytic and T-cell markers. Chromosomal analysis revealed complex karyotypic abnormalities, including numerical and structural changes. Additionally, sequencing analysis identified an N-ras mutation, which has not previously been reported in MH. The patient was treated with combination chemotherapy and achieved a partial response. This case highlights the importance of recognizing the diverse clinical and molecular characteristics of MH, as well as the potential role of N-ras mutations in its pathogenesis. Further studies are needed to elucidate the role of these chromosomal abnormalities and mutations in the development and progression of MH.

The effect of metoclopramide on ovarian responsiveness to gonadotropin administration in patients with severe polycystic ovarian syndrome. Polycystic Ovarian Syndrome (PCOS) is a common endocrine disorder associated with various reproductive and metabolic abnormalities. The aim of this study was to evaluate the effect of metoclopramide on ovarian responsiveness to gonadotropin administration in patients with severe PCOS. A total of 50 patients diagnosed with severe PCOS were randomly assigned into two groups: group A received metoclopramide in addition to gonadotropin therapy, while group B received only gonadotropin therapy. Ovarian responsiveness was evaluated by measuring the number of mature follicles, serum estradiol levels, and pregnancy rates. The results showed that the addition of metoclopramide to gonadotropin therapy significantly increased the number of mature follicles and serum estradiol levels compared to the gonadotropin therapy alone group. Furthermore, the pregnancy rates were significantly higher in the metoclopramide group. These findings suggest that metoclopramide improves ovarian responsiveness in patients with severe PCOS, thereby enhancing their chances of successful ovulation induction and pregnancy outcomes.

Treating systemic fungal infections in AIDS patients. Systemic fungal infections are a significant cause of morbidity and mortality in AIDS patients. This study aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of different antifungal treatments in this population. A total of 256 AIDS patients with systemic fungal infections were enrolled and randomly assigned to receive either amphotericin B or fluconazole. The primary outcome measures included mortality rate, clinical response, and adverse events. Results showed that both treatments were effective in reducing mortality rates, with no significant difference between the two groups. However, amphotericin B was associated with a higher incidence of adverse events compared to fluconazole. Furthermore, patients with more severe immunosuppression and higher fungal burden showed poorer treatment responses. In conclusion, both amphotericin B and fluconazole are effective antifungal treatments for systemic infections in AIDS patients, although the choice of treatment should be individualized based on patient characteristics and risk-benefit analysis.

Is emotional disturbance a precipitator or a consequence of chronic pain? The present study examined the relationship between psychological factors and pain in order to assess the contribution of emotional disturbance to the perpetuation of pain. This study aimed to investigate the association between emotional disturbance and chronic pain, specifically examining whether emotional disturbance acts as a precipitator or a consequence of pain. A comprehensive assessment of psychological factors and pain was conducted to determine the influence of emotional disturbance on pain perpetuation. The study included a sample of individuals experiencing chronic pain, and their psychological well-being was evaluated using standardized measures. The results revealed a significant relationship between emotional disturbance and pain, suggesting that emotional disturbance may contribute to the perpetuation of pain. However, the directionality of this association could not be definitively determined. Further research is needed to explore the temporal relationships between emotional disturbance and chronic pain, as well as the underlying mechanisms involved. Understanding this relationship could provide valuable insights for the development of effective interventions targeting both emotional and physical aspects of chronic pain management.

Decision criteria for pure-tone detection used by two age groups of normal-hearing and hearing-impaired listeners. The study aimed to investigate the decision criteria for pure-tone detection in two age groups: normal-hearing and hearing-impaired listeners. A total of 50 participants were divided into two groups, with 25 participants each (age range: 18-30 years and 60-70 years). Pure-tone thresholds were measured using an audiometer for various frequencies. Results revealed that both age groups exhibited similar decision criteria, prioritizing sensitivity over specificity. However, the hearing-impaired group showed significantly lower detection thresholds compared to the normal-hearing group. These findings suggest that decision criteria for pure-tone detection may be influenced by hearing impairment, potentially impacting the accuracy of auditory assessments and necessitating tailored interventions for effective management of hearing loss.

Analysis of alterations in the retinoblastoma gene and tumor grade in bone and soft-tissue sarcomas. This study aimed to investigate the correlation between alterations in the retinoblastoma (RB) gene and tumor grade in bone and soft-tissue sarcomas. The RB gene is a known tumor suppressor gene involved in cell cycle regulation and has been implicated in various cancers. The tumor grade is an important prognostic factor that reflects the aggressiveness of the tumor. 

A retrospective analysis of 100 cases of bone and soft-tissue sarcomas was conducted. Tumor specimens were evaluated for RB gene alterations using molecular techniques such as polymerase chain reaction and sequencing. The tumor grade was determined based on histopathological examination.

The results showed that RB gene alterations were significantly associated with high-grade tumors. Specifically, mutations and deletions in the RB gene were more frequently observed in high-grade sarcomas compared to low-grade sarcomas. This finding suggests a potential role for RB gene alterations in the progression and aggressiveness of bone and soft-tissue sarcomas.

Further studies are warranted to elucidate the underlying mechanisms by which RB gene alterations contribute to tumor grade and to evaluate their potential as prognostic markers or therapeutic targets in bone and soft-tissue sarcomas.

Pineal hyperactivity in spontaneously hypertensive rats: muscarinic regulation of indole metabolism.  1. The study investigated the role of muscarinic regulation of indole metabolism in pineal hyperactivity in spontaneously hypertensive rats (SHR). Rats were divided into two groups: SHR and normotensive control rats (WKY). Pineal glands were isolated and incubated with carbachol, a muscarinic receptor agonist. The results showed that carbachol significantly increased indole metabolism in the SHR group compared to the WKY group. This increased indole metabolism was mediated by increased activity of tryptophan hydroxylase and decreased activity of indoleamine 2,3-dioxygenase in SHR rats. Additionally, muscarinic receptor blockade using atropine effectively attenuated the increased indole metabolism in the SHR group. These findings suggest that muscarinic regulation plays a role in the abnormal indole metabolism observed in pineal glands of SHR rats, which may contribute to pineal hyperactivity in hypertension. Further studies are needed to fully understand the underlying mechanisms and potential therapeutic implications.

Anton's syndrome in a patient with posttraumatic optic neuropathy and bifrontal contusions. Anton's syndrome, a rare condition characterized by denial of visual loss despite objective evidence of visual deficits, is typically associated with bilateral occipital lobe damage. We describe a case of Anton's syndrome in a patient with posttraumatic optic neuropathy and bifrontal contusions. A 42-year-old male presented with bilateral visual loss following a motor vehicle accident. Examination revealed optic disc pallor and visual field defects consistent with optic neuropathy. Neuroimaging demonstrated bilateral frontal contusions and diffuse axonal injury. Despite evidence of severe visual impairment, the patient adamantly denied any visual deficits and confidently performed visually guided tasks. This case highlights the dissociation between objective visual deficits and subjective perception in Anton's syndrome. It also underscores the importance of assessing the integrity of higher-order visual processing centers, such as the occipital lobes, in patients with apparent visual denial following traumatic brain injury.

Oral squamous cell carcinoma arising in a patient with long-standing lichen planus. We report a case of oral squamous cell carcinoma (OSCC) in a patient with a long-standing history of lichen planus (LP). LP is an immune-mediated inflammatory disorder that affects the mucous membranes, skin, and nails. It is known to have an increased risk of malignant transformation, particularly in the oral cavity. The patient, a 65-year-old male, presented with a non-healing ulcer in the buccal mucosa. Histopathological examination revealed features consistent with OSCC. The presence of LP in the adjacent tissue suggests a potential association between LP and OSCC development. This case highlights the importance of regular surveillance and prompt evaluation of any suspicious lesions in patients with LP.

Pneumococcal anticapsular antibodies in patients with chronic cardiovascular and obstructive lung disease in The Netherlands. The objective of this study was to determine the levels of pneumococcal anticapsular antibodies in patients with chronic cardiovascular and obstructive lung disease in The Netherlands. A total of 120 patients were enrolled in the study, including 60 patients with chronic cardiovascular disease and 60 patients with obstructive lung disease. Blood samples were collected from all patients and tested for levels of pneumococcal anticapsular antibodies using enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA). The results showed that patients with obstructive lung disease had significantly lower levels of pneumococcal anticapsular antibodies compared to patients with chronic cardiovascular disease (p < 0.05). Furthermore, within the obstructive lung disease group, patients with severe airflow limitation had lower levels of pneumococcal anticapsular antibodies compared to patients with mild to moderate airflow limitation (p < 0.05). These findings suggest that patients with obstructive lung disease, particularly those with severe airflow limitation, may be at increased risk for pneumococcal infections and may benefit from vaccination strategies targeting this pathogen. Further research is needed to explore the clinical implications of these findings and to develop tailored prevention strategies for this patient population.

Awareness during caesarean section.  Between 1982 and 1989 over 3000 patients were questioned about recall and dreaming after general anaesthesia for Caesarean section. During the period from 1982 to 1989, a total of over 3000 patients who underwent general anesthesia for Caesarean section were surveyed regarding their experiences with recall and dreaming. The study aimed to assess the incidence of awareness during the surgical procedure. The findings revealed that awareness occurred in 1 in 500 cases (0.2%). Out of the patients who reported being aware, 34% described experiencing pain, 2.6% reported distressing experiences, and 0.1% reported dreaming. The study concluded that although the incidence of awareness during Caesarean section under general anesthesia was relatively low, efforts should be made to minimize the occurrence and improve patient safety through increased awareness and implementation of appropriate anesthetic techniques.

Pancreatic ascites: treatment by continuous somatostatin infusion. Pancreatic ascites is a rare complication of chronic pancreatitis characterized by the accumulation of pancreatic secretions in the peritoneal cavity. Management of this condition requires a multidisciplinary approach and the use of various therapeutic modalities. We report a case of pancreatic ascites in a 55-year-old male with a history of chronic pancreatitis. The patient presented with abdominal distension, pain, and dyspnea. Diagnostic workup revealed a large amount of ascitic fluid with elevated amylase levels. Initial attempts at conservative management with total parenteral nutrition and octreotide were unsuccessful. Subsequently, the patient underwent continuous somatostatin infusion, resulting in a significant reduction in the volume of ascitic fluid and improvement in clinical symptoms. This case highlights the effectiveness of continuous somatostatin infusion as a therapeutic option for pancreatic ascites, and emphasizes the importance of considering this treatment modality in refractory cases. Further studies are needed to determine the optimal dosage and duration of therapy.

Colorectal adenocarcinoma in patients less than 40 years of age.  From 1973 to 1985, 105 patients under 40 years of age were treated for colorectal adenocarcinoma at Roswell Park Cancer Institute. Colorectal adenocarcinoma is typically considered a disease of older individuals; however, there is a subset of patients who are diagnosed at a younger age. This study aimed to analyze the clinical characteristics and outcomes of colorectal adenocarcinoma in patients under 40 years of age.

Data from 105 patients treated at Roswell Park Cancer Institute between 1973 and 1985 were retrospectively analyzed. The majority of patients were symptomatic at presentation, with abdominal pain and rectal bleeding being the most common symptoms. Histological analysis revealed well-differentiated adenocarcinoma as the predominant subtype.

Despite the relatively young age of the patients, the prognosis was poor, with a 5-year survival rate of only 36%. Advanced stage at diagnosis and lymph node involvement were significant predictors of poor outcomes.

This study highlights the importance of considering colorectal adenocarcinoma in young patients presenting with suggestive symptoms. Early detection and management strategies tailored to this age group may improve outcomes.

Periventricular hyperintensity detected by magnetic resonance imaging in infancy.  Twenty-one infants younger than 12 months of age were diagnosed as having periventricular hyperintensity (PVH) on T2-weighted magnetic resonance imaging. All infants underwent imaging due to abnormal neurological findings or other clinical concerns. The most common presenting symptom was developmental delay, followed by seizures and abnormal muscle tone. The PVH was predominantly bilateral and located adjacent to the lateral ventricles. Additional abnormalities seen on imaging included periventricular white matter changes, ventriculomegaly, and diffuse cortical atrophy. The etiology of PVH was varied and included hypoxic-ischemic injury, infection, genetic abnormalities, and metabolic disorders. The majority of infants had unfavorable outcomes, with neurodevelopmental delay, cerebral palsy, and epilepsy being the most common sequelae. Follow-up imaging showed stability or progression of PVH in most cases. These findings emphasize the importance of early recognition and diagnostic work-up for infants with PVH to guide appropriate management and anticipate long-term neurodevelopmental outcomes.

Malignant melanoma of the biliary tract: a case report.  A 58-year-old man was seen with obstructive jaundice and discomfort in the upper abdomen. Malignant melanoma is a rare malignancy that commonly arises from the skin. However, its occurrence in the biliary tract is extremely rare and only a few cases have been reported. We present the case of a 58-year-old man who presented with obstructive jaundice and upper abdominal discomfort. Imaging studies revealed a mass in the common bile duct. A Whipple procedure was performed to resect the mass, and histopathological examination confirmed the diagnosis of malignant melanoma. Further investigations ruled out primary cutaneous melanoma or metastatic disease from other sites. The patient underwent adjuvant chemotherapy and was followed up for 10 months without evidence of recurrent disease. This case highlights the importance of considering malignant melanoma as a differential diagnosis in patients with biliary tract masses, even in the absence of a primary cutaneous lesion.

Extensive peripheral retinectomy combined with posterior 360 degrees retinotomy for retinal reattachment in advanced proliferative vitreoretinopathy cases. Advanced proliferative vitreoretinopathy (PVR) is a challenging condition to manage and often requires complex surgical interventions. This study aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of extensive peripheral retinectomy combined with posterior 360 degrees retinotomy for retinal reattachment in PVR cases. A retrospective analysis of 32 eyes from 28 patients who underwent this surgical technique was performed. The primary outcome measures included retinal reattachment rate, visual acuity improvement, and surgical complications. The results showed a retinal reattachment rate of 90.6% and a significant improvement in visual acuity in the majority of cases. Additionally, the surgical complications were minimal and manageable. This technique proves to be a valuable option for managing advanced PVR cases.

Post-traumatic bile fistulae.  Bile leakage after liver injury has been reported to be a complication associated with significant mortality. Bile fistulae resulting from liver injury are a rare but serious complication that can lead to significant morbidity and mortality. This study aims to evaluate the incidence of post-traumatic bile fistulae and analyze its associated risk factors and outcomes. A retrospective analysis was conducted on patients who presented with liver injury and subsequently developed a bile fistula. Clinical and radiological data, as well as operative reports, were reviewed to determine the etiology, time to presentation, and management strategies employed. Out of the total cohort, 24 patients were identified with post-traumatic bile fistulae.
