However, other therapies such as glycoprotein IIb/IIIa inhibitors showed promising results in terms of improved myocardial reperfusion and reduced major adverse cardiac events. Further research is needed to identify the most effective adjunctive therapies in coronary thrombolysis.

Chronic posterior subluxation and dislocation of the radial head. Chronic posterior subluxation and dislocation of the radial head is a rare condition characterized by the displacement of the radius bone in the elbow joint. This study presents a case series of 15 patients with chronic posterior subluxation and dislocation of the radial head, who were treated at a tertiary care hospital. The clinical and radiological findings, as well as the management and outcomes of these patients, were analyzed. The majority of patients presented with chronic elbow pain and limited range of motion. Radiographic evaluation revealed posterior displacement of the radial head. Surgical intervention was performed in all patients, including open reduction and internal fixation or radial head excision. Overall, satisfactory outcomes were achieved, with improvements in pain, range of motion, and functional status. This study highlights the importance of early recognition and appropriate management of chronic posterior subluxation and dislocation of the radial head.

Combined tensor fasciae latae musculocutaneous flap and sartorius musculocutaneous flap for the repair of wide defects of the lower leg. Wide defects of the lower leg can be challenging to repair due to the lack of sufficient soft tissue coverage. This study evaluates the efficacy of a combined tensor fasciae latae musculocutaneous flap and sartorius musculocutaneous flap for the reconstruction of such defects. A retrospective analysis was conducted on 25 patients who underwent this combined flap procedure between 2010 and 2018. The flaps provided reliable coverage for defects ranging from 6 cm to 20 cm in width. Complications such as flap necrosis and wound infection were observed in a small percentage of cases. Overall, the combined flap technique demonstrated good outcomes in terms of flap survival and wound healing. This approach offers a viable option for the repair of wide defects of the lower leg, providing satisfactory functional and aesthetic results.

Hepatocellular carcinoma with tumor thrombus extending into the right atrium: report of a successful resection with the use of cardiopulmonary bypass. Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) is the most common primary liver malignancy and often presents as an advanced stage disease. Tumor thrombus extending into the right atrium is a rare but aggressive form of HCC with poor prognosis. We report a case of successful resection of HCC with tumor thrombus using cardiopulmonary bypass (CPB). A 57-year-old male presented with symptoms of right upper quadrant pain and was diagnosed with HCC with tumor thrombus extending into the right atrium. Due to the extent of the tumor thrombus, surgical resection was considered high risk. The use of CPB allowed for complete resection of the tumor thrombus and the primary liver lesion. The patient had an uneventful postoperative course and remained recurrence-free at 18 months follow-up. Our case highlights the importance of a multidisciplinary approach in the management of advanced HCC and demonstrates the potential benefits of using CPB in selected cases with tumor thrombus extending into the right atrium.

Clinical results of femoropopliteal bypass using externally supported (EXS) Dacron grafts: with a comparison of above- and below-knee anastomosis.  As of the end of September 1989, 52 EXS Dacron grafts had been implanted for femoropopliteal bypass operations. The aim of this study was to evaluate the clinical outcomes of femoropopliteal bypass using externally supported (EXS) Dacron grafts and compare the outcomes of above-knee (AK) and below-knee (BK) anastomosis. A total of 52 patients underwent femoropopliteal bypass with EXS Dacron grafts between January 1988 and September 1989. The primary patency rate at 12 months was 76.9% for AK anastomosis and 77.8% for BK anastomosis. The secondary patency rate at 12 months was 87.1% for AK anastomosis and 92.3% for BK anastomosis. Limb salvage rates at 12 months were 92.3% for AK anastomosis and 94.4% for BK anastomosis. These results suggest that both AK and BK anastomosis techniques using EXS Dacron grafts have favorable clinical outcomes in femoropopliteal bypass operations.

DNA analysis of multiple synchronous renal cell carcinomas.  The authors used retrospective quantitative DNA analysis to study interrelationships between multiple synchronous renal cell carcinomas in seven patients. The authors aimed to study the genetic relationships and clonal origins of multiple synchronous renal cell carcinomas (RCC) in seven patients using retrospective quantitative DNA analysis. Tumor samples were obtained from multiple lesions in each patient and subjected to DNA ploidy analysis. Additionally, comparative genomic hybridization (CGH) was performed on selected cases to identify chromosomal aberrations. 

The results showed that all patients had two or more RCCs, with a total of 32 tumors analyzed. The majority of cases (71%) exhibited concordant DNA ploidy patterns, indicating a clonal origin. CGH analysis revealed recurrent chromosomal aberrations, including gains of 5q, 7q, and losses of 9p, 14q, 17p, and 22q. Interestingly, one patient showed distinct DNA ploidy patterns in different tumors, suggesting independent origins. 

In conclusion, this study demonstrates the clonal relationship between multiple synchronous RCCs in most cases, supporting the theory of intrarenal spread or multicentric development. Further understanding of the genetic alterations involved may have implications for diagnosis, prognosis, and targeted therapies in these patients.

Removal of radiation-induced cataracts in patients treated for retinoblastoma.  Experience with removal of radiation-induced cataract in patients treated for retinoblastoma is limited. We report our experience in removing radiation-induced cataracts in patients previously treated for retinoblastoma. Ten patients (five males, five females) with a mean age of 12 years (range 5-18 years) were included in the study. All patients had received external beam radiation therapy for the treatment of retinoblastoma at a mean dose of 40 Gy (range 30-50 Gy). Cataract extraction surgery was performed using phacoemulsification and intraocular lens implantation. Visual acuity improved in all patients after surgery, with a mean postoperative visual acuity of 20/30 (range 20/20 - 20/40). No intraoperative complications were observed, and all patients had clear corneas and stable intraocular pressure postoperatively. Our results suggest that cataract surgery is a safe and effective treatment option for radiation-induced cataracts in patients treated for retinoblastoma. Further studies with larger patient cohorts are warranted to confirm these findings.

Granular cell tumor of the esophagus: endoscopic ultrasonographic demonstration and endoscopic removal. Granular cell tumors (GCTs) of the esophagus are rare and benign neoplasms. We present a case of a 45-year-old female who presented with dysphagia and was found to have a submucosal mass in the middle third of the esophagus on endoscopy. Endoscopic ultrasound (EUS) demonstrated a hypoechoic lesion arising from the muscularis propria. The lesion was successfully removed using endoscopic submucosal dissection (ESD) technique. Histopathological examination confirmed the diagnosis of a granular cell tumor. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first reported case of an esophageal GCT managed with ESD. EUS is helpful in diagnosing and localizing these lesions, and ESD can be a safe and effective treatment modality in selected cases.

Islet cell carcinoma of the pancreas presenting as bleeding from isolated gastric varices.  Report of a case and review of the literature. A case of islet cell carcinoma of the pancreas presenting with bleeding from isolated gastric varices is reported. A 57-year-old male presented with hematemesis and melena. Upper endoscopy revealed isolated gastric varices as the source of bleeding. Contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CT) scan of the abdomen showed a 3 cm mass in the head of the pancreas with liver metastasis. Endoscopic ultrasound-guided fine-needle aspiration confirmed the diagnosis of islet cell carcinoma. The patient underwent distal pancreatectomy and splenectomy, and liver metastases were treated with transarterial chemoembolization. This case highlights the importance of considering islet cell carcinoma as a potential cause of bleeding from gastric varices, and the role of multimodal treatment including surgery and targeted therapy in the management of this malignancy.

Periventricular hyperintensity detected by magnetic resonance imaging in infancy.  Twenty-one infants younger than 12 months of age were diagnosed as having periventricular hyperintensity (PVH) on T2-weighted magnetic resonance imaging. The aim of this study was to assess the clinical characteristics and outcomes of infants with periventricular hyperintensity detected by magnetic resonance imaging (MRI). Demographic and clinical data were collected for each patient, including age at MRI, presence of neurological symptoms, and neurodevelopmental outcomes. Follow-up imaging was performed to evaluate the progression of PVH. The majority of infants (81%) presented with neurological symptoms, most commonly hypotonia and developmental delay. Follow-up imaging showed stable or improved PVH in 76% of cases. Neurodevelopmental outcomes at follow-up were variable, with 38% having normal development, 29% having mild to moderate disability, and 33% having severe disability. These findings suggest that periventricular hyperintensity detected by MRI in infancy is associated with a range of neurodevelopmental outcomes. Further research is needed to determine the underlying cause and optimal management strategies for infants with PVH.

Cytologic diagnosis of aspergillosis in cardiac transplantation. This study presents three cases of cardiac transplant recipients with cytologic diagnosis of aspergillosis. All patients presented with fever, pleural effusion, and pulmonary infiltrates. Fine needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) was performed on the pleural fluid and lung nodules. Cytologic examination revealed septate hyphae with acute angle branching, characteristic of Aspergillus species. Subsequent fungal cultures also confirmed the presence of Aspergillus. Antifungal therapy was initiated, resulting in clinical improvement in all cases. Cytologic examination of pleural effusion and lung nodules can be a rapid and reliable method for diagnosing Aspergillus infection in cardiac transplant recipients, allowing for timely initiation of appropriate treatment. Early detection and treatment are crucial in preventing further morbidity and mortality in this immunocompromised patient population.

Genotypic analyses of Richter's syndrome. Richter's syndrome is a rare condition characterized by the transformation of chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) into an aggressive lymphoma, most commonly diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL). Limited information is available on the genotypic alterations associated with Richter's syndrome. In this study, we performed targeted next-generation sequencing to investigate the genetic landscape of Richter's syndrome in 20 patients. We observed a high frequency of alterations in genes involved in cell cycle regulation, B-cell receptor signaling, and DNA damage response pathways. Notably, we identified recurrent mutations in TP53, MYD88, and CDKN2A genes. Copy number alterations affecting known tumor suppressor genes were also detected. Our findings provide insight into the genetic basis of Richter's syndrome, highlighting potential therapeutic targets and prognostic markers for this aggressive malignancy.

On the inheritance of abdominal aortic aneurysm. Abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) is a common vascular disease with a high mortality rate. The underlying genetic factors contributing to the inheritance of AAA have been extensively studied. This review aims to summarize the current knowledge on the inheritance of AAA, including the identification of genetic variants and their functional implications. Several genes, such as the angiotensin-converting enzyme gene and the 9p21 locus, have been associated with an increased risk of developing AAA. Additionally, genetic and environmental factors interact to influence the disease progression and rupture risk. Understanding the inheritance patterns of AAA is crucial for identifying individuals at high risk and developing targeted screening and prevention strategies to reduce the burden of this life-threatening condition.

Genotypic analyses of Richter's syndrome. Richter's syndrome is a rare and aggressive transformation of chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) into diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL). The genetic basis and underlying molecular mechanisms of Richter's syndrome have not been fully elucidated. In this study, the authors performed genotypic analyses on a cohort of Richter's syndrome cases to further understand the genetic alterations associated with this transformation. Through whole-exome sequencing and copy number variation analysis, they identified key genetic alterations, including mutations in genes involved in cell cycle regulation, chromatin remodeling, and DNA damage response pathways. Additionally, they observed recurrent genomic amplifications and deletions, indicating the importance of these aberrations in Richter's syndrome development. These findings provide valuable insights into the genomic landscape of Richter's syndrome and may have implications for the development of targeted therapies for this aggressive disease.

Differentiation in embryonal neuroepithelial tumors of the central nervous system. Embryonal neuroepithelial tumors (ENTs) of the central nervous system (CNS) are a heterogeneous group of tumors with varying histologic features and clinical outcomes. This study aimed to evaluate the differentiation patterns in ENTs and determine their correlation with prognosis. 

A retrospective analysis of 50 patients with ENTs was performed. Immunohistochemical staining was utilized to assess markers of neural and glial differentiation, including GFAP, synaptophysin, and neurofilament protein. The tumors were classified into three groups based on their differentiation patterns: neural differentiation, glial differentiation, and mixed differentiation. 

Results showed that 25% of the tumors exhibited neural differentiation, 30% displayed glial differentiation, and 45% showed mixed differentiation. The patients with tumors displaying neural differentiation had a significantly better prognosis compared to those with glial or mixed differentiation tumors. 

In conclusion, differentiation patterns in ENTs of the CNS have prognostic implications. Further research is warranted to identify molecular markers associated with specific differentiation patterns, which may have significant implications for targeted therapies and improved patient outcomes.

Gastrointestinal intraluminal pH in normal subjects and those with colorectal adenoma or carcinoma. The objective of this study was to evaluate the differences in gastrointestinal intraluminal pH between normal subjects and those with colorectal adenoma or carcinoma. A total of 100 participants were included, consisting of 50 individuals with colorectal adenoma or carcinoma and 50 normal subjects. Gastrointestinal intraluminal pH was measured using a pH electrode in the esophagus, stomach, duodenum, and colon. The results showed that individuals with colorectal adenoma or carcinoma had significantly lower pH levels in the esophagus, stomach, and colon compared to normal subjects (p < 0.05). However, no significant difference was found in duodenal pH between the two groups (p > 0.05). These findings suggest that alterations in gastrointestinal intraluminal pH may be associated with the development of colorectal adenoma and carcinoma. Further studies are needed to elucidate the underlying mechanisms and explore the potential clinical implications of these findings.

Stressful events and life satisfaction among elderly men and women.  The purpose of this study was to examine the interrelationships among stressful events, domain-specific assessments of life satisfaction, and global evaluations of life satisfaction. This study aimed to investigate the associations between stressful events and life satisfaction among elderly men and women. A sample of elderly individuals (n=300) aged 65 years and older were recruited for this cross-sectional study. The participants completed self-report measures assessing stressful events, domain-specific assessments of life satisfaction, and global evaluations of life satisfaction. The results indicated that stressful events were negatively associated with both domain-specific and global life satisfaction in both men and women. However, the strength of the association differed between the two genders, with women reporting a stronger negative impact of stressful events on life satisfaction compared to men. These findings suggest that stressful events may have a considerable influence on the overall well-being and satisfaction of elderly individuals, particularly among women. Further research is needed to explore potential mechanisms underlying these gender differences and develop interventions to mitigate the negative impact of stressful events on life satisfaction in older adults.

The natural history of left ventricular spontaneous contrast.  Spontaneous contrast in the left ventricle is an unusual entity. This study aimed to investigate the natural history of left ventricular spontaneous contrast (LVSC), an uncommon phenomenon characterized by the presence of echogenic material within the left ventricular cavity. A total of 50 patients with LVSC were included in the study, and their medical records were retrospectively analyzed. The mean age of the patients was 61 years, and the majority were male (70%). The etiology of LVSC varied, with the most common cause being ischemic heart disease (60%), followed by dilated cardiomyopathy (22%) and valvular heart disease (18%). Follow-up data was available for 40 patients, with a mean follow-up period of 3 years. During follow-up, 20% of patients experienced clinical events, including stroke, myocardial infarction, or death. The presence of LVSC was significantly associated with a higher risk of adverse events. In conclusion, LVSC is a rare finding that often occurs in the setting of underlying cardiovascular diseases. Its presence may indicate an increased risk of adverse events, warranting close monitoring and appropriate management.

A pitfall in azygos vein cannulation in cirrhotic patients: mistaken cannulation of the mammary vein. Azygos vein cannulation is a commonly performed procedure in cirrhotic patients, but it can be challenging due to the distorted anatomy and increased risk of complications. In this report, we present a case of mistaken cannulation of the mammary vein instead of the azygos vein during a planned azygos vein catheterization in a cirrhotic patient. The error was identified intraoperatively, and immediate measures were taken to correct the cannulation and prevent further complications. This case highlights the importance of careful anatomical identification and verification during azygos vein cannulation in cirrhotic patients, as well as the potential risks and consequences of misplaced cannulation. Clinicians should remain vigilant and employ proper techniques to avoid such pitfalls.

Argon versus krypton panretinal photocoagulation side effects on the anterior segment. Panretinal photocoagulation (PRP) is a widely used treatment for proliferative diabetic retinopathy and other ocular neovascular diseases. The choice of laser wavelength for PRP, however, can have potential side effects on the anterior segment of the eye. This study aimed to compare the side effects of argon and krypton laser PRP on the anterior segment in patients with diabetic retinopathy. A total of 50 eyes were included in the study, with 25 eyes receiving argon laser PRP and 25 eyes receiving krypton laser PRP. Side effects such as corneal endothelial cell density, intraocular pressure, and anterior segment inflammation were assessed at baseline and at multiple postoperative time points. The findings of this study provide valuable insights into the choice of laser wavelength for PRP in patients with diabetic retinopathy.

Neuro-imaging and positron emission tomography of congenital homonymous hemianopsia. Congenital homonymous hemianopsia is a visual field defect characterized by the loss of half of the visual field on the same side in both eyes. Neuro-imaging techniques, such as magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) and computed tomography (CT), have been used to identify structural abnormalities in the visual pathway that may be responsible for this condition. However, these imaging modalities have limited ability to assess functional changes in the visual cortex. Positron emission tomography (PET) is a nuclear imaging technique that allows for the measurement of regional cerebral blood flow and glucose metabolism, providing valuable information on the functional integrity of the visual cortex. This review summarizes the current literature on the use of PET in evaluating congenital homonymous hemianopsia and discusses its potential role in improving our understanding of the underlying neurobiological mechanisms and guiding therapeutic interventions for this condition.

Vector short-latency somatosensory-evoked potentials after median nerve stimulation. Short-latency somatosensory-evoked potentials (SSEPs) are neurophysiological measures commonly used to assess the integrity of the somatosensory pathways. This study aims to investigate the characteristics of vector short-latency SSEPs after median nerve stimulation in healthy individuals. A total of 50 subjects were included in the study, and SSEPs were recorded using surface electrodes. The results revealed consistent waveform patterns with identifiable components, including N20, P25, N35, and P45. Peak latency and peak-to-peak amplitude were measured for each component. The study also explored the effects of age and gender on SSEP characteristics. Notably, age was found to significantly influence P25 peak latency and N35-P45 amplitude, while no gender differences were observed. These findings contribute to our understanding of normative values and variations in vector short-latency SSEPs, which can aid in the clinical interpretation of SSEP recordings and facilitate the diagnosis and management of various neurological disorders.

Contracturing granulomatous myositis: a separate entity. Contracturing granulomatous myositis (CGM) is a rare inflammatory myopathy characterized by chronic granulomatous inflammation and progressive muscle contracture. This study aims to describe the clinical features, treatment course, and outcomes of patients with CGM. We retrospectively reviewed the medical records of 15 patients diagnosed with CGM between 2000 and 2020. All patients presented with muscle contractures, predominantly affecting the proximal muscles. Additionally, 10 patients had preceding skin involvement, while 8 patients had associated systemic symptoms. Immunohistochemical analysis of muscle biopsies showed granulomatous inflammation in all cases. Treatment approaches included glucocorticoids, immunosuppressants, and surgical interventions. Patient outcomes varied, with 7 patients experiencing progressive worsening despite treatment. Furthermore, 3 patients required surgical interventions for functional improvement. CGM is a distinct entity characterized by chronic granulomatous inflammation resulting in progressive muscle contracture. Treatment involves a multidisciplinary approach, including medical and surgical interventions. Further research is needed to better understand the pathogenesis and optimal treatment strategies for CGM.

Acinic cell carcinoma.  Clinicopathologic review. Acinic cell carcinoma (ACC) is a rare malignant neoplasm originating from the salivary glands, particularly the parotid gland. This study aimed to provide a comprehensive clinicopathologic review of ACC in order to enhance our understanding of its clinical presentation, histological features, treatment modalities, and prognostic factors. A retrospective analysis was conducted on a cohort of patients diagnosed with ACC at our institution between January 2000 and December 2019. Clinical and pathological data were collected, including demographic characteristics, presenting symptoms, tumor location, histological subtypes, tumor stage, treatment received, and patient outcomes. Our findings revealed a predilection for ACC in females, with the majority presenting in the fifth and sixth decades of life. The parotid gland was the most commonly affected site. Histologically, most cases demonstrated classic acinar architecture with a variable degree of perineural invasion. The treatment approach varied depending on the tumor stage, with surgical resection being the mainstay. Adjuvant radiation therapy and chemotherapy were utilized in advanced cases. The overall survival rate at 5 years was 68.5%, with tumor stage and histological grade proving to be significant prognostic factors. This study provides valuable insights into the clinicopathologic characteristics of ACC and may aid in improving diagnostic accuracy, treatment planning, and patient outcomes.

The Ams (altered mRNA stability) protein and ribonuclease E are encoded by the same structural gene of Escherichia coli. The study of gene regulation is pivotal for understanding cellular processes and disease mechanisms. In Escherichia coli, the Ams (altered mRNA stability) protein and ribonuclease E are encoded by the same structural gene. This novel finding suggests a unique regulatory mechanism that involves a multifunctional protein. Recent studies have elucidated the roles of Ams and ribonuclease E in mRNA degradation, RNA processing, and post-transcriptional regulation. Furthermore, Ams has been found to interact with various proteins involved in RNA metabolism, indicating its potential involvement in complex regulatory networks. Understanding the molecular interactions and functional implications of Ams and ribonuclease E holds great promise for unraveling the intricate mechanisms underlying gene regulation in E. coli and other organisms. This knowledge may have broader implications in fields such as microbiology, molecular biology, and biotechnology, leading to the development of novel therapeutic interventions and genetic engineering techniques. Further investigations are warranted to fully comprehend the intricate interplay between Ams, ribonuclease E, and gene regulation.

Cerebral infarction in patients with nephrotic syndrome. Nephrotic syndrome is a common renal disorder characterized by various metabolic and vascular abnormalities. Cerebrovascular complications, including cerebral infarction, are rare but serious consequences of nephrotic syndrome. This study aimed to investigate the incidence, risk factors, and clinical characteristics of cerebral infarction in patients with nephrotic syndrome. Data from a nationwide health insurance claims database were analyzed, identifying a total of 2,489 patients with nephrotic syndrome and 24 cases of cerebral infarction. The incidence rate of cerebral infarction in patients with nephrotic syndrome was found to be 0.96 per 1,000 person-years. Pre-existing comorbidities, including hypertension, diabetes mellitus, and hyperlipidemia, were significantly associated with an increased risk of cerebral infarction in these patients. Furthermore, the presence of nephrotic syndrome-related complications, such as hypoalbuminemia and proteinuria, was also found to be predictive of cerebral infarction. Early recognition and management of these risk factors are essential for the prevention and optimal treatment of cerebral infarction in patients with nephrotic syndrome. Further studies are warranted to explore potential interventions to reduce the risk of cerebral infarction in this population.

Neonatal small bowel atresia, stenosis and segmental dilatation. Neonatal small bowel atresia, stenosis, and segmental dilatation are congenital anomalies of the gastrointestinal tract that can lead to significant morbidity and mortality in affected infants. Despite advances in surgical techniques and neonatal intensive care, the management of these conditions remains challenging. This review aims to provide an overview of the epidemiology, clinical presentation, pathophysiology, and current management strategies for neonatal small bowel atresia, stenosis, and segmental dilatation. Various etiological factors, including genetic and environmental factors, have been implicated in the development of these anomalies. Prompt diagnosis through prenatal ultrasound and postnatal imaging is crucial for timely surgical intervention. Surgical options range from resection and primary anastomosis to the creation of stomas and subsequent bowel lengthening procedures. The postoperative care of these patients often involves close monitoring for complications such as anastomotic leaks, strictures, and intestinal dysmotility. Further research is needed to better understand the underlying mechanisms and improve outcomes for infants with these challenging conditions.

The perineal artificial sphincter for acquired incontinence--a cut and dried solution? Sixteen males with stress incontinence due to sphincter damage were investigated with videourodynamic studies after implantation of a perineal artificial urinary sphincter. The use of a perineal artificial urinary sphincter was evaluated as a treatment for acquired incontinence in 16 male patients with sphincter damage. Videourodynamic studies were conducted post-implantation to assess the effectiveness of the artificial sphincter. Results showed that the perineal artificial urinary sphincter provided a satisfactory solution for these patients, as it effectively controlled the urinary flow during stress-inducing activities. No complications or adverse effects were observed in any of the patients. The use of the perineal artificial urinary sphincter appears to be a viable and successful option for managing acquired incontinence in males with sphincter damage, offering a promising solution to a challenging clinical problem.

Growth, thermogenesis, and hyperphagia. Growth, thermogenesis, and hyperphagia are interconnected physiological processes that are influenced by various factors and play important roles in the regulation of energy balance. This review aims to explore the intricate relationship between these processes and the underlying mechanisms involved. Growth, which is primarily driven by the growth hormone axis, is closely linked to thermogenesis and hyperphagia. Thermogenesis, the generation of heat by the body, is critical for maintaining body temperature and is mediated by various thermogenic effectors such as brown adipose tissue and uncoupling proteins. Hyperphagia, an increase in food intake, is influenced by both peripheral and central factors, including hormonal signals such as leptin and ghrelin. Dysregulation of any of these processes can lead to energy imbalance and contribute to the development of obesity and metabolic disorders. Therefore, understanding the intricate interplay between growth, thermogenesis, and hyperphagia is crucial for developing effective strategies for the prevention and treatment of obesity and related conditions.

Erythropoietin response to anemia as a function of age.  The erythropoietin (EPO) response to anemia was assessed for 244 subjects aged 1-64 years (mean 45. The study aimed to investigate the age-related variations in erythropoietin (EPO) response to anemia in a population of 244 individuals ranging from 1 to 64 years old, with a mean age of 45. Anemia was induced in each subject using phlebotomy, and EPO levels were measured at baseline and after anemia induction. Results showed a significant decline in EPO response with increasing age, with younger individuals exhibiting a more robust response compared to older participants. This age-dependent decline in EPO response may have implications for the management of anemia in different age groups, highlighting the need for individualized treatment strategies. Further research is needed to elucidate the underlying mechanisms responsible for this age-related variation in EPO response to anemia.

Neodymium: YAG laser hysteroscopy in large submucous fibroids. This study aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of neodymium: YAG laser hysteroscopy for the treatment of large submucous fibroids. A total of 35 patients with symptomatic large submucous fibroids underwent neodymium: YAG laser hysteroscopy. The presenting complaints were menorrhagia in 23 patients, menometrorrhagia in 9 patients, and heavy postmenopausal bleeding in 3 patients. The procedure successfully removed the fibroids in all patients, with no major complications observed. Long-term follow-up was available for 32 patients, and 29 of them reported improvement or resolution of their symptoms. Three patients required repeat hysteroscopic laser treatment for recurrent fibroids. In conclusion, neodymium: YAG laser hysteroscopy is an effective and safe technique for the removal of large submucous fibroids, providing symptom relief and avoiding the need for more invasive procedures like hysterectomy.

Multiple intracranial mucoceles associated with phaeohyphomycosis of the paranasal sinuses. Intracranial mucoceles are rare and typically arise as a result of chronic obstructive sinus disease or prior trauma. We present a case of a patient with multiple intracranial mucoceles associated with phaeohyphomycosis of the paranasal sinuses, a condition caused by dematiaceous fungi. The patient initially presented with symptoms of chronic sinusitis and was found to have multiple mucoceles on imaging. Endoscopic sinus surgery was performed and fungal culture revealed the presence of dematiaceous fungi. The patient was started on antifungal therapy but unfortunately developed complications including intracranial involvement of the disease. Surgical intervention was subsequently required to drain the mucoceles and debride infected tissue. Despite the aggressive treatment, the patient's outcome was poor with persistent neurological deficits. This case highlights the challenging management of intracranial mucoceles associated with phaeohyphomycosis and the need for early diagnosis and appropriate treatment to prevent potentially devastating complications.

Phospholipids from rat, human, and canine gastric mucosa.  Composition and metabolism of molecular classes of phosphatidylcholine. Phospholipids are important components of gastric mucosa and play a crucial role in maintaining its integrity and function. This study aimed to investigate the composition and metabolism of molecular classes of phosphatidylcholine (PC) in the gastric mucosa of rats, humans, and dogs.

The composition of PC molecular classes was determined using high-performance liquid chromatography. The results showed significant differences in the distribution of PC molecular species between the three species. Specifically, rats had a higher proportion of saturated fatty acids in their PC molecules compared to humans and dogs. Additionally, rats exhibited a higher level of polyunsaturated fatty acids in their PC molecules, while dogs had the highest proportion of monounsaturated fatty acids.

The metabolic turnover of PC molecular classes was assessed by measuring the incorporation of radiolabeled choline into PC molecules. The results revealed differences in the kinetics of PC synthesis and degradation between the three species.

Overall, this study provides valuable insights into the composition and metabolism of phospholipids in gastric mucosa, highlighting species-specific differences that may have implications for gastrointestinal health and disease. Further research is warranted to elucidate the functional significance of these differences and their potential therapeutic implications.

Sclerotherapy of varicose and telangiectatic leg veins. Sclerotherapy is a commonly used procedure for the treatment of varicose and telangiectatic leg veins. This study aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of sclerotherapy in a cohort of 50 patients with varicose and telangiectatic leg veins. The patients underwent sclerotherapy using a foam sclerosant under ultrasound guidance. The treatment outcomes were assessed based on the reduction in vein diameter and improvement in clinical symptoms such as pain, heaviness, and itching. The results showed a significant reduction in vein diameter and improvement in clinical symptoms in the majority of patients. Adverse events were minimal and mostly related to temporary skin discoloration or minor pain at the injection site. This study supports the use of sclerotherapy as an effective and safe treatment option for varicose and telangiectatic leg veins. Further studies with larger sample sizes are warranted to confirm these findings and explore long-term outcomes.

Quality of life in elderly, chronically ill outpatients.  Quality of life (QL) in elderly outpatients is poorly characterized. The quality of life (QL) of elderly, chronically ill outpatients has received limited attention in medical research. Understanding and improving the QL of this population is vital for optimizing healthcare outcomes and addressing their unique needs. This study aimed to investigate the QL of a sample of elderly, chronically ill outpatients and examine factors that may influence their QL. A cross-sectional survey was conducted among 200 participants aged 65 and above, with various chronic illnesses, attending outpatient clinics. Participants completed standardized QL questionnaires, including domains related to physical, mental, and social well-being. Results showed that the QL of elderly, chronically ill outpatients was generally lower than that of the general elderly population. Factors such as the number of chronic illnesses, functional disability, and social support were found to significantly impact QL. These findings highlight the importance of developing interventions and healthcare policies that address the specific needs of this population to enhance their QL.

Comparison of structure, mechanical properties, and functions of lumbar spinal ligaments. The lumbar spinal ligaments play a crucial role in the stability and function of the spine. However, little is known about the specific structural, mechanical, and functional differences between these ligaments. This study aimed to compare the structure, mechanical properties, and functions of the lumbar spinal ligaments.

A total of 40 lumbar spinal ligaments were collected from 10 human cadaveric specimens. The ligaments were categorized into four groups: supraspinous ligament, interspinous ligament, ligamentum flavum, and posterior longitudinal ligament. Histological analysis was conducted to assess the ligaments' microstructure.

Mechanical testing was performed using a materials testing machine to evaluate the ligaments' tensile properties, including ultimate stress, ultimate strain, and modulus of elasticity. Additionally, the ligaments' functional properties, such as range of motion and load bearing capacity, were investigated using a custom-designed spinal motion simulator.

Preliminary results indicate that each lumbar spinal ligament has a unique microstructure and mechanical behavior. The ligamentum flavum exhibited the highest ultimate stress and modulus of elasticity, suggesting its role in providing stability and preventing excessive motion. The posterior longitudinal ligament demonstrated the lowest ultimate stress, indicating its susceptibility to injury and degeneration. Furthermore, the supraspinous and interspinous ligaments displayed substantial range of motion and load-bearing capabilities, emphasizing their role in facilitating spinal flexibility.

Understanding the distinct characteristics of these ligaments can provide valuable insights for the development of targeted therapeutic interventions for various lumbar spinal pathologies, including disc herniation, spinal stenosis, and degenerative disc disease.

Management of penile gunshot wounds. Penile gunshot wounds are rare but potentially devastating injuries that require prompt and appropriate management. We present a retrospective analysis of seven cases of penile gunshot wounds treated at our institution over a period of five years. The average age of the patients was 32 years, with the majority being victims of intentional self-harm. Initial evaluation involved a thorough assessment of the wound, including localization, size, depth, and involvement of adjacent structures. Surgical exploration was performed in all cases to assess the extent of damage and facilitate debridement. The management approach varied depending on the severity of injury, with a combination of wound exploration, debridement, repair, and reconstruction techniques employed. Complications encountered included penile deformity, erectile dysfunction, and urethral stricture. Long-term follow-up revealed satisfactory cosmetic and functional outcomes in the majority of patients. Prompt recognition and appropriate management of penile gunshot wounds are essential to minimize complications and optimize patient outcomes.

Ocular complications of rheumatic diseases of childhood. Rheumatic diseases can have ocular manifestations that significantly impact the overall well-being of children. This study aimed to assess the prevalence and types of ocular complications in children with rheumatic diseases. A total of 82 children with rheumatic diseases were included in the study, with a mean age of 10 years. Ocular complications were found in 38% of the children, with uveitis being the most common (26%), followed by scleritis (10%) and keratitis (2%). The presence of ocular complications was significantly associated with disease activity and severity. Prompt recognition and management of ocular complications in children with rheumatic diseases are crucial to prevent potential visual impairment and improve overall outcomes.

The Maylard incision in gynecologic surgery The transverse muscle-splitting Maylard incision was used in 175 gynecologic patients who required pelvic-abdominal surgery. The Maylard incision, a transverse muscle-splitting approach, was utilized in 175 gynecologic patients undergoing pelvic-abdominal surgery. The incision was performed to gain access to the desired surgical site while minimizing potential complications. The patients' demographic data, operative details, intraoperative findings, and postoperative outcomes were analyzed. The Maylard incision provided excellent exposure to the pelvic and lower abdominal structures, enabling the surgical team to perform the necessary procedures effectively. Intraoperative complications were minimal, with only a few cases requiring additional interventions. Postoperative recovery was uneventful, with patients experiencing minimal pain and excellent wound healing. The Maylard incision demonstrated its efficacy and safety in gynecologic surgery, making it a suitable choice for accessing the pelvic-abdominal region.

Effect of motilin on gastric emptying in patients with diabetic gastroparesis. Patients with diabetic gastroparesis often experience delayed gastric emptying, resulting in symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, and upper abdominal discomfort. Motilin is a gastrointestinal hormone that has been shown to stimulate gastric motility and improve gastric emptying in healthy individuals. The purpose of this study was to investigate the effect of motilin on gastric emptying in patients with diabetic gastroparesis. 

A total of 40 patients with confirmed diabetic gastroparesis were enrolled in the study. They were randomly assigned to receive either motilin or placebo for a period of 4 weeks. Gastric emptying was assessed using scintigraphy before and after the treatment period. 

The results demonstrated a significant improvement in gastric emptying in the motilin group compared to the placebo group. Patients who received motilin also reported a significant reduction in symptoms such as nausea and vomiting. No serious adverse events were reported during the study.

In conclusion, motilin appears to be an effective treatment for improving gastric emptying in patients with diabetic gastroparesis. Further research is needed to fully understand the mechanism of action and long-term effectiveness of motilin in this patient population.

Isolated erythroid hypoplasia and renal insufficiency induced by long-term griseofulvin therapy. We present a case of isolated erythroid hypoplasia and renal insufficiency induced by long-term griseofulvin therapy. A 44-year-old male with tinea corporis was treated with griseofulvin for a prolonged period of six months. Subsequently, he developed progressive fatigue, weakness, and pale appearance. Laboratory investigations revealed severe anemia, with a hemoglobin level of 7.9 g/dL, and marked renal impairment, with elevated serum creatinine levels. Bone marrow biopsy demonstrated erythroid hypoplasia without evidence of myelodysplasia or malignancy. The patient's symptoms and laboratory abnormalities improved upon discontinuation of griseofulvin therapy and initiation of supportive care, including blood transfusions and renal supportive measures. To our knowledge, this is the first reported case of isolated erythroid hypoplasia and renal insufficiency associated with long-term griseofulvin therapy. This case highlights the importance of recognizing potential adverse effects of certain medications, even in commonly used agents such as griseofulvin, and prompt discontinuation of therapy in the presence of significant hematological and renal abnormalities. Further research is needed to understand the underlying pathophysiology of this rare complication.

Doppler diagnostics, indications, and control of surgical treatment in patients with carotid pathology. Carotid artery disease is a common vascular pathology associated with increased risk of cerebrovascular events. Doppler ultrasound has emerged as a valuable tool for evaluating this condition, providing real-time visualization of blood flow and identifying stenosis or occlusion. In this review, we aim to summarize the indications and diagnostic utility of Doppler ultrasound in patients with carotid pathology.

Doppler ultrasound allows for accurate assessment of carotid artery stenosis, aiding in treatment decision-making. It can help identify patients who would benefit from surgical intervention, such as carotid endarterectomy or carotid stenting. Furthermore, Doppler ultrasound can be used for postoperative surveillance to monitor restenosis or detect any new lesions.

In conclusion, Doppler ultrasound plays a crucial role in the management of patients with carotid artery disease, facilitating proper patient selection for surgical treatment and enabling effective postoperative monitoring. Its non-invasive nature, cost-effectiveness, and accuracy make it an essential tool in the armamentarium of clinicians involved in the care of patients with carotid pathology.

The neuromuscular pathology of the Eosinophilia-Myalgia syndrome.  The Eosinophilia-Myalgia Syndrome (EMS) is a recently reorganized disorder in patients ingesting pharmacologic doses of L-tryptophan. The Eosinophilia-Myalgia Syndrome (EMS) is a rare disorder characterized by eosinophilia and myalgia, which has been associated with the ingestion of L-tryptophan. The pathogenesis of EMS is not fully understood, but it has been suggested that an unknown contaminant in L-tryptophan supplements may trigger an immune-mediated response leading to the development of the syndrome. This abstract aims to summarize the neuromuscular pathology associated with EMS.

Several studies have reported peripheral nerve abnormalities in EMS patients, including axonal degeneration, demyelination, and infiltration of inflammatory cells. Muscle biopsies have revealed features consistent with a necrotizing myopathy, including myofiber atrophy, fiber splitting, and inflammatory infiltrates. In addition, abnormalities in nerve conduction studies and electromyography have been reported, indicative of a peripheral neuropathy.

Further research is needed to fully understand the underlying mechanisms leading to the neuromuscular pathology in EMS. Improved understanding of these pathological changes may lead to better diagnostic and therapeutic strategies for patients affected by this syndrome.

Atonic pupil: an unusual complication of cataract surgery. We report a rare case of an atonic pupil following cataract surgery. A 68-year-old male presented with complaints of blurred vision and a large central scotoma in his left eye following an uneventful cataract surgery. Slit lamp examination revealed a dilated and unresponsive pupil in the left eye. The rest of the ocular examination was within normal limits. A diagnosis of atonic pupil was made based on the clinical findings. Treatment options including pharmacological and surgical interventions were discussed with the patient. The patient opted for conservative management and was followed up regularly. After 6 months, there was partial recovery of the pupillary function, with a smaller but still dilated pupil. Atonic pupil is a rare complication of cataract surgery, and timely diagnosis and appropriate management are crucial for patient outcomes.

Lumbar spinal nerves in the neural foramen: MR appearance. The aim of this study was to assess the magnetic resonance (MR) appearance of lumbar spinal nerves in the neural foramen. A total of 25 patients with lumbar radiculopathy underwent MR imaging of the lumbar spine. Images were obtained in the axial and sagittal planes using T1-weighted and T2-weighted sequences. The MR images were evaluated for the presence of nerve root compression, intraneural edema, and perineural fibrosis. The results showed that nerve root compression and intraneural edema were the most common findings in patients with lumbar radiculopathy. Perineural fibrosis was also observed in a subset of patients. The MR appearance of the lumbar spinal nerves in the neural foramen can provide valuable information for the diagnosis and management of lumbar radiculopathy. Further studies are needed to determine the clinical significance of these findings and their correlation with patient symptoms and outcomes.

Synergistic effects of INTERCEED(TC7) and heparin in reducing adhesion formation in the rabbit uterine horn model. Adhesion formation is a significant complication following gynecological surgeries and can lead to pain, infertility, and bowel obstruction. The use of anti-adhesion barriers, such as INTERCEED(TC7), has been shown to reduce adhesion formation. Heparin, a well-known anticoagulant, has also been investigated for its potential anti-adhesion properties. This study aimed to assess the synergistic effects of INTERCEED(TC7) and heparin in reducing adhesion formation in a rabbit uterine horn model.

Twenty female New Zealand White rabbits underwent laparotomy and bilateral uterine horn injury. They were divided into four groups: control, INTERCEED(TC7), heparin, and the combination of INTERCEED(TC7) and heparin. Adhesions were assessed macroscopically and histologically at two and four weeks post-operatively.

The combination of INTERCEED(TC7) and heparin significantly reduced adhesion scores compared to the control and individual treatment groups. Histological evaluation confirmed reduced fibrosis and inflammatory response in the combination group.

In conclusion, the synergistic effects of INTERCEED(TC7) and heparin demonstrate promise in reducing adhesion formation. Further research is warranted to optimize the dosage and evaluate the long-term outcomes of this combination therapy.

Intra-abdominal "angiosarcomatosis" report of two cases after pelvic irradiation. Angiosarcomatosis is a rare complication that can occur following pelvic irradiation. We present two cases of intra-abdominal angiosarcomatosis in patients who had previously undergone pelvic irradiation for gynecologic malignancies. The first case involved a 58-year-old female with a history of endometrial cancer treated with radiation therapy. She presented with abdominal pain and imaging studies revealed multiple intra-abdominal masses. The second case involved a 62-year-old female with a history of cervical cancer treated with radiation therapy. She presented with fatigue and weight loss, and imaging studies showed diffuse intra-abdominal nodules. In both cases, histopathological examination confirmed the presence of angiosarcoma. Despite aggressive treatment with surgery and chemotherapy, both patients had a poor prognosis with rapid disease progression and metastasis. In conclusion, intra-abdominal angiosarcomatosis should be considered in patients with a history of pelvic irradiation who present with new-onset intra-abdominal masses. Early diagnosis and prompt intervention are crucial for improving patient outcomes.

The risk for systemic vascular diseases and mortality in patients with central retinal vein occlusion.  In this cross-sectional study, the authors evaluated 197 patients diagnosed with central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO) at the Wilmer Ophthalmological Institute between 1980 and 1985 to determine the risk of systemic disease and mortality. This cross-sectional study aimed to investigate the risk of systemic vascular diseases and mortality in patients with central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO). A total of 197 patients diagnosed with CRVO at the Wilmer Ophthalmological Institute between 1980 and 1985 were included. The patients were followed up for a median of 16.3 years to assess the occurrence of systemic vascular diseases and mortality. The results showed that patients with CRVO had a significantly higher risk of developing systemic vascular diseases, such as hypertension, diabetes mellitus, and cerebrovascular disease, compared to the general population. Furthermore, the mortality rate was also found to be elevated in these patients. These findings highlight the importance of early identification and management of systemic risk factors in individuals with CRVO to prevent adverse outcomes.

Mucocele of the cystic duct remnant in eight liver transplant recipients: findings at cholangiography, CT, and US.  The case histories and radiologic studies of eight liver transplant recipients who developed a mucocele of the allograft cystic duct remnant were retrospectively evaluated. Mucocele of the cystic duct remnant is a rare complication that can occur in liver transplant recipients. This study retrospectively evaluates the case histories and radiologic studies of eight liver transplant recipients who developed a mucocele of the allograft cystic duct remnant. Cholangiography, computed tomography (CT), and ultrasound (US) were used to investigate and diagnose this condition. The findings from these imaging techniques revealed the presence of dilated cystic duct remnant filled with mucus in all cases. Additional complications, such as biliary obstruction or infection, were observed in some patients. Prompt diagnosis and management of mucocele of the cystic duct remnant are vital to prevent further complications and ensure successful outcomes in liver transplant recipients. Further research is needed to better understand the mechanisms and risk factors associated with this condition.

'Cystic papilloma' in humans? Demonstration of human papillomavirus in plantar epidermoid cysts. Plantar epidermoid cysts, also known as cystic papillomas, are common benign skin lesions commonly found on the soles of the feet. Previous studies have suggested a possible association between these cysts and human papillomavirus (HPV) infection; however, conclusive evidence supporting this association is lacking. In this study, we aim to determine the presence of HPV in plantar epidermoid cysts.

Samples were collected from 30 patients with clinically diagnosed plantar epidermoid cysts. DNA extraction and PCR amplification were performed using consensus primers targeting the L1 region of HPV. Positive PCR results were further analyzed using type-specific primers for the detection of 14 high-risk HPV types.

HPV DNA was detected in 15 out of the 30 samples (50%). Of these, 10 samples (33.3%) were positive for high-risk HPV types. The most common type detected was HPV-16 (26.7%), followed by HPV-18 (6.7%). Additionally, two samples (6.7%) were positive for low-risk HPV type 6.

This study provides evidence supporting the presence of HPV in plantar epidermoid cysts, suggesting a possible role of the virus in the development of these lesions. Further research is warranted to elucidate the pathogenesis and clinical implications of this association.

Flow cytometric DNA content of adenoid cystic carcinoma of submandibular gland.  Correlation of histologic features and prognosis. AIMS: The aim of this study was to investigate the correlation between histologic features and prognosis in adenoid cystic carcinoma (ACC) of the submandibular gland by analyzing the flow cytometric DNA content. METHODS: Twenty-nine patients diagnosed with ACC of the submandibular gland were included in this study. Flow cytometric analysis of DNA content was performed on paraffin-embedded tumor tissues. The histologic features of the tumors were evaluated using hematoxylin and eosin staining. The patients were followed up for a minimum of 5 years to assess their prognosis. RESULTS: The flow cytometric analysis revealed that 55.2% of the cases had aneuploidy, while the remaining cases were diploid. Histologically, the presence of solid growth pattern, perineural invasion, and lymphovascular invasion was significantly associated with aneuploidy. Additionally, patients with aneuploid tumors had a significantly lower overall survival rate compared to those with diploid tumors. CONCLUSIONS: The results of this study suggest that flow cytometric DNA content analysis can provide valuable information regarding the prognosis of ACC of the submandibular gland, and the histologic features associated with aneuploidy can serve as predictors of poor prognosis.

Decalcification of a choroidal osteoma. Decalcification is a common approach utilized to study bone tumors and other calcified structures. In this case, we report on the successful decalcification of a choroidal osteoma, a rare benign tumor of the eye. The decalcification technique involved the use of a specific decalcifying agent and was followed by histological processing of the specimen. The decalcification process effectively removed the mineralized components of the tumor, allowing for improved visualization of the histological features. We describe the step-by-step procedure for decalcification, as well as the subsequent histological examination of the specimen. This case highlights the importance of decalcification in the diagnostic evaluation of choroidal osteomas and provides valuable insights into the histopathological characteristics of this unique tumor.

Pelvic pain: lessons from anatomy and physiology. Pelvic pain is a complex symptom that can arise from a variety of structural, functional, and psychosocial factors. Understanding the underlying anatomy and physiology of the pelvis is crucial in diagnosing and managing pelvic pain. This article provides a comprehensive overview of the anatomical structures and physiological functions of the pelvis, highlighting the potential sources of pelvic pain. The pelvis houses various organs, including the bladder, uterus, and rectum, which can all contribute to pain when dysfunction or pathology occurs. Additionally, the intricate network of nerves, blood vessels, and muscles in the pelvis play a significant role in pain perception and transmission. By examining the interplay between anatomy and physiology, healthcare professionals can develop a more holistic approach to evaluating and treating patients with pelvic pain.

Expression and characterization of TCA3: a murine inflammatory protein.  TCA3 is a cDNA originally isolated from activated T cells. TCA3 is a murine inflammatory protein that was originally identified in activated T cells. In this study, we aimed to investigate the expression and characterize the function of TCA3 in the context of inflammation. First, we examined the expression of TCA3 in various tissues and found that it was primarily expressed in immune cells, including T cells, B cells, macrophages, and dendritic cells. Furthermore, we observed increased TCA3 expression following stimulation with inflammatory mediators such as lipopolysaccharide and interleukin-1. To elucidate the function of TCA3, we performed in vitro experiments and found that it enhanced the production of pro-inflammatory cytokines, including tumor necrosis factor- and interleukin-6, by immune cells. Additionally, we observed that TCA3 induced the recruitment of immune cells to the site of inflammation in a murine model. Overall, our findings suggest that TCA3 plays a crucial role in mediating inflammatory responses and may serve as a potential therapeutic target for inflammatory diseases.

Risk ratios and risk differences in estimating the effect of risk factors for cardiovascular disease in the elderly. Estimating the effect of risk factors for cardiovascular disease (CVD) in the elderly population is essential for preventing and managing CVD in this age group. This study aimed to compare the use of risk ratios (RR) and risk differences (RD) in estimating the effects of risk factors for CVD in the elderly. A systematic review of published studies was conducted, and data from the included studies were analyzed using meta-analysis techniques. The results showed that both RR and RD were commonly used in estimating the effects of risk factors for CVD in the elderly. However, RR tended to overestimate the effect sizes compared to RD. Furthermore, RR was more sensitive to changes in the prevalence of risk factors, whereas RD was more robust. These findings suggest that both RR and RD have their strengths and limitations in estimating the effects of risk factors for CVD in the elderly, and their use should be considered based on the specific research question and population characteristics.

Cyclosporine-induced thrombotic microangiopathy resulting in renal allograft loss and its successful reuse: a report of two cases. Cyclosporine-induced thrombotic microangiopathy (TMA) is a rare but serious complication in renal transplant recipients. We present two cases of renal allograft recipients who developed TMA, resulting in graft loss. Both patients had received cyclosporine as part of their immunosuppressive regimen. TMA was confirmed by histopathological examination showing thrombi in the glomerular capillaries and arterioles. The patients were managed with discontinuation of cyclosporine, plasmapheresis, and supportive therapy. Despite initial graft loss, both patients were able to undergo successful retransplantation and demonstrate adequate renal function postoperatively. This case report highlights the importance of early recognition, prompt management, and potential for reutilization of renal allografts in cyclosporine-induced TMA.

Laparoscopic management of ovarian cysts. The laparoscopic management of ovarian cysts has become a widely used technique in the field of gynecology. This minimally invasive surgical approach offers several advantages, including shorter hospital stays, reduced postoperative pain, and faster recovery times compared to traditional open surgery. In this study, we aim to evaluate the safety and efficacy of laparoscopic management in a cohort of patients with ovarian cysts. We reviewed the medical records of 100 patients who underwent laparoscopic cystectomy or oophorectomy for ovarian cysts. Our results demonstrate that laparoscopic management is a safe and effective technique with low complication rates and favorable outcomes. We also discuss the various types of ovarian cysts encountered, the surgical techniques used, and the postoperative follow-up care required for optimal patient outcomes.

Facial muscle reanimation using the trigeminal motor nerve: an experimental study in the rabbit. This experimental study aimed to investigate the feasibility of facial muscle reanimation using the trigeminal motor nerve in rabbits. Fifteen rabbits were included in this study and divided into three groups. The first group underwent facial nerve transection only, the second group underwent transection and anastomosis of the trigeminal motor nerve to the facial nerve, and the third group served as a control with no intervention. The rabbits were evaluated for facial muscle function using the House-Brackmann grading system and electromyography. Results showed that the rabbits in the second group had significantly improved facial muscle function compared to the first group. The study concludes that facial muscle reanimation using the trigeminal motor nerve holds promise as a potential treatment option for facial nerve paralysis.

Radical resection for carcinoma of the ampulla of Vater.  One hundred four consecutive patients who underwent radical resection for ampullary cancer between 1965 and 1989 were retrospectively reviewed. The objective of this study was to evaluate the long-term outcomes of radical resection for carcinoma of the ampulla of Vater. The study included 104 consecutive patients who underwent the procedure between 1965 and 1989. The overall survival rate was determined using Kaplan-Meier analysis, and prognostic factors were identified using Cox regression analysis. The median follow-up period was 10.5 years. The overall 5-year survival rate was 58.7%, and the 10-year survival rate was 47.5%. Multivariate analysis revealed that lymph node metastasis, positive resection margin, and advanced tumor stage were independent poor prognostic factors. Moreover, adjuvant chemotherapy was found to significantly improve survival in patients with lymph node metastasis. Based on these findings, radical resection appears to be an effective treatment option for carcinoma of the ampulla of Vater, with potential survival benefits when combined with adjuvant chemotherapy in selected patients.

Lateral medullary infarction: prognosis in an unselected series.  We describe the acute and long-term prognosis in 43 patients with lateral medullary infarction (LMI) collected from a population-based stroke registry from 1982 to July 1988. Lateral medullary infarction (LMI), also known as Wallenberg syndrome, is a rare type of stroke that affects the lateral part of the brainstem. In this study, we aimed to investigate the acute and long-term prognosis of LMI in an unselected series of patients.

43 patients with confirmed LMI were included in the study, and their data was collected from a population-based stroke registry from 1982 to July 1988. The patients' medical records were reviewed to gather information about their initial presentation, clinical course, and outcome.

Of the 43 patients, 32 presented with typical symptoms of LMI, such as ipsilateral facial pain, dysphagia, and hoarseness. The remaining 11 patients had atypical presentations, which included dizziness and gait disturbances. 

At the time of the initial evaluation, 24 patients had complete resolution of symptoms, while 19 patients had residual deficits. The long-term prognosis varied, with some patients experiencing improvement and others having persistent symptoms. 

In conclusion, LMI can present with a variety of symptoms and has a variable prognosis. Further research is needed to better understand the factors that influence the outcomes of patients with LMI.

Carcinoma of female urethra.  Manitoba experience: 1958-1987. The purpose of this study was to review the clinical and pathological features of carcinoma of the female urethra based on the Manitoba experience from 1958 to 1987. A total of 32 cases were identified, with a mean age at diagnosis of 61 years. The most common presenting symptom was hematuria, followed by dysuria and urinary frequency. Squamous cell carcinoma was the most frequent histological type, accounting for 78% of cases, while adenocarcinoma and transitional cell carcinoma were less common. The majority of cases were localized at diagnosis, with only 9% showing regional or distant metastasis. Treatment modalities included surgery, radiation therapy, and chemotherapy, either alone or in combination. The overall five-year survival rate was 69%, with a better prognosis observed in patients with early-stage disease and those who underwent surgical resection. These findings provide valuable insights into the clinical characteristics and therapeutic strategies for carcinoma of the female urethra.

Rehabilitation in brain disorders.  4. This is a review article discussing the importance of rehabilitation in brain disorders. The article examines various rehabilitation strategies and their effectiveness in improving outcomes for patients with brain disorders. It highlights the significant impact that brain disorders can have on an individual's physical, cognitive, and emotional functioning, and emphasizes the need for a multidisciplinary approach to rehabilitation.

The review discusses evidence supporting the use of different rehabilitation techniques, including physical therapy, occupational therapy, and cognitive rehabilitation. It emphasizes the importance of early intervention and individualized treatment plans in order to maximize functional recovery.

The article also discusses the role of technology in brain disorder rehabilitation, including the use of virtual reality and robotics. It highlights the potential benefits of these innovative approaches in enhancing motor and cognitive function.

Overall, the review emphasizes the importance of rehabilitation in improving long-term outcomes for individuals with brain disorders. It suggests that a comprehensive and personalized rehabilitation program can lead to improved functional abilities, increased independence, and enhanced quality of life for patients with brain disorders.

DNA ploidy pattern in rectal carcinoid tumors. The DNA ploidy pattern in rectal carcinoid tumors was analyzed using flow cytometry in order to investigate its potential prognostic significance. Tumor samples from 36 patients with rectal carcinoid tumors were analyzed for DNA content and categorized as diploid or aneuploid based on the DNA index. The results showed that 19 out of 36 tumors (52.8%) were diploid, while the remaining 17 tumors (47.2%) were aneuploid. Additionally, tumor size, lymph node involvement, and distant metastasis were assessed and correlated with the DNA ploidy pattern. Interestingly, there was no significant association between the DNA ploidy pattern and any of these clinicopathological factors. These findings suggest that DNA ploidy analysis does not have prognostic significance in rectal carcinoid tumors, highlighting the need for alternative biomarkers to predict tumor behavior and guide therapeutic strategies.

Sensitivity and specificity of various morphological features of cervical condylomas. Cervical condylomas are common manifestations of human papillomavirus (HPV) infection and are a major cause of morbidity and mortality. The accurate identification and classification of these lesions is crucial for determining appropriate management strategies. This study aimed to evaluate the sensitivity and specificity of various morphological features in diagnosing cervical condylomas. A total of 100 patients with histologically confirmed cervical condylomas were included in the analysis. The presence or absence of features such as cauliflower-like appearance, color, surface texture, and size were recorded. Sensitivity and specificity were calculated for each feature using histopathology as the gold standard. Our results showed varying sensitivity and specificity for different morphological features. The cauliflower-like appearance had the highest sensitivity (85%) and specificity (80%). These findings highlight the importance of careful observation and consideration of multiple morphological features in the diagnosis of cervical condylomas.

Nursing home patients transferred by ambulance to a VA emergency department.  Nursing home residents are frequently transferred to hospital emergency departments. This study aimed to examine the characteristics and outcomes of nursing home patients transferred by ambulance to a Veterans Affairs (VA) emergency department (ED). A retrospective analysis of data from nursing home residents who were transferred by ambulance to the ED of a VA hospital over a one-year period was conducted. The study included 456 patients with a mean age of 78 years, of which 56% were male. The most common reason for transfer was altered mental status (40%), followed by respiratory distress (20%) and falls (17%). The majority of patients had multiple comorbidities, with dementia being the most prevalent (60%). The mean ED length of stay was 6.7 hours, and approximately 25% of patients required hospital admission. The overall mortality rate within 30 days of ED presentation was 13%. These findings highlight the significant burden placed on VA EDs by nursing home transfers, emphasizing the need for improved communication and coordination between nursing homes and emergency services to optimize patient care and reduce unnecessary hospitalizations.

Association of disease-free survival and percent of ideal dose in adjuvant breast chemotherapy. Current research has demonstrated the importance of optimizing chemotherapy dosing in patients with breast cancer to maximize disease-free survival (DFS). The aim of this study was to assess the association between disease-free survival and the percent of ideal dose received by patients receiving adjuvant breast chemotherapy. A retrospective analysis was conducted on a cohort of 200 patients who received adjuvant chemotherapy following surgical resection of stage II or III breast cancer. The ideal dose was calculated based on body surface area and recommended guidelines. Patients were categorized into three groups based on the percent of ideal dose received: <80%, 80-100%, and >100%. The primary outcome measure was disease-free survival, defined as the time from chemotherapy initiation to disease recurrence or death. The results revealed a statistically significant association between disease-free survival and the percent of ideal dose received. Specifically, patients receiving 80% of the ideal dose had significantly higher disease-free survival rates compared to those receiving <80% or >100% of the ideal dose. These findings emphasize the importance of accurately dosing adjuvant chemotherapy in breast cancer patients to optimize treatment outcomes.

Coronary collateral recruitment: functional significance and relation to rate of vessel closure.  Studies in animals and humans have demonstrated the anatomic presence and functional significance of coronary collaterals. Collateral vessels develop as a compensatory mechanism in response to chronic myocardial ischemia. The recruitment of collateral vessels has been shown to have a protective effect in reduced myocardial blood flow conditions. However, little is known about the rate of collateral recruitment and its relation to vessel closure in the context of acute coronary syndrome. 

In this study, we investigated the functional significance of coronary collateral recruitment and its relation to the rate of vessel closure in patients with acute coronary syndrome. We enrolled 50 patients who underwent coronary angiography and measured collateral flow index (CFI) using the Rentrop scoring system. The rate of vessel closure was assessed by angiographic findings and electrocardiographic changes. 

Our results showed a significant correlation between CFI and the rate of vessel closure (p<0.001). Patients with higher CFI had a lower rate of vessel closure, indicating a protective effect of collateral circulation. Furthermore, patients with higher CFI had significantly smaller infarct sizes and better myocardial salvage as assessed by cardiac magnetic resonance imaging (p<0.05).

In conclusion, coronary collateral recruitment plays a significant role in reducing the rate of vessel closure in patients with acute coronary syndrome. These findings suggest that promoting collateral vessel development may have therapeutic implications in the management of acute coronary syndrome. Further studies are warranted to explore strategies for enhancing collateral recruitment in this clinical setting.

Metastatic small cell tumor of bone with 'true' rosettes and glial fibrillary acidic protein positivity. Metastatic small cell tumor of bone is a rare malignancy characterized by aggressive behavior and poor prognosis. Here, we report a case of a 56-year-old male presenting with bone pain and fractures, who was found to have widespread metastasis to the skeletal system. Histopathological examination of the bone biopsy specimen revealed the presence of 'true' rosettes, a characteristic feature of this tumor. Additionally, immunohistochemical analysis demonstrated positive staining for glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP), a marker typically associated with glial tumors. This unexpected finding suggests a possible neuroendocrine origin of this tumor, as GFAP expression is not commonly observed in small cell tumors. Treatment options for metastatic small cell tumor of bone remain limited, and prognosis is generally unfavorable. Further research is needed to better understand the pathogenesis and identify potential targeted therapies for this aggressive malignancy.

Extrahepatic portal vein aneurysm associated with a tortuous portal vein. Extrahepatic portal vein aneurysm is a rare vascular anomaly that can lead to life-threatening complications such as rupture and portal hypertension. This case report presents a unique case of an extrahepatic portal vein aneurysm associated with a tortuous portal vein in a 56-year-old male patient. The patient presented with abdominal pain and was diagnosed with an aneurysm located in the extrahepatic segment of the portal vein. Imaging studies revealed a tortuous portal vein, which may have played a role in the development of the aneurysm. The patient underwent surgical intervention, including aneurysm resection and portal vein reconstruction. Pathological examination confirmed the diagnosis of an extrahepatic portal vein aneurysm. Postoperative recovery was uneventful, and the patient remained symptom-free during the follow-up period. This case highlights the importance of considering extrahepatic portal vein aneurysms in the differential diagnosis of patients presenting with abdominal pain and provides insights into the association with a tortuous portal vein.

Pancreaticobiliary ductal union. Pancreaticobiliary ductal union is a congenital anomaly characterized by the anatomical joining of the pancreatic and bile ducts.
