This condition is known to result in various clinical manifestations and is often associated with pancreaticobiliary diseases, such as choledochal cysts, pancreatitis, and cholangiocarcinoma. This study aimed to investigate the incidence and clinical features of pancreaticobiliary ductal union in a cohort of patients with pancreaticobiliary diseases. A total of 150 patients who underwent endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) were included in the study. The presence of pancreaticobiliary ductal union was assessed based on ERCP findings. The results showed that 28 patients (18.7%) had pancreaticobiliary ductal union, with a higher prevalence in patients with choledochal cysts and cholangiocarcinoma. Additionally, patients with pancreaticobiliary ductal union had a higher incidence of pancreatitis compared to those without this anomaly. These findings suggest that pancreaticobiliary ductal union is a significant risk factor for the development of pancreaticobiliary diseases and should be taken into consideration during diagnostic and therapeutic approaches in these patients.

Benign missense variations in the cystic fibrosis gene. The cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) gene is associated with cystic fibrosis (CF), a genetic disorder that affects multiple organs, including the lungs and digestive system. While CF is typically caused by deleterious mutations in the CFTR gene, there is growing evidence that benign missense variations in this gene may also play a role in disease pathogenesis. This study aimed to investigate the frequency and functional consequences of benign missense variations in the CFTR gene in a cohort of CF patients. A total of 256 CF patients were included in the study, and genetic analysis revealed the presence of several benign missense variations. Furthermore, functional studies indicated that these variations resulted in altered CFTR protein function. These findings suggest that benign missense variations in the CFTR gene may contribute to CF pathogenesis and should be considered in genetic testing and counseling for CF patients.

Polyglucosan body disease.  Adult polyglucosan disease has been described in 15 cases. Polyglucosan body disease is a rare genetic disorder characterized by the accumulation of abnormal glycogen-like material in various tissues. It manifests clinically with progressive neurological symptoms including cognitive impairment, gait disturbances, urinary incontinence, and peripheral neuropathy. The disease primarily affects adults, with onset typically occurring between the fourth and sixth decade of life. Diagnosis is based on clinical presentation, histopathological examination of affected tissues, and specific enzymatic or genetic testing. Treatment options are limited and primarily focused on supportive care to manage symptoms and optimize quality of life. The prognosis of polyglucosan body disease is variable, with some patients experiencing a slow, progressive decline in neurological function, while others may have a more stable clinical course. Further research is needed to understand the underlying molecular mechanisms and develop targeted therapeutic interventions for this rare disorder.

Susceptibility to invasive Haemophilus influenzae type b disease and the immunoglobulin G2m(n) allotype. Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib) is a major cause of invasive bacterial infections in young children. It has been observed that individuals with a deficiency in immunoglobulin G2m(n) allotype have an increased susceptibility to Hib disease. In this study, we investigated the relationship between immunoglobulin G2m(n) allotype and susceptibility to invasive Hib disease in a cohort of 200 children. We found that children with the G2m(n-) allotype had a significantly higher risk of developing invasive Hib disease compared to children with the G2m(n+) allotype (odds ratio 2.3, 95% confidence interval 1.1-4.8). These findings provide further evidence for the role of immunoglobulin G2m(n) allotype in susceptibility to invasive Hib disease and highlight the importance of vaccination in individuals at higher risk.

Effects of prostaglandin E1 on collagen diseases with high levels of circulating immune complexes. Prostaglandin E1 (PGE1) has been used in the treatment of collagen diseases characterized by high levels of circulating immune complexes (CICs). We conducted a study to evaluate the effects of PGE1 on this specific subgroup of patients. Seventeen patients with collagen diseases and elevated CIC levels were included in the study. PGE1 administration resulted in a significant reduction in CIC levels in all patients. Additionally, clinical symptoms and laboratory parameters such as erythrocyte sedimentation rate and C-reactive protein improved after PGE1 treatment. No significant adverse effects were observed. These findings suggest that PGE1 may be an effective therapeutic option for patients with collagen diseases characterized by high levels of CICs. Further studies are warranted to elucidate the underlying mechanisms of action.

Acute syphilitic posterior placoid chorioretinitis.  Six patients with evidence of secondary syphilis presented with visual loss in both eyes caused by large, placoid, yellowish lesions with faded centers at the level of the pigment epithelium in the macula and juxtapapillary areas. Acute syphilitic posterior placoid chorioretinitis is a rare manifestation of secondary syphilis that can cause significant visual loss. This abstract presents a case series of six patients who presented with visual symptoms and were subsequently diagnosed with this condition. All patients had evidence of secondary syphilis and exhibited large, placoid lesions with yellowish pigmentation and faded centers in the macula and juxtapapillary areas. The lesions were located at the level of the pigment epithelium in the retina. Prompt diagnosis and early initiation of appropriate treatment resulted in improvement in visual acuity in all patients. This case series highlights the importance of considering syphilis as a potential etiology in patients presenting with posterior placoid chorioretinitis, particularly in the context of secondary syphilis.

Extrapyramidal features in advanced Down's syndrome: clinical evaluation and family history.  Extrapyramidal, frontal release, and other neurological signs were studied in 54 demented and non-demented patients with Down's syndrome (DS). A comprehensive evaluation of extrapyramidal features in advanced Down's syndrome was conducted, focusing on clinical presentation and family history. A total of 54 patients with DS, both with and without dementia, were included in this study. The presence of extrapyramidal signs, frontal release signs, and other neurological abnormalities were assessed using standardized clinical evaluation tools. The results revealed that a significant proportion of patients with DS exhibited extrapyramidal features, such as parkinsonism-like symptoms and dystonia. Interestingly, a positive family history of similar neurological signs was found in a substantial number of patients. This suggests a potential genetic component to the development of extrapyramidal features in DS. The findings of this study contribute to a better understanding of the neurological manifestations in individuals with DS and highlight the importance of considering genetic factors in the evaluation and management of these patients.

Thoracoscopic treatment of spontaneous pneumothorax using carbon dioxide laser. Spontaneous pneumothorax is a common condition that often requires surgical intervention for definitive treatment. Thoracoscopy has emerged as an effective minimally invasive approach for the management of spontaneous pneumothorax. This abstract reports the use of a carbon dioxide laser in the thoracoscopic treatment of spontaneous pneumothorax.

A retrospective analysis was conducted on a cohort of patients who underwent thoracoscopic treatment for spontaneous pneumothorax using a carbon dioxide laser. The surgical procedure involved creating multiple small incisions in the chest wall and inserting a thoracoscope to visualize the lung and pleural cavity. The carbon dioxide laser was then used to ablate small blebs and bullae, seal air leaks, and perform pleurodesis.

Preliminary results from this analysis demonstrate successful treatment outcomes with minimal postoperative complications. The carbon dioxide laser proved to be a safe and efficient tool for precise tissue ablation and hemostasis during thoracoscopic surgery. This innovative approach offers several advantages, including reduced postoperative pain, shorter hospital stays, and improved cosmesis.

Further studies are needed to validate these findings and compare the outcomes of carbon dioxide laser-assisted thoracoscopy with traditional surgical techniques.

Use of the metabolic tracer carbon-11-acetate for evaluation of regional myocardial perfusion.  The high first-pass myocardial extraction fraction of carbon-11-acetate suggests that its initial uptake depends on blood flow.  Accordingly, regional uptake of 11C-acetate at 4 min was compared to regional perfusion determined with nitrogen-13-ammonia in 119 segments in 15 patients with stable coronary artery disease by two methods.  A close correlation was observed between initial relative myocardial concentrations (segmental activity normalized to maximal activity) of both tracers (11C-acetate = 0. 88; 13N-ammonia + 0. This suggests that carbon-11-acetate can be used as a metabolic tracer to evaluate regional myocardial perfusion. The study included 15 patients with stable coronary artery disease, and regional uptake of carbon-11-acetate at 4 minutes was compared to regional perfusion determined with nitrogen-13-ammonia. A strong correlation was observed between the initial relative myocardial concentrations of both tracers, indicating that carbon-11-acetate uptake is dependent on blood flow. These findings suggest that carbon-11-acetate has the potential to be a valuable tool for evaluating regional myocardial perfusion in patients with coronary artery disease. Further research is warranted to validate these findings and explore the utility of carbon-11-acetate in clinical practice.

Prehospital care: the future of emergency medical services. The field of prehospital care is continually evolving and plays a crucial role in emergency medical services (EMS). This report discusses the future of prehospital care and highlights key developments that are shaping the field. These advancements include the integration of technology, such as telemedicine and mobile health applications, allowing for real-time communication and remote medical guidance. Additionally, there is a growing emphasis on community paramedicine, where paramedics are trained to provide extended care beyond traditional emergency response, bridging the gap between primary care and emergency medicine. The implementation of alternative transport options, such as use of drones and autonomous vehicles, has the potential to enhance response times and optimize patient outcomes. Furthermore, the importance of incorporating mental health support and trauma-informed care into prehospital care is recognized. Overall, the future of prehospital care holds promise for improved patient outcomes through innovative approaches and advancements in technology.

Colposcopic survey of Papanicolaou test-negative cases with hyperkeratosis or parakeratosis. Colposcopy is a valuable tool in evaluating women who have abnormal Papanicolaou (Pap) test results. However, there is limited data on the significance of hyperkeratosis or parakeratosis observed during colposcopy in women with negative Pap tests. This study aimed to evaluate the clinical outcomes of women with hyperkeratosis or parakeratosis detected during colposcopy in the absence of visible cervical abnormalities. A retrospective analysis was conducted on women who underwent colposcopy with negative Pap results from a single center. The findings showed that among the women with hyperkeratosis or parakeratosis, none had high-grade squamous intraepithelial lesions or cervical cancer. These results suggest that hyperkeratosis or parakeratosis alone in the absence of visible cervical abnormalities may not require further intervention or invasive testing, providing reassurance to both clinicians and patients. Future prospective studies are needed to validate these findings.

Fluorosilicone oil in the treatment of retinal detachment. Retinal detachment is a sight-threatening condition that requires prompt treatment to prevent permanent visual impairment. We evaluated the efficacy of fluorosilicone oil in the management of retinal detachment. A retrospective analysis was conducted on 55 eyes of 53 patients who underwent retinal detachment repair using fluorosilicone oil as a tamponade. The primary outcome measure was anatomical success, defined as attachment of the retina at the final follow-up visit. Secondary outcome measures included visual acuity improvement and complications associated with the use of fluorosilicone oil. At the final follow-up visit, anatomical success was achieved in 50 eyes (90.9%). Visual acuity improved in 43 eyes (78.2%). Complications included cataract formation in 13 eyes (23.6%), glaucoma in 4 eyes (7.2%), and silicone oil emulsification in 2 eyes (3.6%). Fluorosilicone oil demonstrated a high success rate in the management of retinal detachment, with a low incidence of complications. Further prospective studies are warranted to confirm these findings and compare fluorosilicone oil to other tamponade agents.

Human immunodeficiency virus-induced immunosuppression: a risk factor for human papillomavirus infection.  In a group of 92 women with genital condylomata, 15 (16. 4%) were found to be positive for human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection. This rate is significantly higher than the estimated HIV prevalence in the general population. We conducted a retrospective study to further investigate the association between HIV-induced immunosuppression and human papillomavirus (HPV) infection. We found that the presence of HIV infection was strongly associated with increased risk of HPV infection in our study population (odds ratio = 4.27, 95% confidence interval: 1.79-10.19). Furthermore, among the HIV-positive women, we observed a higher prevalence of high-risk HPV genotypes, suggesting a potential link between HIV-induced immunosuppression and the development of HPV-related malignancies. Our findings highlight the importance of offering routine HPV screening and vaccination to HIV-positive women to reduce the burden of HPV-related diseases in this population.

Kinin/prostaglandin system: its therapeutic value in surgical stress. The kinin/prostaglandin system plays a crucial role in the pathophysiology of surgical stress. Kinins, such as bradykinin, and prostaglandins, including PGE2 and PGD2, are released in response to tissue injury and inflammation during surgery. These mediators are involved in various physiological processes, including vasodilation, increased vascular permeability, pain modulation, and immune regulation. However, excessive activation of the kinin/prostaglandin system can contribute to the development of complications such as edema, hypotension, and hyperalgesia. Therefore, pharmacological modulation of this system has been investigated as a potential therapeutic strategy to mitigate surgical stress. Inhibition of kinin receptors or prostaglandin synthesis has shown promising results in animal models and small-scale clinical trials. The use of specific antagonists and inhibitors of kinin and prostaglandin receptors has demonstrated reduced inflammatory response, improved wound healing, and enhanced postoperative recovery. The present review summarizes the current understanding of the kinin/prostaglandin system in surgical stress and discusses its therapeutic potential as a target for intervention in surgical patients. Further larger-scale clinical trials are needed to validate the efficacy and safety of pharmacological manipulation of this system in the surgical setting.

Buerger's colour.  Cyanosis of the hands and feet in Buerger's disease is known as 'Buerger's colour'. Buerger's disease, also known as thromboangiitis obliterans, is a non-atherosclerotic segmental inflammatory disease affecting small- to medium-sized arteries and veins, predominantly in the upper and lower extremities. A distinct clinical manifestation of this disease is the development of cyanosis of the hands and feet, known as "Buerger's colour". This discoloration is due to the occlusion of peripheral arteries, leading to reduced blood flow and tissue oxygenation. Buerger's colour is typically observed during acute exacerbations of the disease and is often accompanied by other symptoms such as ischemic pain, ulcers, and gangrene. Proper recognition and understanding of this characteristic feature can aid in the diagnosis and management of Buerger's disease. Early intervention with smoking cessation and vasodilator therapy, along with regular monitoring, is essential to prevent disease progression and minimize complications.

Computed tomography-guided fine-needle aspiration of retroperitoneal lymph nodes in gynecologic oncology. The authors present a retrospective analysis of the utility and safety of computed tomography (CT)-guided fine-needle aspiration (FNA) of retroperitoneal lymph nodes in the field of gynecologic oncology. A total of 45 patients who underwent CT-guided FNA between January 2015 and December 2020 were included in the study. The main indications for the procedure were suspicious lymph nodes identified on imaging studies or during surgery. The results of the FNAs were correlated with subsequent histopathology from surgical lymph node dissection or other diagnostic procedures. The study found that CT-guided FNA had a high diagnostic accuracy of 88%, with a sensitivity of 84% and specificity of 92%. Complications related to the procedure were rare, with only one case of minor bleeding requiring intervention. The authors conclude that CT-guided FNA is a valuable tool in the management of gynecologic oncology patients, as it provides accurate and safe guidance for obtaining tissue samples from retroperitoneal lymph nodes for diagnosis and staging purposes. Further studies are warranted to validate these findings and assess long-term outcomes.

Causes of death in hospitalized intravenous drug abusers.  The authors reviewed at autopsy the causes of death of 274 patients with evidence of intravenous drug abuse who had been admitted to a large public hospital. The study aimed to determine the causes of death in hospitalized intravenous drug abusers. A total of 274 patients who had evidence of intravenous drug abuse and were admitted to a large public hospital were included in the study. Autopsy reports were reviewed to identify the underlying causes of death for these patients.

The results showed various causes of death among the study population. The most common cause of death was drug overdose, accounting for 61% of the cases. Infections related to drug abuse, such as endocarditis and sepsis, were the second most frequent cause of death, accounting for 17% of the cases. Other causes of death included respiratory failure (9%), cardiovascular disease (6%), and trauma (5%).

These findings highlight the significant morbidity and mortality associated with intravenous drug abuse. Effective strategies for harm reduction and prevention of drug-related complications should be implemented to address this growing public health concern.

Occult vascular malformations of the optic chiasm: magnetic resonance imaging diagnosis and surgical laser resection.  Angiographically occult vascular malformations of the optic nerve and chiasm are extremely rare. We report two cases of occult vascular malformations involving the optic chiasm, diagnosed using magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), and surgically treated with laser resection. Both patients presented with progressive visual loss and optic disc edema. MRI revealed subtle hyperintense signals on T2-weighted images, which were confirmed to be vascular malformations on angiography. Microvascular decompression surgery was performed in both cases, using a CO2 laser to coagulate and resect the abnormal vessels. Postoperative ophthalmologic examinations showed improvement in visual acuity and resolution of optic disc edema. Follow-up MRI demonstrated complete resection of the vascular malformations. Occult vascular malformations of the optic chiasm are challenging to diagnose and treat due to their uncommon occurrence and subtle imaging findings. MRI is a valuable diagnostic tool in these cases, providing detailed anatomical information for surgical planning and successful resection of the malformations.

Cone cerclage in pregnancy.  We report a technique of cone cerclage and the results and outcome in 17 patients who required a diagnostic cone biopsy in pregnancy. Cervical incompetence can lead to premature cervical dilation in pregnancy, resulting in preterm birth or miscarriage. Cone cerclage is a surgical intervention that involves placing a suture around the cervix to reinforce its structural integrity. In this study, we present the technique of cone cerclage and evaluate the outcomes of 17 pregnant patients who underwent diagnostic cone biopsy. All patients exhibited signs of cervical incompetence on initial examination and had abnormal cervical histology. The cone cerclage procedure was successfully performed in all cases, with no intraoperative or postoperative complications. Follow-up assessments revealed that all patients maintained their pregnancies for the intended duration and delivered healthy infants without any signs of premature cervical dilation. Cone cerclage appears to be an effective intervention for managing cervical incompetence in pregnancy and may contribute to improved obstetric outcomes. Further studies are needed to determine the long-term effects and success rates of this technique.

Regression of the left main trunk lesion by steroid administration in Takayasu's aortitis. We report a case of Takayasu's aortitis in a 42-year-old female who presented with left main trunk stenosis. The patient was initially treated with high-dose steroids, resulting in significant regression of the stenotic lesion. Takayasu's aortitis is a chronic inflammatory disease affecting the aorta and its branches, commonly leading to stenosis and aneurysm formation. Treatment typically involves corticosteroids, immunosuppressive agents, and endovascular interventions. However, there have been limited reports on the regression of stenotic lesions with steroid administration alone. This case highlights the potential efficacy of high-dose steroids in inducing regression of the left main trunk lesion in Takayasu's aortitis, underscoring the importance of considering conservative management options before proceeding to invasive interventions.

Successful control of bleeding from gastric antral vascular ectasia (watermelon stomach) by laser photocoagulation. Gastric antral vascular ectasia (GAVE), commonly known as watermelon stomach, is a rare cause of chronic gastrointestinal bleeding. Various treatment modalities have been employed to control bleeding, but laser photocoagulation has emerged as an effective and safe method. In this retrospective study, we evaluated the outcome of laser photocoagulation in 15 patients with GAVE. All patients had evidence of active bleeding at the time of endoscopy, and successful hemostasis was achieved in all cases. No major complications were encountered. Our findings suggest that laser photocoagulation is an effective therapeutic option for controlling bleeding in patients with GAVE.

Fusiform dilatations of the carotid artery following radical surgery of childhood craniopharyngiomas. We present a series of cases demonstrating fusiform dilatations of the carotid artery following radical surgery for childhood craniopharyngiomas. Five patients, aged 7 to 14 years, underwent extensive tumor resection via a transcranial approach. Postoperative imaging revealed a progressive fusiform dilatation of the ipsilateral carotid artery in all cases. The dilatation extended from the cavernous to the cervical segment of the artery, with an average increase in diameter of 2 mm. None of the patients presented with symptoms related to the carotid artery dilatation, and there were no cases of rupture or thromboembolic events during the follow-up period. We hypothesize that the extensive surgical dissection and manipulation of surrounding tissues during craniopharyngioma surgery may have contributed to the subsequent dilatation of the carotid artery. Long-term follow-up is necessary to determine the clinical significance and potential complications associated with this finding.

Endoscopic treatment of biliary tract strictures in sclerosing cholangitis: a larger series and recommendations for treatment. Endoscopic treatment is a valuable approach for managing biliary tract strictures in patients with sclerosing cholangitis. This study presents a larger series of patients who underwent endoscopic therapy for biliary strictures associated with sclerosing cholangitis. The study aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of endoscopic treatment and provide recommendations for its use. A total of XX patients with sclerosing cholangitis-related biliary strictures were included in the study. The endoscopic treatment consisted of balloon dilatation, temporary stent placement, and permanent stenting. The overall success rate of endoscopic therapy was XX%. The authors recommend considering endoscopic treatment as a first-line option in managing biliary strictures in patients with sclerosing cholangitis.

IgG and IgA antibodies to the collagen-like region of C1q in rheumatoid vasculitis. Rheumatoid vasculitis is a rare but serious complication of rheumatoid arthritis, characterized by inflammation of blood vessels leading to tissue damage. The role of autoantibodies in this condition remains unclear. In this study, we aimed to investigate the presence of IgG and IgA antibodies to the collagen-like region of C1q in patients with rheumatoid vasculitis.

Sera from 35 patients diagnosed with rheumatoid vasculitis were analyzed for the presence of IgG and IgA antibodies to the collagen-like region of C1q using an enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA). Results were compared to sera from 35 rheumatoid arthritis patients without vasculitis and 35 healthy controls.

We found that IgG antibodies to the collagen-like region of C1q were significantly elevated in patients with rheumatoid vasculitis compared to both the rheumatoid arthritis group (p<0.001) and healthy controls (p<0.001). However, no significant difference was observed in IgA antibodies to the collagen-like region of C1q between the groups.

These findings suggest a potential role for IgG antibodies to the collagen-like region of C1q in the pathogenesis of rheumatoid vasculitis. Further studies are warranted to elucidate the exact mechanisms underlying this association and to determine the potential diagnostic and therapeutic implications of these autoantibodies in rheumatoid vasculitis.

Ventricular responses to mental stress testing in patients with coronary artery disease. Mental stress testing is commonly used in patients with coronary artery disease (CAD) to assess the impact of psychological stress on cardiovascular function. This study aimed to evaluate the ventricular responses to mental stress testing in patients with CAD. Forty-five patients with documented CAD underwent mental stress testing using a standardized protocol. Echocardiographic measurements were obtained at rest and during mental stress, including left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF), regional wall motion abnormalities (RWMA), and cardiac output (CO). Significant changes were observed in LVEF, RWMA, and CO during mental stress compared to rest. Patients with more severe CAD exhibited significant reductions in LVEF and CO during mental stress. These findings suggest that mental stress testing may induce ventricular dysfunction in patients with CAD, particularly those with advanced disease. Further research is warranted to investigate the underlying mechanisms and potential impact on prognosis in this population.

Immunoglobulins A, G, and M to cytomegalovirus during recurrent infection in recipients of allogeneic bone marrow transplantation. Cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection is a significant complication in recipients of allogeneic bone marrow transplantation (BMT). Understanding the immune response to recurrent CMV infection in these patients is crucial for the development of effective therapeutic strategies. In this study, we investigated the levels of immunoglobulins A, G, and M (IgA, IgG, and IgM) against CMV in recipients of allogeneic BMT during recurrent CMV infection. Serum samples were collected from 30 patients with recurrent CMV infection and analyzed for the presence of CMV-specific IgA, IgG, and IgM antibodies. We found that the levels of all three immunoglobulins were significantly elevated during recurrent CMV infection compared to pre-infection levels. Moreover, the levels of IgA and IgM remained elevated even after the resolution of CMV infection, indicating a persistent immune response. These findings suggest that monitoring the levels of CMV-specific immunoglobulins could serve as a useful diagnostic and prognostic tool in recipients of allogeneic BMT with recurrent CMV infection.

Efficacy of doxazosin in specific hypertensive patient groups. Hypertension is a common medical condition that affects a significant proportion of the population. Doxazosin, an alpha-1 adrenergic blocker, has been widely used for the management of hypertension. However, the efficacy of doxazosin in specific hypertensive patient groups remains uncertain. In this study, we aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of doxazosin in different patient subgroups.

A systematic review and meta-analysis were performed, including randomized controlled trials that compared doxazosin with placebo or other antihypertensive medications. Subgroup analyses were conducted based on patient characteristics such as age, gender, race, and comorbidities. The primary outcome measure was the change in systolic and diastolic blood pressure from baseline.

Preliminary results indicate that doxazosin significantly reduces both systolic and diastolic blood pressure in all patient subgroups. However, the magnitude of blood pressure reduction varied among different groups. Elderly patients and those with comorbidities demonstrated a greater reduction in blood pressure compared to younger individuals. Gender and racial differences did not seem to affect the efficacy of doxazosin.

These findings suggest that doxazosin is an effective antihypertensive agent, particularly in older patients and those with comorbidities. Further research is warranted to explore the optimal dosing and long-term outcomes of doxazosin in specific hypertensive patient groups.

Traumatic and spontaneous extracranial internal carotid artery dissections. Extracranial internal carotid artery dissections (EICAD) can occur either spontaneously or as a result of trauma. This study aimed to compare the clinical characteristics and outcomes of traumatic and spontaneous EICAD cases. A retrospective analysis was conducted on 67 patients diagnosed with EICAD between 2010 and 2018. The patients' medical records were reviewed to collect demographic data, clinical features, imaging findings, treatment modalities, and outcome measures. Of the 67 patients, 39 had traumatic EICAD and 28 had spontaneous EICAD. The traumatic group exhibited a significantly higher prevalence of male patients and were more likely to have a history of recent trauma compared to the spontaneous group. Additionally, traumatic cases were more frequently associated with vascular injury in other vessels. However, there were no significant differences between the two groups in terms of presenting symptoms, imaging characteristics, treatment modalities, or long-term outcomes. This study contributes to the understanding of EICAD and highlights the importance of thorough evaluation and appropriate management in both traumatic and spontaneous cases.

Partial laryngectomy after irradiation failure.  Forty-three patients who had partial laryngectomies after radiotherapy were evaluated. Partial laryngectomy is a common surgical intervention for patients with laryngeal cancer who have failed previous radiotherapy treatment. This retrospective study aimed to evaluate the outcomes of partial laryngectomy in 43 patients who had undergone the procedure after irradiation failure. Patient demographics, tumor characteristics, surgical techniques, and postoperative complications were analyzed. Results showed that the majority of patients (69.8%) had T3 or T4 tumors prior to the partial laryngectomy. The surgical techniques utilized included supraglottic laryngectomy, supracricoid partial laryngectomy, and hemilaryngectomy. Postoperative complications were observed in 34.9% of patients, the most common being pharyngocutaneous fistula. Out of the total cohort, 62.8% of patients maintained satisfactory voice quality postoperatively. The overall survival rate at 5 years was 49.8%. These findings indicate that partial laryngectomy can be an effective salvage treatment option for patients with laryngeal cancer who have failed irradiation, although complications should be carefully monitored and managed. Further studies are warranted to optimize patient selection and surgical techniques in this population.

Magnetic resonance imaging of experimental rat brain tumors: histopathological evaluation. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is widely used in the diagnosis and monitoring of brain tumors. However, the correlation between MRI findings and histopathological characteristics of these tumors remains poorly understood. In this study, we evaluated the accuracy of MRI in depicting the histopathological features of experimental rat brain tumors. T2-weighted MRI images were obtained from rats with induced brain tumors, and the tumors were subsequently histopathologically examined. The MRI findings were compared with the histopathological features, including tumor type, grade, vascularity, and necrosis. Our results showed a high correlation between MRI findings and histopathological characteristics of brain tumors, with an overall accuracy of 85%. MRI accurately depicted tumor type, grade, and vascularity, but showed limitations in detecting necrosis. These findings provide valuable insights into the utility of MRI in evaluating brain tumors, supporting its role as a reliable imaging modality in the clinical management of these tumors.

Eosinophilia-myalgia syndrome.  A clinical case series of 21 patients. Eosinophilia-myalgia syndrome (EMS) is a rare and potentially life-threatening disorder characterized by the development of eosinophilia and severe myalgia. This study aims to provide a comprehensive analysis of 21 clinical cases of EMS and to identify potential risk factors and clinical manifestations associated with the syndrome. 

The medical records of 21 patients diagnosed with EMS were reviewed in this retrospective case series. The mean age of the patients was 46 years, and the majority were female (81%). All patients presented with a history of exposure to L-tryptophan supplements before the development of symptoms. The most common clinical manifestations observed were myalgia (100%), eosinophilia (95%), skin changes (76%), and peripheral neuropathy (43%). 

Laboratory investigations revealed elevated levels of eosinophils in all patients, with a mean count of 5,000 cells/mm3. Peripheral nerve biopsies demonstrated eosinophil infiltration in 62% of cases. Treatment consisted of discontinuation of L-tryptophan supplements and administration of systemic glucocorticoids. 

This case series highlights the importance of recognizing EMS as a potential complication of L-tryptophan use and underscores the need for increased awareness among healthcare professionals. Prompt diagnosis and appropriate management are essential for minimizing morbidity and preventing long-term complications in patients with EMS.

Ichthyosis, exocrine pancreatic insufficiency, impaired neutrophil chemotaxis, growth retardation, and metaphyseal dysplasia (Shwachman syndrome).  Report of a case with extensive skin lesions (clinical, histological, and ultrastructural findings). We present a case report of a patient with Shwachman syndrome, a rare genetic disorder characterized by multiple systemic manifestations. This case is unique due to the extensive skin lesions observed in the patient, which is a rarely reported clinical feature of the syndrome. The patient presented with ichthyosis, exocrine pancreatic insufficiency, impaired neutrophil chemotaxis, growth retardation, and metaphyseal dysplasia, all of which are characteristic of Shwachman syndrome. Clinical examination revealed widespread scaling, thickening, and erythema of the skin. Histological analysis of skin biopsy specimens showed hyperkeratosis, acanthosis, and vacuolar degeneration of the epidermis. Furthermore, ultrastructural examination revealed abnormal keratinization and disorganized epidermal architecture. This case highlights the importance of considering Shwachman syndrome in the differential diagnosis of patients who present with extensive skin lesions and systemic features associated with the syndrome. Additionally, it emphasizes the need for further research to better understand the pathogenesis of the cutaneous manifestations in this rare disorder.

mtDNA depletion with variable tissue expression: a novel genetic abnormality in mitochondrial diseases. We present a case of a 4-year-old male with a complex mitochondrial disease characterized by multisystem involvement. The patient presented with severe hypotonia, developmental delay, dysmorphic features, and metabolic acidosis. Initial investigations revealed a depletion of mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) in muscle biopsy, leading to a diagnosis of mtDNA depletion syndrome. However, further genetic testing revealed an atypical presentation of mtDNA depletion syndrome with a novel genetic abnormality characterized by variable tissue expression. This case highlights the importance of considering mtDNA depletion syndromes in the differential diagnosis of patients with multisystem involvement and metabolic abnormalities. It also emphasizes the need for comprehensive genetic testing to identify rare genetic variants and expand our understanding of mitochondrial diseases. Further research is warranted to elucidate the underlying pathophysiological mechanisms and potential targeted treatments for this unique genetic variant.

SPECT imaging of pediatric brain tumor with hexakis (methoxyisobutylisonitrile) technetium (I). This study aimed to evaluate the utility of single-photon emission computed tomography (SPECT) imaging using hexakis (methoxyisobutylisonitrile) technetium (I) (99mTc-MIBI) in pediatric patients with brain tumors. Twenty-eight patients (mean age 8.6 years) with suspected brain tumors underwent SPECT imaging after intravenous administration of 99mTc-MIBI. The results were compared with histopathological findings or clinical follow-up. SPECT imaging showed increased uptake of 99mTc-MIBI in 78.6% of the tumors, with a sensitivity of 73.7% and a specificity of 80.0% for detecting brain tumors. The positive predictive value and negative predictive value were 93.5% and 40.0%, respectively. The overall accuracy of 99mTc-MIBI SPECT imaging in pediatric brain tumor diagnosis was 75.0%. No adverse effects were observed. These findings suggest that SPECT imaging with 99mTc-MIBI is a safe and moderately accurate method for detecting brain tumors in pediatric patients, providing valuable information for diagnosis and treatment planning. Further studies with larger sample sizes are warranted to confirm these results.

Pulmonary acinar development in diaphragmatic hernia. Diaphragmatic hernia (DH) is a congenital anomaly characterized by the protrusion of abdominal contents into the thoracic cavity through a defect in the diaphragm. This condition can lead to pulmonary hypoplasia and abnormal acinar development in affected infants. However, the specific mechanisms underlying these abnormalities are not well understood. In this study, we performed histological and imaging analyses of lung tissue from neonates diagnosed with DH. We found that DH was associated with reduced lung weight, decreased overall lung volume, and altered alveolar structure. Furthermore, we observed impaired branching morphogenesis and reduced expression of key markers of alveolar development. These findings suggest that DH disrupts normal pulmonary acinar development, leading to pulmonary hypoplasia. Further studies are needed to elucidate the cellular and molecular mechanisms involved in this process, which could potentially inform the development of therapeutic interventions to improve pulmonary outcomes in infants with DH.

Developmental dysmnesia in a poor reader. Developmental dysmnesia refers to a specific subtype of developmental amnesia characterized by severe difficulties in the acquisition and retention of declarative memory skills, despite normal intelligence and other cognitive functions. This case report presents the unique finding of developmental dysmnesia in a 9-year-old child who also exhibited poor reading skills. The patient's medical history revealed no significant medical conditions or head trauma that could account for the memory impairment. Neuropsychological assessments confirmed significant deficits in episodic and semantic memory, while other cognitive domains remained relatively intact. The co-occurrence of developmental dysmnesia with poor reading skills suggests a potential overlap between memory and language processing systems. Further research is needed to elucidate the underlying mechanisms and treatment strategies for this rare combination.

Treatment of vaginal candidiasis: orally or vaginally? Vaginal candidiasis continues to be the most common cause of vaginal discharge. Vaginal candidiasis is a prevalent condition characterized by the overgrowth of Candida species in the vaginal region. Despite its high incidence, there remains a lack of consensus regarding the optimal treatment approach. Currently, two main administration routes are widely employed: oral and vaginal. This study aims to evaluate the efficacy of these treatment modalities in patients with vaginal candidiasis. A systematic review and meta-analysis was conducted, including 15 randomized controlled trials involving a total of 2,500 participants. The results revealed that both oral and vaginal treatments exhibited comparable rates of clinical cure and mycological eradication. However, oral therapy demonstrated a slightly higher risk of adverse events compared to vaginal treatment. Therefore, considering the similar efficacy and potentially lower risk of complications, vaginal administration may be preferred as the primary treatment approach for vaginal candidiasis. Further research is warranted to validate these findings and address any remaining uncertainties.

Pseudocyst of the auricle: successful treatment with intracartilaginous trichloroacetic acid and button bolsters. Pseudocyst of the auricle is a rare condition characterized by the presence of a fluid-filled cystic lesion in the auricle. While various treatment approaches have been described, there is no consensus on the optimal management strategy. This case report presents a successful treatment approach using intracartilaginous trichloroacetic acid (TCA) injection and button bolsters. A 45-year-old male patient with a large pseudocyst of the right auricle was treated with multiple intracartilaginous injections of 50% TCA solution followed by the placement of button bolsters for compression and support. The treatment resulted in complete resolution of the pseudocyst without any complications. This minimally invasive technique offers a safe and effective treatment option for pseudocyst of the auricle, avoiding the need for surgery and potential complications associated with invasive procedures.

Immunohistochemical demonstration of pancreatic secretory trypsin inhibitor in normal and neoplastic colonic mucosa. Pancreatic secretory trypsin inhibitor (PSTI) is a protein involved in the protection of the pancreas and gastrointestinal tract against protease-mediated damage. This study aimed to investigate the presence of PSTI in normal and neoplastic colonic mucosa using immunohistochemistry. A total of 50 samples, including normal colon tissue and various stages of colorectal neoplasms, were analyzed. Immunohistochemical staining was performed and the expression of PSTI was evaluated based on staining intensity and distribution. The results showed that PSTI was consistently present in the cytoplasm of normal colonic epithelial cells, with a predominantly diffuse staining pattern. In neoplastic colonic mucosa, the expression of PSTI varied, with some cases showing decreased staining intensity or focal absence. However, overall, PSTI expression was maintained in a majority of neoplastic lesions. These findings suggest that PSTI may play a role in the protection of colonic mucosa, and alterations in its expression may be associated with the development or progression of colorectal neoplasms.

Enveloping the bladder with displacement of flap of the rectus abdominis muscle for the treatment of neurogenic bladder. Neurogenic bladder is a common complication in patients with spinal cord injury or neurological disorders, leading to urinary incontinence and urinary tract infections. Various surgical techniques have been developed to improve bladder function and prevent these complications. In this study, we present a novel surgical technique involving enveloping the bladder with displacement of a flap of the rectus abdominis muscle. This technique aims to provide a protective barrier between the bladder and surrounding tissues, reducing the risk of bladder injury and improving bladder capacity. Preliminary results in a small cohort of patients show promising outcomes, with improved bladder function and reduced complications. Further studies are needed to evaluate the long-term efficacy and safety of this technique.
